GAME: El Grande
RANK: 51

RATING: 10
One of the best games ever. Easy rules, planety tactics, visual appeal and great tension. 

Works well with three or more (I disagree that it needs 5 as some say).

The box is too big though and the expansions don't add anything (they make the game worse).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Excellent. Broad horizon of options built on a simple, really elegant system. Deeply interactive, victory must be pursued round by round, optimizing your long period resources (caballeros for area control and power cards for turn order selection) with the tactical dilemmas offered by the shared action cards. Due to the random extraction of the action cards, every round can bring unexpected twists to the game, but nothing can beat a good tactical (and strategic, to some extent) play. Furthermore, I was surprised by its accessibility: I've had the opportunity to play El Grande with some non-gamers and they really appreciated the game, since their first play. 
Shake and serve to 3 people or more (with 2 the game can be dry, not nearly as good as in 4 or 5).

Hans im Glück (German) version. Neat and solid euro components. Minor complaints: the score track on the board is without numbers (only in the HiG version, as far as I know), the iconography on the cards is a bit less intuitive than I expected: it will usually take more than one game to completely forget about the text, be it right on the cards or on a handy translation. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
The beauty of this game is that the rules and mechanics are fairly simple.  Its the cards that make your brain burn nearly every turn - this means that those who want to think deeply can (and will probably blow the opposition away) and those who want light can just pick a card on a fairly ill-considered basis and still know what is going on in the game.  Some of the cards are great in that they cause the complexion of the board to change completely.

Upped rating from 8 to 9.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
I'm not a big fan of area majority games but this is the best of them. Far too tactical and not enough strategy for me to rate it any higher but I still enjoy it
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
The "Granddaddy of Euro cube pushers." I adore area control/influence games, and I find that the subtle strategy in the game is a nice touch. Not hard to learn (I teach it in about 5 minutes), but the strategy takes a couple games to completely unfold. Another plus to me; you play against other players. I understand the criticism that the cards make it random to some degree, but there are ways to mitigate that through use of expansions.

Lots of folks (read; most in my experience) play this at 4 and 5p. I get that, the turn order allocation and board are interesting with lots of people. You can manipulate folks into doing your dirty work, etc. 2p though shouldn't be sneezed at (not my fav player count, but very playable). The differences are that 2p requires much more fanatical attention to the board than turn order. Where as in 4 or 5p, you can't be everywhere, let alone defend everywhere, at 2p, you basically have a shot at just about anywhere and I've found I can win various districts with just 1 dude. K&I cards help 2p.

Decently-simple area-control game. The Spain setting is fun. The game plays smoothly and there is very little downtime.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
The definitive area control game.

It's all about getting majorities in Spanish provinces, or at least scoring some second-place points where you can.  Some great original ideas here, including the use of power cards to determine play order, face up action cards to execute your actions (OK so that's not too original), and the secret disc/Castillo used to plan for sneak attacks.

There's a tradeoff with every decision- play too high a power card, and you don't get to import many caballeros (cubes), plus you're likely to have to play your power card last next round, select a powerful action card, and you don't get to place many caballeros, put too many caballeros into the Castillo, and it's overkill.

Plays 2-5, but I find it to be better with 4-5.  Long-range strategy can be difficult, as this game is very tactical, but it is definitely a strategic game.  One of the best Euro games ever, and a must for any gamer.

Own the El Grande expansions.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
A game from the golden age of Euros.  El Grande is a multi-player conflict game where you can't kill your opponents' dudes.  At best you can outnumber them at the right time.  Yet they persists, those voiceless masses, not so patiently waiting for their day in the sun.

The Castillo is a lot of fun, trying to remember what's in there while competing for position on the board.

An almost perfect game with great pacing.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Smooth-playing, tense, and exciting, with just the right amount of randomness as well as several clever game mechanics. This isn't a game where you build a strong position from the start; you have to be willing to drop your previous plans and think up a new one at a moment's notice. Not to say that there isn't some level of strategic planning, but you have to be willing to squeeze the most out of every turn to really get the most out of this game. There's a lot to like here; El Grande is a deserved classic of boardgaming, though I imagine it's probably a bit dry for some people.

RATING: 10
2007/XX/XX: I'm not a big fan of this game but will play if someone lays it on the table.

Edit 2010/5/13: Played again after many years and I had to raise the rating from 6 -> 8. Maybe I wasn't ready for El Grande when I first tried it a few years ago. This must mean that I've grown as a boardgamer. Especially I've grown into area control games.

2013/01
8->9
Just great. El Grande has developed into a solid favourite of mine and I'm always in a mood for playing it. This clearly satisfies the criteria for a 9

2016/04
9->10
It is really astonishing how a game I initially perceived as dry has revealed so much depth and flavour over the years. Every single decision feels infinitely important and there are no dead moments in the game. Upon almost every move you have to choose whether you want to capitalise the potential immediately or build up your position for later rounds, and all actions have an impact on your opponents. Thus, the playing time of approx. 90 minutes with 4-5 players is packed full of excitement.

However, it is easy to see why El Grande is not to everyone's tastes. The game is very confrontational with a lot of in-your-face moments. It is also rather chaotic since you have very little control over other players. Thus it is crucial to tolerate a constant feel of insecurity and uncertainty. But this is not to say that the game is random. Actually it is far from it.

I must admit that at today's standards the game does not look very appealing and mechanically it is very simple. But even with this simple set of rules you find yourself agonising over your decisions. Not because the decision tree would be too big but for the trade-offs you have to take.

If there is something to really criticise about El Grande it would be the fact that the game plays well only with 4-5 players the optimum being 5. With fewer players you usually end up in a situation where the game is decided at the very moment when two players start fighting. In this case the third player usually claims the prize. Moreover, in really tight games you can have king making situations. Personally I have come to tolerate this and don't feel sorry for losing if it was due to a kingmaker because I know I played well.

In a nutshell, El Grande should be used as an example of a reasonably fast playing game in which every move is significant.

RATING: 9
I think this is going to be one of my favourites as I play it more and more.  I was very impressed with its depth and elegance.  There are lots of things to think about and the mechanics are well integrated.  

It reminded me of San Marco in many respects - the area control and mess-up-you-neighbour mechanisms are similar and some of the cards do the same sorts of things.
Having said that, San Marco is a much quicker game with less, though still significant depth, but possibly slightly more elegance (it's simpler and works with less big shifts).

Which is preferable may come down to the number of players available at the time.

RATING: 8
Area influence game in medieval Spain. Get your nobles into the various regions and score points on a descending scale based on what your total nobles compared to your rivals is. Cards determine order of play and what actions you can take. A game where experience of the action cards would appear to be a necessity. Enjoyable and I suspect a game I will need to play a lot more to actually be able to compete.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
El Grande is a great area control game that's easy to learn, but takes a few games to figure out the relationship between the auction, the action cards, and the overall gaming strategy. 

I love the auction system, which uses numbered bid cards (1-13) that also determine how many cabelleros you can move into court (the lower the bid, the higher the number of pieces). Since you have to move the cabelleros from the provinces to the court before you use them on the game board, you need to make sure that you have an adequate supply. 

At the same time, you also have figure out how you want to bid for the action cards. You have a choice among 5 action cards, 4 of which are replaced with new cards each round. And each action card determines how many cabelleros you can move onto the board.

So, there are multiple factors that you need to think about for each auction - (1) the action card and the number of pieces you can move onto the board, (2) the bid cards that also determines how many pieces you can move into your supply, and (3) what your overall goal is for the round and how it could affect other rounds.

You also need to consider the scoring, which happens after the 3, 6, and 9 rounds. I like this because it gives everyone a heads-up on who's in the lead and allows you to re-evaluate your own strategy. 

El Grande expansions: http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/60589

Tracked on family game list (grooven).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Juegazo de mayorías con mayúsculas. Crea gran tensión, muchas posibildiades tácticas y lo mejor, las vueltas que da la partida, nadie sabe a ciencia cierta quien va ganando. A medida que ha pasado el tiempo, sigue estando de entre msi favoritos, y sigue viendo mesa con relativa facilidad.

RATING: 9
El Grande was my introduction into gaming. I've played far more games of this than my play count suggests because I've only recently started logging my plays. Currently it is my highest rated game, not only because of the nostalgic place in my heart it holds, but also because of the intensely interactive and strategic game play it offers.

Each game feels fresh, new, and tense. I feel invested in the outcome of this game and that's always a good sign. Every time I play it I remember why I love it so much. Truly a great game.

RATING: 8
This was an interesting change of pace for my group. Normally we prefer resource gathering efficiency engine building titles like Puerto Rico, Race for the Galaxy or Agricola, but I dropped El Grande on them last night and we all had a pleasant experience. 

I prefer Shogun's added depth, and - though it in some ways 'makes' the game - the frequent special scoring actions bogged down the play for me. However, this criticism speaks more to my expectation of it offering a faster table dynamic than any inherent issue with the game. For what it is, El Grande is very subtle and elegant. It's one of those games that evokes a sense of depth one can't really fathom till they get into the experience. 

Perhaps my score will go up on future plays, but due to the pace and restricted player counts I have my doubts. 

(ps: It was definitely worth the $40 I paid for the  Rio Grande edition through boards and bits - I'd have been annoyed to pay $60+ retail for it though).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
4-5(5)

I thought this was an excellent game. A classic. The king nicely limits your placement options (and also adds a crucial element of trying to locate the king and then, of course, trying to snag some of those nicer action cards. Also a nice ebb and flow of units from the provinces to the courts to the board and then back again.

I realize now we played the turn order mechanism wrong (we passed the first bid to the left), which may well have changed much of the game (I cannot ascertain). Certainly a tangible "bash the leader" element.

Others have said that El Grande is obsoleted by newer titles (Chaos in the Old World and Dominant Species being two that get mentioned). CitOW is enjoyable enough, it's got really cool variable powers and win conditions and an interesting game arc, but the rules are a bear to follow and explain, along with randomness in the combat (which is key to Khorne's win condition).

I enjoy Dominant Species a lot, but the obvious thing is its length. I like the variable powers here too (much more subtle than in CitOW), but it's a bit different from El Grande, with the growing and changing landscape, as exploration occurs and resources enter and leave and tundra expands and populations migrate. El Grande is just so much more ... [i]Euro[/i] ... cleaner and a purer distillation of the area control.

[5]3-5
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.25
Competitive area control game that blends a bidding mechanic for getting cards with the cutthroat nastier of area control games. 

Complexity - moderately high. You will understand the game after a few rounds but at first it may be confusing.

Strategy - high, a skilled player will be more successful but it is a war game and ganging up will make things drastically harder.

Luck - low, cards are drawn randomly from a pile and bidding is used every turn to aquire the cards but turn order is clockwise based off lowest bidder from the previous round. So seating position can be a factor.

Interaction - extreme, everything you do to help you is hindering others. You either get points for most influence or give it to others. There is no sharing.

Fun - more of a serious competitive game that can cause frustration with conflicts in regions.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Colorblind Issues

RATING: 4

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Overall a good game that i would be willing to play again.
The good
- Replayability.
- Implements the basic concept well.
- I like the simple but concise graphic design.
- Few short and clear rules. Always a plus!

The bad
- Kingmaking. The choice of the player who is last on the score, whether to use the action on the action card or not might potentially decide the winner. Not good. 
- Randomness might ruin attempted strategies before they take effect and without warning.
- Attacking other players' assets is not a viable long term strategy. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
A fun, challenging game.  A real "gamers' game" that demands a lot of concentration...if you plan to win.  I think this game is properly considered the granddaddy of many subsequent euro's (including Hansa Teutonica).  It utilizes so many mechanisms that other games subsequently incorporated.  I particularly love the way the turn order is determined in this game.  Way way back (was it 1995?), this was the first game to introduce me to the concept of structuring a game such that one element of the game would involve players competing to advantageously determine turn order.

RATING: 8
A tentative 8 with more plays required for a firm review. A simple game to teach as well as a deep and strategic challenge, which is a rare combination. An ever rarer bird since it's also a classic eurogame with a high degree of interaction. 

I wish this game were easier to find a copy of; I feel it would be rated higher if it were. 

Side note: El Grande is clearly the inspiration for newer card-driven area control games like Blood Rage, but it seems that the newer games haven't improved upon the classic. If anything, it shows that extra bells and whistles do not make for a better game (and also shows that fancy models and hype have an undue influence in the BGG top 100...)

RATING: 8

The mechanics are very smooth, the card powers are pretty well balanced, and the strategy is pretty complex.  You really need to see the board as a whole when going for regions, rather than just focusing in one place.  It's not a game I would want to play often, nor is it one I think I could get many of my friends to enjoy, but it is definitely a good one.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
Having been so long since I first played El Grande, I was intrigued if my negative sentiment about the game would remain. But, like most area-control games, I ultimately found the experience lackluster. Which made me wonder... why? After all, there are a handful of area-control games that I do enjoy. And there are many games, which have an area control element, that I absolutely love (and I don't consider the area-control element a weakness). 

As I wrestled with this question... I believe it comes down to one thing. That is, area-control games often break down into bash-the-leader exercises where the game-state continuously reverts back. In other words, the puzzle, for which the game is, doesn't change in a significant/meaningful way. It's generic... samey... and ultimately boring. 

Granted, this isn't the only reason I dislike El Grande. For instance, the blind-selection for scoring is a mechanic I'll never enjoy. But when I'm playing a game, I'm looking for an interesting puzzle. And when I'm playing El Grande, I'm struck with a feeling of deja vu; the round marker has moved, the VP are different, but the puzzle feels the same.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
WOW! Where has this game been all of my life? This game strikes a good balance is so many different ways. The theme strikes me as quite right for a game of this type: present enough to give you enough metaphors to understand the play, but it stand back and allows to players to go play the game and make their own stories. The rules are simple to teach and to play, but again it gives the players enough room to understand and calculate their moves in a reasonable amount of time. There's a lot of interaction, and much of it 'mean' (and often memorable), yet I never felt it was too heavy-handed. I like the purity of the game play, with many of it's successors have combined the area-majority scoring with something else (e.g. Belfort = area-majority + worker-placement!, etc.).

Sad to see this out-of-print; hopefully it will see the light of day again, and I'll be first in line to get the first copy.

RATING: 9
Bár a Jubileumi van meg, itt hagyom a véleményemet ennél a kiadásnál, mert amikor írtam még nem volt fenn többféle verzió... egyébként meg kezd tele lenni a tököm vele, hogy lassan minden kiadást külön feltesznek a BGG-re.
---
Nagyon megelőzi a korát... Kifejezetten jó, szeretnék játszani még vele!! Nekem úgy ajánlották, hogy ez az a játék, ahol meg lehet fordítani a vesztett partit is. És tényleg, nagyon váratlan fordulatok is lehetnek, ennek ellenére elviselhető a szerencse szerepe szerintem.
A szabály meglepően egyszerű és rövid (külön dícséret: nagyon kevés szabály van ilyen egzaktul és tömören leírva, kb. 20 perc, minden elsőre világos), mégis elég mély a játék. Néhány kis apróság biztosítja az árnyalatokat, és adja a nehézséget: a király, a kastély, a mozgatható pontozók, és a Grandék... A titkos választási korong pedig a játék jelképe is lehetne.
Egyik játékostársam kritikai észrevétele: a pontozásban megjelenhetne, hogy kinek milyen erőkártyája maradt meg. Ha Knizia készítette volna, tuti számítana ez is:)

Azért csak ~9 pontot adok a játékra, hogy legyen ürügy még játszani, hátha lesz még jobb is:) Amúgy is szeretném kipróbálni 4-5 fővel, állítólag öten a legjobb.
---
4-en is kipróbáltuk, így jobbnak tűnt, mint 3-an.
---
Mindhárom kieg nagyon jó, akinek megvan feltétlen próbálja ki!!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Wow, this game has been around for 18 years before hitting the table at my gaming night!
How did I miss such a great design for all this time?

This is the archetype of area majority games, with simple and straightforward rules, but with so much interaction and cut-throatness that it doesn't seem a german game! It is probably my favorite of the games of the 90s!

I can feel its greatness with the full compliment of 5 players, and I guess it loses something with less (I can't see it hitting the table with less than 4)... but it is indeed a great design, and I can't wait to play it again!

Update december 20th, 2012: this is definitely one of the best 5-player game around, vote raised to 9.

RATING: 9
Keeper.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
El Grande is subject to kingmaking, which normally turns me off, but for some reason I accept it in this game.  I prefer it with 4+ players. Although the base game is favored by most, I prefer variety.

The main downside to El Grande is that players are at the mercy of the current round of action cards.   Although players can anticipate future actions, any attempt at a longterm plan is hazy... especially since 2 unknown action cards from each stack will not be used.   


[b]Intrigue & the King[/b]
I enjoy the customizable aspect of choosing your own action cards.  I also like that you don't have to read 4 stacks of action cards at the beginning of each round.  Currently, I highly prefer the Intrigue & the King cards to the base game. 


[b]Grand Inquisitor[/b] 
My recommendation is to use every new feature.  The Colonies (France, America, & the Mediterranean) add new, unique scoring opportunities that are safe from the secret disc selection of the Castillo!  The Grand Inquisitor, his little henchmen, and the Limit Table are not to be underestimated.  The biggest impact on the game however, is the Ship.  It allows a player to place Caballeros on any coastal region!  
  

[b]Grandissimo[/b]
I recommend setting aside 8 of the stack six action cards, so that some of the more unbalanced cards are removed.  The Ship, Jail, Queen, Jester, and Portugal improve upon the base game... so long as you remove a few of the stack 6 cards.


I have created an expansion variant:
http://boardgamegeek.com/thread/303862
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This is a tricky and fun territorial game. Each territory is worth different points and usually worth points to more then 1 single player. The player with most units in an area will be awarded the most points and the player with 2nd most 2nd most points and so on. The game consists of 9 rounds of which 3 are rounds who after they are finished you will be awarded points for all the areas on the board in which you have units. The goal is to in the end have been awarded most points through all 9 rounds and end up the victor with the largest grand total.

Ofcourse the game includes twists such as actioncards that can award extra points or award points before one of the 3 "award rounds" take place. To make things even more interesting there is a giant castle in which you can place units instead of in an area on the board. these units are kept blind until one of the "award rounds" come into action. (Round 3,6,9 are the award rounds). When this happens it will first secretly be determined in which area the player of the hidden units wish them to go on the board to shift the balance in that particular area before points from areas are determined. This can give an hidden advantage but units placed this way can only tip the scales of one single area where other players might have spread their units across the board and if lucky can be awarded most or 2nd most points in more areas then 1.

This proved great with 4 players and we only played the basic version of the game. It is a strategic, knaving aswell as a diplomatic game. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
[url=http://ballearicus.blogspot.com/2008/05/el-grande-y-reef-encounter.html]El grande[/url] es un juego familiar de mayorías (o control de áreas) sencillo, fácil de jugar y de aprender. El tema realmente es lo de menos, ya que la sensación que tuve mientras lo jugaba era de estar moviendo cubitos de un sitio a otro. Lo jugamos 4 jugadores y no tuvimos ningún problema para hacernos con el desde el principio. El juego transmite tensión y grandes dosis de confrontación directa ya que las cartas pueden alterar la puntuación y mover los cubitos del contrario. La incertidumbre de la torre me parece un gran acierto.

Rápido y ágil de duración moderada, se jugó en hora y media en nuestra primera partida, creo que se puede acortar bastante en las venideras.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This game is brilliant. Every turn you are confronted with mulitple tough decisions. Do you get pieces into your courts? or choose what action to use? Do you choose for the action? or the number of pieces you get to place. Where do you put them? Do you advance your position? or hinder your opponents? These sort of decision are the bread and butter of this brilliant area-control game.

However, I don't see how the game is even nearly as good with less than 5 people as it takes away so much of the 'least of many evils' feel to each decision.

See my [url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/article/1926242]review[/url] for my full thoughts.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.9
Superb tactical area control game. One of the best in it's kind and definitely a classic. Managing the cubes combined with bidding for turn order is a brilliant mechanic that will let you face a difficult decision every turn. The order in which the different actions come up makes for a different game everytime. 

Gameplay: :star::star::star::star::halfstar:
Replayability: :star::star::star::star::halfstar:
Fun/Social: :star::star::star::star::halfstar:
Components: :star::star::star::star::nostar:
Rules: :star::star::star::star::halfstar:

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Must remember to put cubes in the Castillo. Must learn strategies for bidding.

I don't think the quality of the reprint is as bad as peple say. The card quality seemed crappy, but the box and board have a nice linen finish. I like the large turn example sheet.

Next Strategy to try: "Playing cards with a alternating value of middle-low-high, middle-low-high, middle-low-high is often a good idea, because it allows you to (hopefully) control the placement of the King before each scoring round (or, once, at the very least)."

Summary
Randomly determine starting province for grandes. randomly determine player to bid first. Player chooses card between 1-13. Card also determines how many troops will be pulled from the provinces to the courts. Bids chosen going clockwise. Highest bidder get first choice of special action/1-5 troop placement. Player may place in province next to King (but not in King province) or in Castillo. Score majorities after round 3, 6 & 9.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.75
A classic that employs auction and area control mechanics. It is tight, tense, brutal and chaotic, but there is an elegance and brilliance that shines through. There are some games that have come out later that employ similar mechanics (Dominant Species and Chaos in the Old World come to mind), but this classic still retains a charm that is irreplaceable. 

Yes, there is chaos and a bash the leader element, but it is all kept in control and it fits well with the gameplay. It probably shines the best with a full complement of five players.

With it's excellent and polished gameplay, El Grande is worthy of it's high accolades here on the Geek.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

It does suffer from a bash the leader effect, and king making at the end of the game can happen.  For these reasons the score is not higher.

I got this game after owning settlers and carc, I would recommend it to people in a similar situation. At that time it blew my mind!

Also has some issues with with the player count, which is why Inis is my go to area control game for now, although the core game of this one probably is better. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Although it doesn't play like Risk, I find that it can be a good transition game for Risk fans.  It looks similar and is about area control.  There are many tough decisions in this game.  It is a Euro game with a fair amount of "take that!"  Because of the "take that," I don't get to play this with my familyish group as much as I'd like.

After 1 and a half years, I played this again and it did not disappoint.  All the ebb and flow of scoring you'd expect with some exciting twists, especially at the finish.  Final scores in the 4 player game were close with 1st and 2nd separated by 1 point and a tie for third just 5 points or so behind.  Fantastic!

Another play and I find this game is only getting better after eight plays.  It's one of the best.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Mike's Game
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
What can be said that hasn't been said?  Every serious gaming collection should have a copy of this game.  The quintessential area majority game, El Grande packs a lot of punch with a simple rules framework, making it quite suitable for semi-gamers despite the dry theme.

I can definitely see where some may not like the leader-bashing; El Grande is almost like a Euro-ized Risk where instead of rolling dice to kill of your opponents you merely score for having more units than them.  The game is about on the edge of what I find acceptable.  There are definitely games where an early leader gets absolutely crushed and it can make for a demoralizing, unfun experience.  It's also slightly too long and the game can drag.

That said, this is probably my favorite negotiation game and that's mostly because it is NOT explicitly a negotiation game.  The tension and downfall of your opponents after a particularly nasty castillo maneuver is why I play games.  Still one of the best games ever despite its flaws.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
A light wargame involving territory control.  The fact that you can move the king or caballeros _ANYWHERE_ on the board with the cards that provide those actions is a huge deal.  I tend to agree with a buddy of mine who thinks that the card that lets you move the king and place 5 caballero (the card that stays out for each round) is probably too powerful.  Being able to shoot and run is the issue (i.e. place caballeros to take over a region, and then move the king to the opposite side of the board, leaving opponents no chance to fight back).  With all of the praise that this game gets, this card and the movement rules probably work just fine and are balanced with experienced players... but it doesn't change the fact that I don't like chaos caused by the "wide open" movement rules.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
We played it wrong the first time. I still had a blast and need to give it another go to see how I feel about it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A classic! This is the definitive area control game and I've finally managed to play it. 

El Grande is a really good game and the concepts are simple. The bidding mechanism balances turn order against the number of cubes you can make available for potentially placing on the board. There's a seperate card choice bit that determines how many of these cubes actually get placed, which is neat. The cards have another use too, there will be a more "random" effect that each card can cause. Do you pick the one you really want or pick another to prevent someone else using it to damage you. This is another clever aspect of the game.

I also like the fact that you have a range of cards to use in bidding and no player can use the same number as someone else.

All the mechanics tend to have balace as a plus somewhere is balanced by a minus somewhere else. The luck of the draw in the order in which the cards turn up (or which ones you don't see) is the only really random part of the game.

I hope I get to play this again soon.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
5, 4
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A little too much AP for my tastes, and I'm just bad at area majority...  I think it will grow on me.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A great game that I'm always up for, if using the basic rules.

However, I've tried it using expansions, and I'm much less fond of them.

The expansion with the player-designed decks I'm totally uninterested in playing - I would prefer to go read a book, or something. No appeal at all.

The expansion which increases the map, adding new territories is better. It doesn't detract from the game, but I'd rather not use it, as it doesn't seem to add much, either.

So, in summary, I love El Grande, and think the expansions are a big mistake.

RATING: 6
Decent area-control game. I really liked how streamlined the game is: there aren't a bunch of set up and cleanup steps after each round, and it's certainly not a point-salad. All good things. However overall the game felt bland, from presentation and components, to theme, to the kinds of choices and their impacts that come each round. There just didn't seem to be "juicy choices". Granted, this was a first play, but I wonder if game design has just advanced enough in the last 20 years that except for a few true classics, games from this era just don't hold up as well.

(February 2012) El Grande was one of my first favorites, but has been replaced by Dominant Species as my favorite area control game. Nowadays I mostly use El Grande as a gateway game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I love this game for its mechanisms AND for its presentation, dammit! I'm someone who actually does enjoy the theme, and as a carcassonne fan I love the board. I do even like the cubes... and who couldn't love that black imposing castillo? The game is fast, full of tension and great decisions, and though it always seems to be a heavier game than I remembered when I'm teaching it to new folks, by the time we score for the first time everyone is vetoing, and groaning at action choices, counting their court of cabillero's and staring at the Castillo trying to remember just how many red cubes are in there. Excellent, though yes, not overly pretty and full of shiny bits, but as someone who has grown to love area control, this game is a gem. I lament that this game is just dry enough that my group usually isn't interested, though I still need to try a 5 player game, as I hear those can be sublime.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

The Decenniel edition is of low quality. The board is ugly and lacking any Spanish flavour.

RATING: 6.5
Good game, with lots of very tense moments, from the mad rush to pick the action cards, to the anxious experience of watching what other players do with them, to the uncertainty one feels when finally revealing the Castillo... all of which makes for an excellent game.

However: the "take-that" feel of the cards, and the push-and-pull nature of the gameplay, not to mention the game's sometimes wildly unpredictable upheavals, combine to make this not great for our gaming group (especially as area control is not our favorite mechanic). If I want to play a game similar to this, I'd pick something a little shorter and less chaotic, like [thing=29937][/thing] or [thing=165986][/thing].

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
[09/06/05 and 31/12/07]Together with In the Shadow of the Emperor my favourite eurogame. 

However, I would not want to play the game without the König & Intrigant expansion. Even with newbies, playing with that expansion is IMO preferable. In that case, just take the same five cards out of each player's deck. Simple. 

Großinquisitor & Kolonien is a great addition I heartily recommend to those who've at least once played the basic game.

Whereas G&K adds more, the König & Intrigant expansion streamlines the game, increases player control and correspondingly dramatically reduces the luck factor.

K&I resembles the "advanced game" of Torres in that it gives you a full hand of possible actions to pick - rather than picking them on the go. Not surprising to see the same principle at work considering both are Kramer designs. 

Once having played El Grande with the K&I expansion, there's really no looking back to the basic game. Mandatory expansion, IMO.

If El Grande is to your liking, I recommend checking out Im Schatten des Kaisers for a yet more strategic offering.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
A seminal game design which sets the stage for Eurogame design every year following.  This game is the first and best implementation of area control, bidding for turn order, and card drafting of variable turn options.  The game flows through ever changing temporary alliances and possible back stabbing.  "We are partners in this province but, I will turn against you in that province."An important boardgame and worthy of play by every board gamer.And, by the way, it's great fun.

Not to say it isn't fun, or isn't a classic.  It's just not going to be chosen by me over other area majority/control games like San Marco or In the Shadow of the Emperor.

RATING: 9
The classic old-school German game: Very abstracted, but with clean rules and intuitive gameplay that belie its depth. Never has pushing cubes around a board been so much fun. From other comments, I thought this would have much more luck/chaos than it does. Awesome with 5, probably close to a 10. I think it works fine with 3 or 4, maybe rated 8 with 4 and a 7 with 3. The only problem is that it can be tough to catch up, but that's never been something that's bothered me in games.

I have played a lot of area control games over the years, and I always end the game questioning why we just don't play El Grande instead. Never surpassed.

RATING: 6
Still not a favorite of mine. Most of the action cards involve a pretty harsh way to "screw your neighbor". There is too much nastiness in this game for my taste. Also, on the 1st & 2nd turn, some of the cards may cause major damage to a player who is not even out of the starting blocks, nor able to do anything to prevent it. Though, some threads contend that against 4 veteran players, a player who gains 25 VP will still lose, if the other four focus on harshing the leader. And then the one of the four wins, who rises most from the muck. So, what's the point of any VP on the first couple turns?

Admittedly, I'm a hypocrit because my favorite games, Titan & Power Grid, arguable have these same characteristics, so there you go.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
El Grande is one of the best area majority games if not THE best! Such an old game, yet I don't think it shows its age at all. 

To me, this game has awesome mechanics throughout the entire game. The betting mechanic for the cards is great; if you bid low, you get more caballeros in your court to place now or later, but you also end up with one of the worst cards which will have a small impact. You are going to start the next round so you can play a 13 if you really want to get a card. 
On the other hand, if you make a high bid, you will get the card you want but will need caballeros in your court from previous rounds. You will go last in the next round, which balances it, but it's actually not that bad to be the last one as you can see what the others have played and play a card in between the other numbers.
So, even though the highest cards are best, you need to play some low cards too in order to get caballeros to place, and it's delightful to plan when to use which card!

The Castillo is a pretty good idea as it introduces a little bit of randomness and can spoil other players' plans. 
The movement of the king and his impact on the entire game is great too!

It is simply a must-have board game in my opinion and it plays very well with 3 players, great with 4 players and fantastic with 5 players. 
This game is a masterpiece and my favorite area majority game by far! I always want to play it and I suspect this will never change!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Easy to learn (from sample game card supplied) or to teach. Quality components. I'd bought other euros before this one but El Grande bowled me over with its clever and original mechanics and beautiful board.

A pity it's now only available in "Big Box" format with six unwanted expansions and an £80 price tag! What a rip-off! I much prefer the earlier edition as I only want to play the base game and I usually play brown and that colour has been replaced by pink in the new edition.

RATING: 8.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
The basic rules system is simple:  bid on the right to choose a card, move men into your court, then follow the instructions on the card and move men onto the board (in either order.)  Every three rounds, there's a scoring round with scores determined by area majority.  The complexity comes from figuring out which card can do the most for you, and they're all different.  I find the game interesting in principle, but for some reason our games always get out of control, they bog down in the middle, people get distracted.  Seems like it should move briskly in principle but it never does.  Also, a big gang-up-on-the-leader element.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Probably my favorite game right now, unfortunately it doesn't hit the table that often becuase it really needs 5 players (IMO...although I haven't tried 4, it just doesn't seem like it would work nearly as well).  This is one of those games that I knew I would like it as soon as I read the rules (unlike many Knizia games).  Just enough chaos to keep it from being overly analyzed, but planning is rewarded.  Also, you are never out of it, as a couple of scoring cards in your favor can make up a lot of ground in a hurry.

RATING: 10
I usually do not do well in area control games, and maybe for that reason I enjoy very few of them.  But for some reason I just "get" El Grande when I play it.  How something can be so open-ended and yet stay so balanced with a full group of 5 players is an absolute mystery to me.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
El Grande is the venerable classic of area control that still laughs at its more recent pretenders to the throne. This is euro gaming at its finest, with plenty of tough decision making, unique and interesting mechanics, and direct messing with other players.

The game would be pretty boring if it wasn't for the various decks of cards that provide just enough shakeup factor to mix up the board without having things devolve into randonmess. Every turn, you get to jockey for turn order and decide how important that display of cards is for your current and future round. 

If you have five players, this game is ideal. It's a game I always enjoy playing, and I can't ever see this game leaving my collection. Wonderful stuff.

Update: after playing the base game 10 times, we finally broke out the King and Intrigue expansion in the decennial edition. Very interesting to see an entirely new implementation of turn order and action options. Good stuff... a legitimate alternate way to play the game, but the group agreed it is probably best with five.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A classic, elegant in its simplicity. Play a card to determine turn order, take one of the 5 actions, and then place some meeples on the board. Every 3 rounds score points and that's it. In my first game I did horrible because I focused on more powerful cards, which meant I could not put out as many meeples as others, and I think that really hurt me when it came to scoring each time. It's so easy to teach so everyone picks it up quickly and with how tight the board is the game is very interactive and vicious moving meeples around to try and improve your scoring and hurting someone else. I wasn't as enamored after my first play, but that is likely based on how poorly I did and definitely want to play it again because it is so easy to pick up.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I have only played once and it was a very enjoyable game. The game is pretty easy to get into, but is very deep. Almost too deep. It is difficult to keep track of all the things needed to score and if you get behind it is too hard to come back. There is no forgiveness in this game.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
(7-8-10 First impression) As a general matter, I’m not a huge fan of hidden but trackable information, so the cards and the castillo are not my favorite mechanisms. Nor do I typically enjoy simultaneous action selection, so the wheels for castillo placement (and other uses) aren’t a hit. While these mechanisms detract from the game as a serious game, they enhance the fun factor. But if the game is supposed to be fun, then it seems the min-max calculations for influence placement and the asymmetrical value calculation of the actions are a bit out of place. I’m not sure yet whether I like the hybrid of fun and heavy. I’ll have to see on further plays, but the heavy seems to undo the fun and the fun seems to undo the heavy.

I AM fine with the randomness of the available actions. Their asymmetrical values add a lot of interest to turn order play. A concern that may come up over time is that the asymmetries can be such that no one wants to throw themselves on a bomb, but everyone should. I suppose this just makes earlier actions more valuable. We’ll see.

The big lesson coming out of my first game was that you’ve got to balance your card play: low cards for future turn order and getting caballeros in your court and high cards to get the actions you need and the influence on the board. Moving the king seems to be a very powerful play, particularly right before scoring since you can assure yourself the extra points as well as play influence to key surrounding provinces. The castillo was much more important than I imagined since the points score AND the influence can go anywhere to score again. Also, making sure you keep you Grande scoring seems to be important.

Is there value in concentrating on a single value type to try to take advantage of the ‘score all the x’ actions? Or perhaps drafting behind in a bunch and letting the other players score them for you with their actions? Hm.

Overall, I felt there was a bit too much chaos swirling about to make this a good heavy game for me. But now that I've had a chance to think about it, I'll approach it a bit more like I do Manila : fun and random game with quite a bit of meat on it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3

Don't get why people go crazy about this game. Boring, boring,boring.

RATING: 3.5
Surprisingly intricate.  More of an experience game than a competitive game due to lack of control, multi-player chaos, lack of look-ahead etc.  Chaotic and almost entirely unpredictable past ~1 turn out.  My rating suffers is primarily due to the fact that I simply don't enjoy the game much (I find the cards too random), and I far too rarely have or get opportunity to play with the more interesting expansions which remove the random factors.

I mostly look at El Grande as Cosmic Encounter wrapped in German clothing.  In truth it is a little better than that, but not much, perhaps enough to scrape El Grande up to a 3.5-4.0 rating versus 2.5 for Cosmic Encounter.

RATING: 8
Had it, traded it away, had it again (plus expansions) and traded it away (again). For me, this game has its highes and lows - sometimes I'll really be in the mood to play it, and sometimes not really. I enjoy how the game minimizes luck and also how it has alot of tactical decisions in deciding 1) which card to play (to determine your turn), 2) determine which action choice to chose, and 3) determine where to place your caballeros. I think the  biggest reason why I keep trying to get and trade away the game is the difficulty (or rather impossibilty) to get 4 - 5 people to play, which is the area in which this game really shines.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
10+ plays - juggling on quicksand - a gaming feast. The 3 player game (with three less phases) can go so fast - finished in something like 40 minutes (or less).Played "Intrigue & the King" (4p) and enjoyed it a lot. Was just over 2 hrs with learning. Lost by one point! Played "Grand Inquisitor & the Colonies" (4p), loved it (though 3hrs + long?), and had my mojo working. I liked some parts of the Grandissimo expansion (3p) although the card set introduced perhaps too many variables... The Grandissimo deck's imaginative set of card powers sometimes required careful cube counting and recounting to determine optimal play, slowing down the pace sometimes. Also I don't see the point of the Jester ability. Consensus of my gaming pals is that the base game is the best. But maybe pickin' and choosin' a few elements from the expansions is a strong option. Based on one play of the various expansions I like the Inquisitor the best, and I think the personal set of power cards/turn order cards is well done. I also like the additional land regions and the pick up/deliver of the Colonies. Probably all of the expansions add to game time, but for me it never dragged.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.7
Solid euro. Lots of abstract. But not as "abstract" as other abstracts....(?)

It's nice to have a game that looks big and imposing and scary (this does!) that you can STILL have a big impact on. Each player can choose to move the king marker which locks off a portion of the board. So it gives the feeling of empowerment to all players, even though some are obviously superior to others. I like that.

It's hard to salvage a losing position in this game, but it is one that involves a lot of guessing and sussing out other players motives which in turn, inspires good table talk and feelings of comradeship between players. I like that too :)

Must play more.

RATING: 9
I really like this game.  But I am afraid my bias towards Spain (I was an exchange student there) may contribute to this more than anything else.  Unfortunately, I can't get my friends fired up about it though they all seem to enjoy it.

I am not a big fan of auction or area control games. But the blend of the two works well for me.  I like the added suspense of trying to screw everyone through the action cards while trying to efficiently balance my moves from the provinces to my court and from my court to the regions.  I also like the added suspense of the Castillo emptying during the scoring round and the "clearly I cannot choose the cup in front of me" reasoning when selecting their destination.

I have the decennial version but haven't gotten into the expansions yet.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
A masterpiece meshing of several tensions. The tension to play a high value card for early action card choice vs the need to play caballeros to your court.  The tension to choose more manipulative actions vs actions that allow you to place more caballeros onto the board.  The tension to place your caballeros into the Castillo vs dispensed throughout the board. 

This game is very engaging throughout, whether its your turn or not. It well deserves its place among the all-time Top 5.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Best. Area Majority Game. Ever.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
This game has stood the test of time quite well. Plenty of neighbour abuse and tactics in this one, and the castillo adds a dash of surprise to each scoring round as well. Must be said that the theme is a 100% paste job, but it doesn't take away from the experience for me. Unlike most people I actually prefer this at the 4 scale instead of 5, with more players I think the game just gets a tad too chaotic, it's still quality at either scale, but 4 is the sweet spot on this one for me. The action cards can get a bit samey with replays, and the game feels a bit basic these days, but it is still the modern progenitor of the AIG school and I have to respect it for that. 

I do have to say that the King & Intrigue expansion has really spoiled me at this point though, and the original game doesn't have as much appeal. The problem for me is that K&I can only be played with 5, and I rarely have a group of 5 experienced players who are interested in it. I actually have ended up getting rid of my copy of Grande for that reason, as the vanilla version, while still better than most of the AIG that have come down the pike, is not the one that I would be pulling off my personal shelf at this point at anything but the 5 scale, and I have a slew of other good options for lower scales which can play fine with 5 as well. 

Playing K&I also makes me more annoyed with the excessively tactical nature of the vanilla Grande action cards. It's gotten to the point now where I've turned down vanilla Grande on a number of occasions because it just doesn't have nearly as much appeal as it used to. I find myself much preferring the more layered AIG that have come out since this such as Liberte, Im Schatten des Kaisers, Struggle of Empires, and so forth. K&I Grande is one of the best in the genre, the basic version? A little pedestrian for my present tastes. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
An amazing game.  Rich with complexity and strategy.  Interesting with great game play - you can work together to fight the leader, but it isn't easy.  There is some randomness, but the effect is shared by all players.  There is a touch of semi-hidden information, but it is something you can plan around.  Every time I play I am won over anew.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
One of the best [u]area control[/u] games: tense, tough decisions, lots of player interaction, huge replay value, low randomness. It's a very tactical game with a minimal downtime, because you must permanently watching and counting and the player turns are quick.
I'm not 'very happy' with the the German cards (I wrote an English translation on the cards) until we learn the iconography on the cards. Also, the English expansion replaces all the German cards.
[i]House rules: we like to play the "Open Castillo" variant (with the Castillo cubes always revealed). Also, the 2-player variant where each person controls 2 colors and adding the two scores together at the end.[/i]
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

It is a little dry and abstract for me now but I loved it when I first got it.

RATING: 8.5
This game is a great mix of strategy and planning with chaos and uncertainty. 5-player is good due to the accommodation of a fifth player and the certainty that someone is going to get stuck with a crappy action card. However, I might enjoy 4-player slightly more since it allows the last player to choose an action card to pick the lesser of two evils and all players have to deal with the uncertainty about which action card will not be selected. I do not think that I would ever play El Grande with fewer then four and have still not used any of the expansions.

RATING: 5.75
Spanish for `The Grande.'
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
El Grande is a sin of my youth. Everyone was raving about it, so I had to get it myself, right? The game is, at its heart, a majority game, and one of the first ones to do this in a big box format. It can be called the granddaddy of majority games, and although many variations have been worked out, they can all trace at least some roots back to this dinosaur. In that regard it was a major step in the evolution of modern game design, so some familiarity with it is almost a necessity if you take this hobby at all serious.

In El Grande, players try to score points for having a numerical majority of cubes in certain areas. The source of those cubes comes from a deck of cards which tie two things together: the amount of cubes you can take out of a public pool and place into your private pool, but also the order in which players can select an action card from a pool. That action card tells the players what they are allowed to do in that round. If you want a shot at being the first player, you must play a high-numbered card will likely not allow you to move many cubes to your private pool; if you don't care then a low card will give you plenty of movement options later. Play three times 3 rounds, interspersed with scoring (which can see some last minute changes on the board), tally the score and determine the victor.

The trouble with this game is that people get their terminology terribly mixed up. Many will call this game 'strategic', but it's nearly all tactics as the action cards change every round (with one exception). The strategy is in managing your pool of cubes, and that is heavily influenced by what you want to achieve in the short term on the board. They also call it 'luckless', which is a big lie too as, once again, the action cards change every round. You can memorise the types of card in each deck so you will get a better idea of what is in there, but you'll always assume that your opponents do this too plus that it is not a given [i]when[/i] the card shows up (if at all). But worst of all, they [i]don't[/i] call this game 'the epitome of multiplayer chaos' (although Maharadja is arguably worse in this respect). Player order is very important because it determines what you can still do on the board. With just 9 rounds of actual play, things need to be efficient. And that's just it: they aren't. You can be easily outclassed by another player, putting your somewhere between place 2 and 5 in the player order. Once it is your turn, you must select a card from what is left, and that might not at all be what caused you to play a high(er) card anyway. In other words, players continuously get in each other's way [i]in unexpected ways[/i], which I find frustrating and annoying. I do not want to play a game where it all comes down to gut feeling and having a few lucky streaks. Because of the nigh impossibility to do any actual steering unless you are lucky enough to have the highest card all the time, people adopt a score-for-the-moment attitude. I don't like this very much.

Phrased another way, the core issue is that I don't feel in control in sufficient amounts for the time I need to think, as well as the game takes to play.  Many majority successors solve this issue quite satisfyingly, either by making the amount of influence to be placed much more a separate fact rahter than something tied in with player order, or by giving each player a more or less guaranteed shot at the actions he can perform. That way, players can select [i]their[/i] amount of influence or actions, and win or lose because of them.

I wish I could rate El Grande higher than the '4' it's getting, but there are other games I'd much rather put in front of multiple players if I feel inclined in a little majority messing. Mykerinos is shorter and intenser; Louis XIV gives rock'n'roll if you want it; San Marco provides zany chaos with its distinctive divide-and-chose mechanism; Liberté is a hoot with 5; King of Siam an intense brain burner; Web of Power is perfect for 3; Aton (as well as a few others) is perfect for 2. None of these games suffer from loss of player control; hence they all rank higher with me. 

After the first few games, I sold off this tile, and have never felt the need to look back upon that decision.

[b]Update[/b] It's always fun to look back on games which you last played several years ago. I played with 3, and like the game better at this number because it's easier to estimate what people will take... But it remains quite a chaotic and ad hoc game; and the fact that a significant amount of players thinks this game best at the high end of the player range tells me that El Grande is simply not my cup of tea. Still, I decided to up the rating a little to account for this effect.

[u]3 PLAYERS[/u]: 5
[u]4 PLAYERS[/u]: 4 (chaos is increasing)
[u]5 PLAYERS[/u]: I'd rather read a book, to be honest.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
Neat euro style board game.  This game is a constant struggle to have the most or second most caballeros in each of the Spanish provinces on the board.  Game mechanics flow well and there is relatively no down time.  This is a good solid game that players nominate for play every now and then even though it is an old game relative to so many newer euro style games.  El Grande plays in 60 - 90 minutes and is fun to play.  El Grande has made my list of top 50 euro style games of all time.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
This is an area majority game in its purest form - have the most caballeros (knights) in a region and score the most points there in one of three scoring rounds.  But it's not so simple - getting your caballeros onto the board and moving them around requires picking the right action cards at the right time.

Timing is determined by playing a "power card" to determine turn order for the round.  Each player selects an available action card and plays it.  Complicating matters is the king - wherever he is, you can't play, but you must enter the board on adjacent provinces.

The very cool twist is the castillo (castle) - there are majority bonuses in this hidden chamber as well.  But before it's scored, players secretly select a region to send their caballeros to after scoring.  That mixes things up when regions are scored!

For a relatively simple game, there's a lot to think about.  Generally I just found it to be fun - something that gets lost in games sometimes.  Definitely looking forward to future plays of this older classic.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
Components: Sturdy components (especially the Castillo). I would prefer that the non-territory spaces (i.e. water, France, and Portugal) were set off from the board proper with a different color, despite breaking from the imitation of an old map.

Experience: Play is interesting, trying to achieve/maintain control in several territories in time to be scored. The actions cards take a bit to get used to, but if players just take a moment to read through what is available for the round, all goes well.

First Played: 2004-03-13
Last Played: 2010-01-27
Eagerness to Play Again: Soon

RATING: 8
Still a favorite, although it may be showing its age. One of the original area majority games. The main fun is in the choice of which card to take each turn and how best to utilize it. Cards change value to different players and at different parts of the game, so one that may be of little value to you may be vital to another. Do you take it to deny it to him? Or take your best play to maximize your own score?  There's lots of room for general nastiness, which I enjoy.

I own the Big Box version.

RATING: 8
After reading the rules and prior to playing, I was less enthused to get this to the table.  To my surprise, when I finally did get to try it, I really enjoyed it.  It's very balanced and yet quite deep.  Lots of ways to affect the other players, but not so much that it's frustrating.

Definitely a game that can be played over and over many times.  The Castillo (castle) mechanic is just brilliant.
This game is one of the top games and well-deserving of it, but it could really use a make-over (board and cards).

I find it equally fun with 4 or 5 players, even though most gamers only want to play it with 5. Still an awesome game with five too.

RATING: 7

I quite like the different mechanics that come into play. 

I got the feeling that the game tends to make you play thinking in the short-term without giving the possibility of building a long term plan.

The fact that each player's round can change the game situation a lot might lead to analysis paralysis because all your strategy might be impacted by what the other players are doing.

I have to play it more!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
2-5

Voorbereiding :

+ Elke speler neemt een draaischijf, kiest een kleur en de bijhorende cabballero’s en machtkaarten.
+ Er wordt een regiokaart getrokken voor iedere speler en voor de koning.
+ De spelers plaatsen hun Grande en 2 cabballero’s in de regio en 1 cabballero op het scorespoor.
+ 7 cabballero’s liggen in het hof, de overige cabballero’s liggen in de provincie.
+ De actiekaarten komen naast het speelbord te liggen.

Speelverloop:

Er zijn 9 rondes. Elke ronde bestaat uit de volgende stappen:

1/ De zwarte rondenteller schuift 1 vakje naar beneden. Aan het einde van de 3e, 6e en 9e ronde vindt er een algemene puntentelling plaats.

2/ De 5 actiekaarten worden omgedraaid.

3/ De spelers spelen hun machtkaarten uit.

In de eerste ronde mag de jongste speler als eerste een machtkaart uitspelen. Vanaf de tweede ronde begint altijd de speler die in de voorgaande ronde als laatste aan de beurt was. De overige spelers volgen in de richting van de klok. Alle uitgespeelde machtkaarten moeten een verschillende waarde hebben. De speler die de hoogste machtkaart heeft gespeeld, begint met het kiezen van een actiekaart. Daarna de speler met de op één na hoogste machtkaart, enz. Afhankelijk van de gespeelde machtkaart verplaatst de speler cabballero’s van zijn provincie naar zijn hof. 

4/ De machtkaart gaat naar de aflegstapel.

5/ De speler neemt één van de openliggende actiekaarten.

6/ De speler voert de actie uit en plaatst het aantal cabballero’s (afhankelijk van de gekozen actiekaart) op het speelbord. Je mag kiezen of je eerst cabballero’s plaatst of eerst de actie uitvoert. Cabballero’s mogen naar believen geplaatst worden in regio’s naast de koningsregio en/of in El Castillo.

7/ De gekozen actiekaart gaat naar de aflegstapel.

Na ronde 3, 6 en 9 volgt een algemene puntentelling:

1. Draaischijf instellen.
2. Telling van El Castillo.
3. Cabballero’s uit El Castillo  in de (op het draaischijf gekozen) regio plaatsen.
4. Telling van alle regio’s.

Waardetabel:

Bij 2 spelers: 1e cijfer
Bij 3 spelers: de 2 eerste cijfers
Bij 4 of 5 spelers: de 3 cijfers

In geval van een gelijke stand in een regio, ontvangen de spelers steeds de punten van de lagere lang. In geval van gelijke stand in de koningsregio krijgt niemand de koningsbonus.

Belangrijke regels:

+ Er worden alleen maar cabballero’s geplaatst in aangrenzende regio’s van de koningsregio (uitzondering: cabballero’s die in het geheim vanuit El Castillo op het speelbord worden geplaatst).
+ Er worden nooit cabballero’s geplaatst in de koningsregio (ook niet vanuit El Castillo).
+ Cabballero’s kunnen vanuit El Castillo slechts in 1 regio worden geplaatst.
+ De meerderheid halen in de koningsregio = +2 bonuspunten.
+ De meerderheid halen in de thuisregio (bij een Grande) = +2 bonspunten.
+ Als je provincie leeg is, mag je cabballero’s van het speelbord halen.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6


=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
El Grande is a classic area control game and it is that element of the game that I feel is the strongest. I do feel, though, that some of the action cards may be imbalanced in the basic game (I know...blasphemy). The King is so powerful; it allows the player to place five caballeros from their court, it potentially keeps other players from adding caballeros to regions where they are needed, and the player controlling the King can score an extra two points from having it in their own region (and other players cannot place caballeros in that region...because the King is there!). Other cards like "score all six and seven regions" are very powerful, as well. Personally, I don't like the need to remember the number of caballeros each player has in the Castillo, but I do like the chaos when the cabelleros are placed into new regions, from the Castillo. Good, solid production value in the Hans im Gluch version. Great decision-making. This game bounces back and forth between a 9 and a 10 for me.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Fairly simple to explain this game, but it has tremendous depth. Also seems to strike an almost perfect balance between keeping everyone in the race, but not too easy to "bash the leader". Good tough decisions too without the tight specifications that can cause analysis paralysis. We always seem to have a lot of friendy table banter when playing this one.

RATING: 6

It is instead lengthy and ridden with downtime. Maybe the speed, enjoyment level, and rating will increase when we're more familiar with the actions.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
El Grande seemed to be another game that was rather interesting. Unfortunately no one I knew seemed to own it, so I went ahead and purchased it. 

I liked and like the game quite a bit. Unfortunately it never caught hold of the people around me. Most of the individuals in my weekend game group of the time though it was less interesting then Shogun (My girlfriend: "Why play El Grande when we could play Shogun instead?") and pushed back against the idea of playing it. At the Wednesday game shop no one really seemed to like it that much. They thought it was fine but nothing special.

As for myself, I thought it was a really solid, really elegant example of the Area Control genre. A basic distillation of the theme without a lot of the bells and whistles added by later area control games. I also learned that why I was hesitant about pure auction games, I did like pure area control games.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
a lot of player interaction and a lot of fun. Faster game. Easy to learn.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
The grand-daddy of majority/scoring games. Over nine turns, players manipulate their control blocks of wood on the board, to try and make them score as many of the regions as possible. Getting them to the board is a three step process, and once on the board they can be moved and removed by events. Lots to think about and certainly rewarding when you win, but boiled down you are never far removed from moving coloured cubes around a board. Several expansions are available.

RATING: 10
Played this for the first time the other day with three. Very much looking forward to playing it again. It's relatively simple area control game, where by a flop of changing cards provide special abilities that enable to board to change in a constantly shifting manner. Turn order is dictated by played power cards that are generic and one use only - your 13 card will let you go first but then you never have that card again, that sort of thing.  Dropping the cubes (I believe they are meeples in the newest edition) into the tower - or castillo if you are into that - is really fun, as is revealing what is in there when the time comes. The tower is perhaps my favourite component in any game. I like the perhaps now dated map. The power cards aren't the prettiest, but like everything in the game are quite functional.

I have only played this with three, I imagine it scales excellently up to the maximum player count.

Playtime was just over an hour, which felt perfect.

Overall, I really enjoyed this game, it would appeal to strategy gamers as there is depth, but not a huge amount of complexity. You could play breezily and have this as  a sort of gateway plus. 

UPDATE: Played again with five, game scaled really well, though plays a little differently as if you go last you have no choice of which card to take.

A provisional 9.

Addendum: a few more plays in, this is not the most fun game in my collection, but it hints at being the best, the most solid, reliable and well behaved. Three, four and five are all wonderful counts.  No rule is fiddly. No component is extraneous. No time is wasted. The aged design of the original game board is weirdly charming. I love that it's set in Spain for a reason I can't articulate. 

https://boardgamegeek.com/geeklist/226605/my-top-25-modest-proposal-2017

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Idea:
Play your units on the map of Spain and fight over control of the regions. One region is the tower where you cant see how many units are in if you dont remember and before scoring each player decides secretly to which area those men go to reinforce.

Mechanism:
Each round there are five different actions that give either more men to get to reserves or stronger action (move men/remove men etc). One action is always same but other four are drawn randomly from respective deck. Amount of men to place from reserves are decided on 1-13 numbered turn orders. The earlier you act (and pick your action) the less you get men from reserves to play. Also numbers are used so once you use 1 or 13 someone can act first/last if they wish. On scoring 'larger' regions give points to multiple players (and more too) thus they tend to be fought over while smaller regions can be controlled with fewer men.

to who:
Really good game for those who like region control games. I also like that there is no combat between men, just over cards which manipulate amount of men.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
The Iberian Peninsula is depicted on a hard mapboard divided into 9 large areas. Impressive at first glance. The rules are easy and straightforward. A game for 2 to 5 players where each player attempts to have majority in each area of Spain and score points. So far so good. The whole mechanics focus around adding cubes to areas trying to have the majority of your color. After a play the game leaves you a dry taste: there is no thrill, no major player interaction, no planning since all strategy is altered by others’ players actions, repetitive – almost boring. After a couple of turns  the players who have been left behind in score results, will most certainly be left in the final place at game end without even the chance or hope to alter their destiny! The player with the most points at game end is the winner; not even the winner feels that he has accomplished something in this game.  The game lacks something for sure; no fun, no interest, no expectation! The theme and concept is intriguing but after actual play one can understand that the map could have portrayed any territory similar to that of a continent or that of a tiny island in the Pacific; The system lacks any incentive for the players,- just adding cubes populating areas and then score. I prefer investing time into games that produce fun, tense moments and excitement!

RATING: 8
Decennial Edition - Included expansions:
[thing=370][/thing] (aka. Intrigue & The King)
[thing=3146][/thing] (aka. Grand Inquisitor & The Colonies)
[thing=597][/thing]

Each time this game is played, it receives relatively warm reviews.  Quite an engaging game.  This is one of the few games that actually obeys its duration: 90 min. for 4 players, 2hrs. for 5-players.  Has become a victim of the 'Cult of the New', however it's played on occasion.  The last time I played was a 2-player game.  What we did was randomly block off 2 regions to reduce the map size so competition would be more prevalent - which worked well.  The game lasted less than 45 min.

I was convinced that the map expansions for adding Portugal & France lend itself to a 6-player variant.  I created player pieces for a 6th player and have tried it!  It works well with 6 players, and adds about a ½ hour to the duration.

2014/02/15
Played this recently & forgot how much I like this game!

RATING: 8
The English title is "The Grande".   Classic area control game whose influence is felt strongly in Mission Red Planet, Rattus, Dominant Species and a host of other games.  Those games might have a thematic edge, but this one might have the edge in terms of simplicity and "pureness" in the design, if it isn't too highbrow and sycophantic to say that.  I do see where leader bashing and some of the chaos in the action cards could be an issue for some, but I don't feel like it is a problem the way it is implemented here.   Seems like a game that just needs to be part of the collection.
