RATING: 9
This game is fantastic. The more players involved, the better it is, but it's still decent with 2 players if you play the variant where each player controls two grandes. There are alot of complaints about the theme, but I'm engaged with every play. My favorite aspect of the game is using the secrecy disks for placing or moving caballeros. Trying to anticipate your opponent's selection is too gripping because of the sometimes devastating consequences of choosing poorly. An excellent game and highly recommended. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I first played this game in 2015 and it never felt like a game from almost 20 years ago.  It’s a very good game that has held up very well, and its easy to see how the mechanics introduced in this game have been replicated and copied into many games since.   

I especially like the option of players collectively hiding cubes in the tower and then having a secret simultaneous reveal to see where they go.  That is the best part of the game.  The part of the game I don’t like are the various special action cards that I feel add too much randomness and make the game a little chaotic.  I feel that if the game was introduced today, they would be standardized into only five customary repeating actions (in much the way as the ‘move the king’ card is) with easy to understand iconography.  As it is, the game seems to stop when they are revealed as everyone seems to freeze while reading them and figuring out what to do next (this slows down the momentum of the game).   

Any game where I have a lack of control over the outcome of my actions and becomes too chaotic makes me loose interest, and that’s how I start to feel halfway through the game.  I rarely saw the same ‘action card’ reveled throughout the entire game.  With nine rounds and four ‘wild’ special action cards reviled during the game (that rarely repeat themselves), that’s about 36 possible chaotic actions that come into play during a five player game.  I feel that if they only had the same five actions (such as the ‘move the scoring marker’ and the ‘veto’ action cards), the game would be a bit more strategic and we could focus several moves in advance.  As it I, the game is just a bit too unpredictable but still a solid area-control game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Great game that has a very tactical feel, though long-term strategy is also important. Plays okay with 2, but shines with 3+
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This is in my top 5 games of all time. El Grande is the prize game for both exp players and new players to Strategy Games.

It is one of the rare games that is almost luck free, focusing solely on placement of the king, your pawns, and the cards you choose. Even the card selection (while semi-random) take thought since you will use ot for power and position. The bidding adds the final piece since you bid to determine turn orderm, but the higher you bid, the less units you get, so every aspect of your turn has both pro and con consequences which I love about this game.

RATING: 7
I love this game, and originally rated it a 10.  Unfortunately, its rather large Kingmaker factor forced me to lower its rating a couple of notches.  When someone falls way behind in El Grande, there's nothing for him to do but hand the game to somebody else.  Players have to work VERY HARD to keep the score balance in El Grande, not only beating up on the leader but generously helping anyone who falls too far behind.  If they don't, that guy way in the back of the pack is forced to be somebody's heel.

Otherwise, El Grande rocks!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I first tried this a few years ago, and have been able to play several times since.  I think it deserves its reputation as one of the first & best area majority games.
You've got some good tension going with the bidding of cards for turn order and piece activation, and lots of interesting choices about where to deploy.  The Castillo and paradropping from it during scoring mean more tense decisions.  The restrictions about placing next to, but not in, the king's region also are a nice touch.  These limitations, as well as the action cards, mean that no majority is ever perfectly safe.  You have to watch out for the other players trying to snipe your majorities during scoring, as well as disrupting your plans by card play.  
All in all, a real classic game.
If I have one complaint, its that the mid-value regions seem oddly more valuable than the high-value ones.  This is because the mid-value ones are less likely to be heavily contested, and because there are cards in the deck that cause those regions to score during the round.  Focusing on them seems to be a winning strategy, from what I've seen.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Great tactical abstract game— maximise your score on a turn and you cant look too far ahead, due to the chaos.  The Castillo makes things even more interesting.  It is a min-maxing points game, and has a bit of analysis-- there are a lot of things to keep track of, such as what other cards will be picked/played this turn, what's in the castillo, what could happen next turn, etc. You spend a lot of time looking at different provinces, seeing what gain you will get in points if you drop cubes there.  In some ways, there are too many options for a multiplayer game, and if you get in the mode of points analysis and optimization (which is easy to fall into), the game is not as good.  The 9-turn game can be too long (in my group).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
briljant
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Wow, I am generally apprehensive about 90s games simply because so many advances have been made since then (although I'm not a snob - some of my favorite games are indeed from that era), but this was nowhere near as dry as I thought it might be.  In fact, if dry is the operative word for sleep-inducing optimization exercises, then the applicable words here are slippery, moist, lubricated gameplay (which is a little fitting given what the king piece looks like... for real, what is the deal with that thing?).

First off, you have a Euro that has all of the traditional trappings of the standard-bearers, but instead of a 5-player solitaire, you get a very engaging and interactive game that doesn't even really involve much cube pushing (while that sounds like an admonishment against all euros, it's more the broad brushstroke of my experiences with more recent 'heavy' ones).  Let's tick off the inventory - VP track around the board? Check. Little wooden cubes everywhere? Check. Multiple scoring rounds that stop normal gameplay? Check. Pointless theme? Check. Weird dudes on the cover? Check-a-roo! Pointlessly-gigantic phallic symbol roaming around the map in a threatening manner? Che... okay, that's not standard, but it's worth a mention.  Seriously... what is the deal with that thing?

So it's not without reason that you can expect a decent brain burner and VP race in the vein of like, anything else out there, but instead there's a few things that set this one apart and make it terrific fun.  It plays fast, for one and it's highly interactive, for two.  Among its more unique features are the Castillo, a tall wooden(?) tower that sits on the board for people to deposit cubes (called caballeros in the game, and while I am aware of its actual meaning, I still can't help but think of Disney's Three Caballeros every time) whose contents are hidden (though declared) and revealed for scoring in later rounds; unless you have a ridiculously good memory, you never quite know how that bit of scoring is going to play out.  Next are the area-selection discs (disks?) that allow for secrecy in a few opportunities that arise in which to place your cubes - thus, this is not a perfect-information game, which I love - and it creates a great little tense moment when you're trying to gamble on someone else's choice.  Then there are the action-selection cards and power cards; while not the first, and most certainly not the last game to feature action-selection and turn-order bidding (with the power cards), what's key here is that the actions available to choose from are almost always going to cause someone else at the table some pain and your choices amount to bid high and get that card to spare yourself, or bid low and risk being a target in order to get more cubes into your supply.  Then, of course, each action card that you choose also determines how many cubes you get to place on the board and the big ol' dildo of a king determines where.

On the surface, it sounds complicated, but the game has this beautifully-elegant flow to it and like I said, it plays fast for what it is.  At no point did I find the game overstayed its welcome and in fact, I found it to be over too soon.  Although the scoring can be a bit swingy, it's all about managing not just what you can do, but also what the other players cannot do.

Amazing game.  Wish I had played it sooner.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
This is one fantastic area control/bidding game with a lot of interesting mechanisms going on, such as your deck of initiative cards for bidding on selection of the various actions in the 5 stacks, the effects of the 5 stacks themselves, and chaotic castillo unit placement.  I also enjoy the King in that nothing can move into or out of his area, the bonus points he provides and that you can only place caballeros in areas adjacent to The King.  My only complaint towards the game is that it can be a bit boring while waiting for people to decide what they're doing, however, this makes the scoring rounds all the more exciting.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
One of those few games where everything comes together to create a fantastic game experience. Area-control at its best. There's strategic planning, where players have to figure out the best way to get their caballeros from the provinces to the court to the regions (and which regions!). There's a psychological element of guessing when it comes to deciding what power cards to play. And there's the action cards, which have very interesting powers to spice up the game and also give the game a stronger theme than you'd think a Eurogame would have. The game is such that a player's strategy must be comprehensive. Neglect one aspect of the game and he will lose the game. Very challenging stuff.

I can foresee myself playing this game for a really long time, and with the expansions, beyond that even. A top effort by Kramer and Ulrich. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.75
An excellent game. Hugely enjoyable and makes for great strategic play. You never feel like you have quite enough caballeros to place, and which action you choose can have an enormous effect on yourself, and on your opponents by denying them important options.

RATING: 6
[3 plays] I really would like to play this more, at least enough to figure out what I really think of it.  I was very favorably impressed by it the first time; I liked the fact that I could play this for the first time and both have fun and be competitive in the game (yet without anywhere near feeling like I had exhausted what it had to offer).  In other words, NOT one of those games where you must totally understand how to play before starting so that you can concoct the grand strategy without which you are doomed.  However, in subsequent plays I felt increasingly at a disadvantage because I was less familiar with the cards.  I think this is one of the many games where it really helps you to know what's in the deck and what the distribution is.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I don't see this game as elegant at all.  Perhaps my definition is different than others, but any game with as many little bits as this can't be elegant.  Power cards, action cards, spinners, two places for pieces, etc.  Not elegant, but incredibly balanced and amazingly rich.

One of the joys of playing this was being able to go back and read rorschah's comments about it and understand what he was talking about.  Just as he says, the beauty of the game is the way that early decisions linger - you're making new moves, but you never quite escape from the early positions you stake.  This makes the beginning and mid game as exciting as the finish.

Even better is that I found the workings to be delightfully transparent.  I won by one point, and I was immediately able to recall a large number of tense moments in the game of which any had gone differently could have knocked me back in the pack.  Good all the way through and fun to think about afterwards.  I love area control, and this is the best I've played.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
A powerhouse of fun. 

My first Euro and perhaps my favourite Euro. A horde of beautiful little coloured wooden blocks makes for a visually attractive game, always a bonus in my experience. El Grande is a very clean game - gameplay is tight and transparent. The castillo mechanic is a superb aspect, delivering some guaranteed moments of suspense three times a game. El Grande is a game devoid of strategy but rich in tactical possibilities every turn. It's the consummate opportunist's dream game. It's not unusual for newcomers to win, as the rules are very easy to understand and experienced players don't receive any strategic-understanding dividend - the game is decided by bidding, card selection and area influence decisions. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
Every single time I play this game I tell myself I need to play it more often.  It is a "take that" game to some extent, a genre I don't tend to enjoy, but there enough constraints placed on player choices that the "take that" aspect doesn't overwhelm the game.  It has exactly the right amount of player interaction for me.

It is a game that requires thoughtful, engaged players in order to shine.  It can be dull if people play flawlessly.

RATING: 9
Based on 4 plays.
+ A good abstract game.
+ For some unknown reason, this game feels a lot better game than Caylus.
- The scoring track seems to be short of numbers, but it isn't. I scored nearly 110 points in my first game and it was unnecessarily difficult to use the scoring track...not to mention my latest game with 128 points.
- The distant (or ridiculous?) theme is not helping to understand the rules.
- New decennial edition has severe printing erros. They have fixed it already, but it was a catastrophy.
- I'm not a big fan of abstract victory point games. I do usually well, though.

Updated 8->9 in 2011 after 4 plays. This is the best area control game -- I don't see how this game could be improved.

Since 2007, updated Dec 2011

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
(2-5 players) This is about as good as boardgaming gets. Great components, lots of levers/choices, interaction, and good, simple mechanics.

Downgraded from 10 to 9:
The few times I've played this game I always try to turtle a bit at the beginning and hope that I can use reserve power at middle and/or end. The game doesn't really allow for that; it rewards "balls to the wall" play from the very beginning and it can be difficult to make up lost ground when everyone else plays that way. For that reason I have dinged it one point. A better game would allow more freedom in play style between players. In this one it is kill or be killed.

RATING: 7
My first play in about a decade. I didn't like El Grande the first time out, and in my mind it seemed very complex. That's probably because I played with the german cards and write ups, so it was difficult for me a s a newcomer. This time, I found it very easy and the decisions for me were simple, my timing was better and I actually squeeked out a win in the end. But it took 3 HOURS!!! Talk about Analysis Paralysis. Go on, talk about analysis paralysis for three hours. I'm much more inclined to play my copy at home now, but this is not a game to play with strangers or new players. I've put it at 7, which may go up or down on the next plays.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This game quickly catapulted itself to the top of my favorite game list, with its easy to learn rules, but seemingly incredible amount of depth and the general atmosphere of deceit and outsmarting one's opponents.  As a relatively basic area control game (with a beautiful map and overall presentation), El Grande encourages constant shifting of plans, and no one way to victory seems overpowered or assured, and those who stick to a similar strategy turn after turn, or even game after game, seem to be easily outmaneuvered or defeated time and time again.  There is a enough tricky and manipulative ways to play to keep the game engaging in a jerk sort of way, without making it mean spirited, so rarely will someone leave the game feeling like they were singled out or unfairly defeated.

As part of the current 10th anniversary edition of the game, it comes with all of the existing El Grande expansions, of which I have only tried Colonies & The Grand Inquisitor (which I throughly enjoyed, and added much to the game's depth without radically altering its mechanics).  Suffice to say, I really enjoy this game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
The first and still the best area majority game I have played, El Grande was my first encounter with Kramer's magical intuitiveness of design. His games have unmatched flow and are case studies for every aspiring game designer. El Grande, in particular, seems to share the DNA of eternal abstract games such as Chess and Go. The retro looks is an acquired taste. I was at first prejudiced against it, but I came to like it. It now brings me atavistic reminiscences of medieval Spain, just like Roland Orzabal's Sketches of Pain (a perfect soundtrack). Scalability is an issue: it is possible to play it one-on-one (I did it, and the game ended in a draw at 60 points!) and it is quite nice with three players; but it should really be played with four or five. In my case, this prevents me from playing it as much as this fantastic game deserves.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

* Played 5+ times. I don't quite understand the immense popularity of this game; I find it scattered and unfocused. Honestly, I still find it chaotic, but enjoying it more regardless. [Can't Stop/? traded for this. Sold.]

RATING: 4
[Area control, Special powers] [5P:5, 4P:4, 3P:3] I understand how others can enjoy it, but it's too dry and tactical for me. You can't plan any further ahead than the current set of action cards (because you'll never know what's coming up). Repetitive and, honestly, boring as dirt. *** UPDATE: Okay, I can expound a little more on EG now that I played again, and still didn't take to it at all. Your work doesn't stick. It's transient. It's chaotic. It's impossible to build anything. You're blind and stone deaf beyond the current turn, and there's nothing you can do now to set up for later success. It's irritating. I can't fault the design, I can see how some gamers like the "live for the moment, score points now" personality of the game, but I can't abide it. Bleh. ***UPDATE: Following a lead from the esteemed Chris Farrell, am considering El Grande + Expansions, which seems to remove my main issue with the game by eliminating the randomness and blindness from the action cards. Under evaluation, we'll see when the reprints (RGG is reprinting both El Grande and the Expansion Kit) roll around in October 2005.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Rules Complexity: :star::star::nostar::nostar::nostar:
Strategic Depth: :star::star::star::halfstar::nostar:
Luck Factor :star::nostar::nostar::nostar::nostar:
Negotiation Factor: :nostar::nostar::nostar::nostar::nostar:
Amount of Downtime: :star::star::nostar::nostar::nostar:
Fiddliness: :star::nostar::nostar::nostar::nostar:
Replayability: :star::star::star::star::star:
Component Quality: :star::star::star::star::star:
Player Interaction: :star::star::star::star::star:
"Take That" Conflict: :star::star::star::star::halfstar:

There are many things I like about El Grande: 
- I love the way I can never be completely in control of what happens, but yet can influence the gameplay in significant ways, especially if I can get inside the minds of my opponents.  The element of bluffing is very cool.
- I love how the castillo gives you those "gotcha" moments.  That element of guessing where your opponents are going to place their castillo cubes adds a superb amount of tension and suprise.
- I love the simple way auctioning with your power cards is implemented - great stuff!
- I really like the amount of confrontation in this game.  After playing a lot of your normal non-confrontational Euro-fare, playing this was like scratching an itch I didn't know I had.  The player interaction is very direct, and can get very mean!  But hey - if your children can handle Sorry!, they can handle this.
- Overall, I thought the mechanics of this game meshed together exceptionally well, leaving me with many good options and very difficult choices at every turn.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
San Marcohoz hasonló játék (vagy inkább fordítva). Itt is a megfelelő pillanatban a megfelelő helyen kell többséget szerezni. Itt is különféle kártyák kijátszásával lehet ezt elérni. Itt sokkal többféle kártya van, mint a San Marcoban, és itt a kártyákat egy speciális licittel szerezzük meg, szemben a San Marco "én felezek, te választasz" mechanikájával. 

Tetszett a játék, szívesen játszom még vele. Elsőre kicsit nehéz volt átlátni a nagyon sokféle kártyát, de a játék végére már kezdtem megérteni az ábrákat rajtuk, és így nem kellett a sok szöveggel bajlódni. Az első játék után egyetlen negatívumot éreztem: szerintem túl nagy a királycsinálás lehetősége ebben a játékban. Szoros állás esetén, simán el tudja dönteni egy-egy hátul lévő játékos azt, hogy kié legyen a végső győzelem.

------------
Ez a királycsinálós dolog az amúgy nagyszerű játék leggyengébb pontja. Igazából az a baj, hogy a játék végén nem az van, hogy valakik(k) királyt tud csinálni ha akar, hanem szinte minden esetben muszáj is neki. Egyszerűen döntenie kell, hogy a-nak vagy b-nek nyeri meg a játékot. Ez sokat ront az amúgy nagyon taktikus, strategikus játék összképén... :(
8->7

----------------
Megfogalmazódott bennem, hogy mi a legnagyobb bajon vele: rengeteget lehet és kell is rajta gondolkodni, de ehhez képest túl sok múlik a véletlenen, dolgok egybeesésén.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
El Grande is an area control game (if not the prototype of the genre). Quite unordinarily, it doesn't show its age at all and can easily keep up with newly released games.

What makes the game interesting are the action cards that additionally also specify how many followers you get to dispatch to the various regions of Spain. Some of these cards are notably stronger than others, and combined with the bidding process that's used to determine who can choose what this adds a certain amount of luck. Also a bit too dry for some.

RATING: 9.528
Decennial Edition contains all expansions (and some cards with missing text - poor QA for a Decennial). Apparently one of the seminal Eurogames, it is a game with a most elegant design. UPDATE : A few more games, and It's still with 5 players a very elegant game (29/11/11).UPDATE: given the expansion included (King & Intrigue) is included in my version, and this game is equally good (but significantly different), the games rating increases by 1 to 9 (30//11/12). RATING: 8
I have only played one 2 player game yet, but it seems like a really great game!!

Probably my favorite EuroGame!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
El Grande is a great Euro.  Trying to build influence in each of the territories by placing the members of the court throughout Spain works very well.  Trying to balance the number of people you hire from the provinces into your court vs. the level of power and number of people from the court you can release is very well balanced.  I like that you must also balance the powers you get and the powers you want to stop your opponents from getting.  You also have to keep in mind the number of people you deposit into the castle, which can be good for points and offer a huge advantage in terms of overpowering other players in Spain.  This game is one of BALANCE, all the time.  Too much or too little force in one aspect can lose you the game.  It is occasionally frustrating, considering the choices you can make, and with no catch-up mechanisms you can really find yourself falling behind in a 5-player game, but overall it's great!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
1 game, 5 players: very fun. i can see how the game will be worse with less but with 5 players i enjoyed a lot! looking forward to play again, though, to decide my final opinion.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
There's something that just doesn't click with me with these area majority games like this one and Louis XIV. Although I kinda know what to do, I always concede the valuable areas to the players who are more experienced and confident. I usually end up maybe not last, but nowhere near the lead.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Although El Grande is the quintessential area control Euro, it has never been able to become a favorite of mine.  The tension is there; the decision making is there, but something is missing.  For me it may simply be the consistency. By this I mean El Grande offers a different experience each time -not in gameplay, but in fun.  Sometimes I am completely absorbed, and at others I am bored and find it dry (I love Colovini by the way).  Regardless, I find El Grande to be an extremely substantial title, that has proven itself now for ten years, and will be one I play easily for ten more. It just never will be a first choice.

UPDATE: This game is a supremely solid design.  With a few more plays this has begun to shine.  It needs the five players, but if they are there, chances are El Grande is one of your better options.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
Lots of interesting things going on in this elegant area control game.  I find the gameplay to be very tactical in nature.  The revolving action cards result in some nice variability between rounds, but you don't really need to memorize the deck to be able to play well.  Moves along pretty well; not so much opportunity for analysis paralysis as you'll find in some of the action point-based games.

The turn order determination leaves something to be desired.

RATING: 6
A solid well made area majority euro. I'm glad I got to play it and would play it again if others wanted to get it out. What I disliked was the hidden trackable information. I did enjoy the castillo mechanic as well as the king mechanic, I thought they worked well together. The game has simple rules and streamlined gameplay. A good amount of interaction for a euro, but not enough to satisfy the wargamer side of me. I recommend it to eurogamers that enjoy player interaction and area majority.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This game is in my top 5 games.  Super subtle strategy.  I think newbies pick up on it pretty well, esp. with the player aides that came with my new copy.

It's hard for someone to win if it's their first time and they are playing with an experienced player, which is probably good.

I suppose it can fall into a kingmaking type of game, but honestly, I haven't seen that.  With 5 people, there's not much elbow room, and people are usually just trying to keep their own stuff and aren't in a position to gang up really.

If I were resetting my collection, this would be an auto-include and I can't see myself getting sick of this one.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
RECEIVED: 2015

KOREA

This is the closest game I've found to a 10. I can see why others would rate it lower. It neither has a strong theme nor is the "game play" necessarily thematic. It's also a bit random in the cards that appear in the stacks each round. However, I realized not too long ago that area control games are among my favorites, and I have yet to find one that does it better than El Grande. Conflict is simple, there is a lot of take that, the cards are well balanced, the dynamic of court and provinces is an interesting push/pull, the Castillo creates a lot of great tension, and the staged scoring keeps your head in the game. Viva El Grande!

EDIT: I still love this game--it's a classic!--but I've come down a bit on the rating. For stripped down simplicity and tactics, El Grande is the king of area majority games. However, lately I've wanted something a little meatier, a little more involved.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
An often-imitated game that's my favorite of the "Acquire/Airlines/El Grande" family (scoring based on ranking players' strengths in various areas or categories).  The heart of the game is the tactical decision-making that goes into the bidding and the selection of the action cards.  There's perhaps more opportunity for leader bashing than I typically enjoy, but the game system limits the bashing enough that front-running is a plausible strategy.

RATING: 9
Several great mechanics melded together so beautifully. I love the area majority; I love deliberating about the most useful moves; I love the 'cold war' aspect of the Castillo. 

I can't decide if the uncontrollable chaos will ultimately wane my currently high view of El Grande. One friend remarked, after losing horribly, that he felt his Cabelleros were controlled more by other players than by himself. He refuses to play again. I can't help but think that poor play from unseasoned players created this type of experience. Unfrotunately, another game that needs a certain quality of play for the tension and competition to really shine. I hope I get to play enough to see this happen in my group.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7.2
A really solid area control game. You have to pay close attention to what your opponents are doing and gang up on the leader if someone starts to break away. I like how the power cards dictate turn order and knowing when to go first and when to go last is imperative. This is a skill I do NOT possess, which always makes it hard for me to really buy into games like this. I'd definitely play this one again if asked, but it rates just below the threshold that warrants a purchase.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Eight plays. A Euro-style game that has an epic quality to it. With five players it's a nail-biting struggle within a densely interrelated but elegant system, one that rewards flexibility and a sharp eye. 

Some people fault the game for lacking long-term strategy, since so much can change from round to round, but that aspect of the game doesn't bother me; to me it's about juggling a lot of balls and trying to keep everything in balance regardless of what the game throws at you. You need to make choices between early points and cubes on the board, you need to have cubes in your court, you have to be able to get the initiative when the time is right, you have to keep yourself from getting involved in pissing matches, et cetera, et cetera. 

Unfortunately the pace of the game can be killed by hyperanalytic players, and players also need a really thick skin or they're going to get their feelings hurt. For those reasons I like El Grande best when people aren't taking it *too* seriously.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
My favorite game at the moment. Easy, fun, strategic-depth, quick setup time, and the ability to add complexity via the expansions (which now come all collected together with the main game) make for a near-perfect game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7.5
Surprisingly simple area control game. Place cubes on the board using cards that you draft (one per turn). Every now and then a scoring round gets you points for majority cubes in a region. That's basically it! A nice variety of cube-pushing cards add a little bit of excitement, and the game's relatively quick pace (2 hours for the full game) keeps the game from getting dull.

RATING: 8
My first love with board gaming, and just as challenging as when I first opened the box.  I've seen other games use this mechanic, and many are more complex. If the actions to be bid on were more unbalanced, I might consider this a better experience.

RATING: 6
This is classic game of area control. In fact, all other games of area control origin from this one.

And, actually, this is decent game, with lot of player interaction (i.e. conflict), simple mechanics and wonderfully looking board (map of Spain). But then again, there is nothing more in it but some resource management, bidding and - I'll say again - area control. There are, definitely, better games which are based on the same mechanism that provide some more fun and complexity.

I'll leave it up to you whether it's worth to own it, or not. This is classic, I repeat, so if you're a game collector and have enough space for [b]really big[/b] box, you should give it a try. Good luck.

RATING: 4.5
Rating after 1 play. I played with a group that had played over a dozen times, I was the only newbie. Still I managed to jump out to a huge lead. I was up by 25 points after the first 2 scoring rounds. It ended up being a 5 point game because of a serious bit of bash the leader. In the last 3 rounds I had people moving my pieces all over the board and doing everything they could to thwart any plan I had made. The biggest problem I have with this is that a few of the people doing this had no chance to win, so all they were doing was potentially helping the 2nd or 3rd place person win (we played with 5). It would have been a shame if 2nd place won because the leader got bashed in to oblivion. Will see how it plays out next time. It was still fun, but I have to be fair in that if I had lost I probably would have said I hated it. I did really enjoy the flow of the game and the mechanic used to determine what actions you could do.

RATING: 8
Some people seem to dislike area influence games--but I am not one of those people. El Grande is undoubtedly among the best of them that I've tried. It's simple, accessible, deep, and swift moving. You get screw-your-neighbour without losing control, short-term vs. long-term scoring options, and lots of fun. It's aged very well indeed, but El Grande scales very poorly. Needs at least 4 players.
[EDIT] The action card decks can really produce some crazy games--both good and bad. The decks can really screw you, or--much worse--produce a very poor game. I&K is much better.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
El Grande is a very well-designed game that is simply not what I enjoy. The main mechanic is area control. You are trying to gain a plurality in each area on the board. The main actions you will take involve adding a few cubes, shuffling cubes about (both yours and your opponents') in an attempt to edge them out. 

There is very little "attacking" in a typical area control sense. A hard-fought battle in El Grande looks like one player having one more cube than his opponent, rather than actually driving his opponent out of a territory he wants. It's a game of tiny advantages that has the feel of a shoving match instead of a fistfight. 

Vying for special powers, locking down territories you are winning, and remembering how many cubes are in the large black tower also come into play. The memory element is mostly an annoyance as if you make a point to keep track, it is not hard to remember. Yet forgetting is a huge penalty and may (again) see a player taking lots of points from you by edging you out with a single cube. 

El Grande demands that successful players walk a knife's edge of precision and optimization. There are no surprises, no alliances, no thrilling turns of fortune. There is only optimization of every single action and prediction of the chaos that your opponents may bring to your plans as they seek to carry out their own. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A fun game but I was surprised at how much direct aggression it allows. Don't be in the lead too early or else you'll get hit pretty hard. I like the mechanics but I don't like how the game encourages you to make poor choices just so you don't get ganged up on.

RATING: 3

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
It seemed daunting at first, but I settled into a groove playing El Grande.  The game is very intense and requires a bunch of thinking/forethought into your moves.  It never really becomes clear who is going to win, even in the last two rounds or so unless you're extremely good at keeping mental tally on what people have and haven't done so far.

The game puts together a lot of different things (bidding/worker management) in ways that are ultimately successful.  

Despite the 2+ hour run time, the entire group was enthralled by the game the whole way though.  There's so much to keep your focus and concentration on, it's hard to become bored or disinterested.  

Great game.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7

And by incredible solid i mean, although it's from '95 this hasn't been surpassed yet!
The simplicity & ease, combined with the clean mechanics makes this game still stand out of the crowd.
The artwork elevates the rather abstract game to something of a theme.

Having said that, people with AP can fall victim to the many options they are faced with.

If i liked euros better this would be a solid 10 for me.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A game of area control and bidding. Players have 13 cards with numbers 1-13. Only use the cards once per game. Player bids highest gets to go first and smallest goes last. However, the last player gets to go first next round. A clever game of area control, bidding, memory.

Hint: Must make sure to conquer the "4" and "5" areas

RATING: 9
The game has rules like a gateway game, with medium deepness. You are trying to make progress by gaining points rewarded for your clever play. The interaction is high and sometimes can be cutthroat that i love. The components are very good quality, but the artwork appeals to be a bit boring and outdated for me. The gameplay was entertaining however i feel like something is missing there. I will give it another chance, but i can't say this game is the best price / value of all time. I don't feel that cubes are my knights at all. After the second play im certain this game won't be in my top10 anytime soon. At the moment i don't understand quite enough the deepness of the gameplay, but i like the ever changing atmosphere. You must adapt to the new situation every single turn. You are trying to choose the best of the avaialable options, but you might be wrong! If you are always in the second place you might be win the whole game in the end. The more players play this game, the better it becomes. It isn't supposed to played with just 2.

RATING: 9
A great game of intrigue and strategy.  It constantly has me wanting to do more than my one action, and be frustrated that I didn't have a perfect setup.  I like the fact that the tactics outweigh the random factor, and I love the balance.  

That said, I find it difficult to get this game to the table often.  It is a "brain burner" and requires serious concentration while playing.  I have to keep "shussh"-ing those who whant to socialize.  For this reason I see this as a "gamer's game" and not a social game.  

I also own the expansions, and while they are very promising, I have not had the opportunity to get them in play yet.  I have, however, used "Intrique and the King" as a way to introduce players to the game without the full mechanisms.  It is not quite the same game, but close enough to enjoy immensely, as well as removing a key component that confuses new players.  (I actually played with a full deck, and let players use cards as they wish instead of "building" a deck.)

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I can see why this is in the Top 10. It is simple, fast, yet has subtle tactical play. It is an area control game, much like San Marco, and instead of making/taking offers, the players bid for the right to go first. Each has a set of power cards, ranking from 1 to 13. Also, each card has a number of caballoro's, which indicates how many 'meeples' can be brought from a supply pile, which is called a 'province', into 'the court'. Higher ranks have fewer or meeples, while the lowest ranks have the ability to bring out a lot of meeples.

There are also five of action cards that are flipped up from different piles on the side. Players select these action cards in bid order. Each action card has a increasing number of symbols that signify how many meeples can be sent out to the various provinces out on the board. Each province has a non-linear scaling of victory points for first, second, and third place, where dominance is indicated by the number of meeples in that province. So, bidding may become fast and furious if certain action cards show up.

There is also an interesting mechanic, where players may deposit some meeples in a tower. The dominance in the tower gives points, but also allows a player to secretly redistribute those meeples during a scoring round to one province.

After playing three rounds, I finally got it, but by then the owner of the game had an insurmountable lead. I wouldn't mind playing it again, but I don't think I will need to get my own copy. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
0704
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
特殊カードの嵐、と当時は思ったが今遊ぶと全く問題にならない。カードは全公開なので、わからないカードがあっても気軽に人に聞くことができる。とはいえ、毎回カードを確認しながらのプレイはテンポが悪い。加えて、長考しやすいシステムなので、もっとテンポが悪い。
ゲーム自体は他人との絡みと読み合いが楽しい非常に良いゲーム。カードの出方によって、ゲームを大きく変えずにそれでいて毎回展開が異なるのも好印象。
パワーカードを同時公開するバリアントはゲーム時間を短くし、程度に運の要素も入るのでお勧め。
適正人数は5人。

RATING: 9
This is a great gateway game. It's easy to teach to new players & captures my attention for the whole game.  Every player's decision affects me & the consequences of each of my actions has a big impact on the present & future state of the game. Each game always has a bunch of tense moments when the hidden decisions are revealed or when you watch to see what actions will be taken before you get to choose.  The theme is thinner than some of my other favourites but that's about the only downside for me.  WIsh I'd have found it sooner!

Prefer to play with the full 5 players.

I'm looking forward to giving the expansions a go too.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
The original area majority game, where the theme is stripped down to its abstract minimum. Well implemented as a carefully calculated series of trade offs in the bidding cards, but then the action cards throw a huge amount of chaos into the board position. This is one of the classis Euros, but revisiting it recently was a disappointment. You just can't overcome the chaos factor and often feel that the game is playing you as much as you're playing it. It's also very bland, later games like Liberte and In the Shadow of the Emperor are much more flavourful. Worthy of respect, but the King & Intrigue variant is the only one I'm interested in playing today.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Pure area majority games bore me to tears, and this is about as pure as they get. Plenty of tactical options save it from being completely dry but there is way too much chaos for my taste. It feels like how well I do is determined by what other people decide to do rather than my own play.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
100 PLN
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I knew I was looking forward to this for a reason.  If you are planning on going around labeling games as "elegant," El Grande is the one to do it with.  The game seems really deep, with plenty to think about each turn, and yet it's simple to play, and even with my current rather inexpert attempts at the game I've been able to feel happy with my decisions (while still grasping for a deeper level of understanding).  As everyone probably knows by now, it is an area control game with many ways to move cubes around the board and interesting tradeoffs between the ability to do interesting stuff and/or go first, and the ability to get more cabelleros on the board.  Absolutely love it.  Yes, there is a memory element, but unless you are playing with people who are particularly good at counting cubes, it just adds another level of doubt and tension to the game. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
El abuelo de los juegos de mayorías es un indispensable. Tiene todo lo que me gusta encontrar en un juego: fácil de aprender, decisiones difíciles, interacción, alguna que otra puñalada, "bluff", frustración y buenos componentes en menos de dos horas. Buenísima mecánica la de las cartas de poder en la que con una única decisión determinas tres variables: meter caballeros en tu corte (aumentar tus recursos), situarlos en el tablero (aumentar tu capacidad de puntuar) y decidir la acción a realizar (puntuar/putear). Más "adaptativo" (táctico) que "previsor" (estratégico) A favor: a pesar del caos reinante (cubos siempre moviéndose) no notas que esté "fuera de tu control". ¡Interacción en un eurogame! Puede jugarse "pensando lógicamente" o con "pensamiento intuitivo" y ser ambos estilos igualmente válidos. En contra: envejece muy mal y perde fuelle rápidamente conforme aumenta el nº de partidas. A algunos se les hace insoportable tanto "caos de filler" en dos horas de duración. Abstracto y con tendencia a "descabezar al lider". Si quieres que sea de jugones hay que comprar la expansión "koing und intrigant"
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8

RATING: 7

It don't take the 2 hours it says, rather a little more than an hour (at least with four).  It's a well designed game with many strategies and a good touch of luck.  I'd recommend giving this a game play and consideration in your rotation of games to play on a regular basis.

RATING: 10
Wonderful area majority game.  The map of Spain illustrated on game board is awesome!  El Grande has a surprising re-playability factor because the sequence that the cards come out can dramatically change the character of the game from one play to another.  Not recommended with less than 4 players.  Five players is best.  Every time I play this, I have an awesome experience.  Great game mechanics, very interesting choices to make on your turn.  I wish every board game was this much fun.  I cannot recommend this highly enough or overstate the profound fun I experience sharing El Grande games with friends.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

*Edit* This is now my most played game and I adore it.

RATING: 9
El Grande is a surprisingly elegant while distilled area control game with massively overproduced components.  The gameplay is very simple yet engaging and interactive (shocking for a Euro, really).  The bits are somewhat gimmicky what with the tower of obfuscation known as "the Castillo," or some such similarly sounding Luchadores name, and secret selection spinning wheels for paratrooping in Spanish court members to various regions.  Of course, I love stuff like that, so it only enables an increased rating in my eyes.  -Great game.

RATING: 9.5
My favorite area-control game.  A definite winner when you have 4 or 5 to play (5 is best).  (I did try it once as a 2-player game - it plays well, but it is much more directly confrontational . . . which may work for some people, but I enjoy the subtle plays available with more players.)

Fabulous mechanics and good replayability.  Easier to teach than expected - nice balance to the play.

Haven't tried any of the expansions yet - the base game plays so well, I just haven't felt the need.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.7
Finally got to play it.  It really is a great game.  A little too cut-throat for my tastes, and I don't like the uneven power level of the special actions.  Even though, the other mechanics ran like a well oiled machine and I had a great time.

I *really* liked how the higher bids would net you less cubes, as would the more devious action cards.  I think this small touch was what really did it for me.  I spent most of the game just maximizing the best actions I could net with the most cubes still available to place.

Aug10:

A few plays later.  I don't know why, but this seems like the minimal investment to get an "Epic" feel.  Nothing else does it as well.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Nice area control game with very simple rules but plenty of depth beneath the surface.  Interesting risk/reward mechanic in the "betting" for turn order, the reward being more soldiers to place (which score points) in exchange for turn position - going last is often bad news.

I also like the Castillo mechanic, in which players can place their soldiers into a hidden castle.  The point being that those soldiers can be deployed all at once before a scoring round, this gives you something else to consider and deepens the game just that bit more.

Played with 5 players which apparently is the sweet spot for this game, it did take a long time to get through but 3 of the 5 players were new to it so I expect it will be a lot swifter if played again.  Recommended.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Could only manage a two-player intro to the system game. I can see how the interaction in a five player game would make this really shine, but area control is not a type of game I enjoy as much as others.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
My favorite Area Majority game, and a contender for favorite game overall.

The fact that you get 13 unique cards to bid with makes for a agonizing decision. What makes that decision brilliant, however, is that it also determines how many caballeros you can move from the provinces to your court. You are constantly asking yourself how badly you need to take a specific action. The actions themselves are quite balanced. In any given situation one is much more powerful than the others, but overall they are all very useful.

Best with 5
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I can see why this game is a classic.  Very solid and fairly "pure" area majority game, with nothing else glued on.  There's a neat mechanism where you have cards numbered up to 13, but you can only play each one once. These determine turn order, but the low (bad) ones balance out by providing the only resource in the game, your guys.  I enjoyed it, and would definitely play it again.

RATING: 10
If I had to choose, I'd name this my favorite board game. (Acquire is a very close second.) Love the player interaction and the way all the game's mechanics mesh together. I considered this game to be heavy/complex in when I was first introduced to it in the early 2000s, but as heavy euros have adopted increasingly intricate mechanics and rulesets, I appreciate more and more how streamlined El Grande is. 

Some people don't like the attack-the-leader aspect, but I embrace it. You gotta play the players. 

The only thing I don't like is the veto card.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
initial rating, may change slightly, especially after playing expansion

WOW! Everything I hoped for was here.

Tough tough game, even tough to rate. There are so many tough decisions to make in the game all with interesting outcomes. I found a lot of intrigue in this game which was great. Planning is a real b*tch as everytime I do I almost never get to do it, must be very flexible in your strategies, very tactically rich game to be sure. The balance of the game was outstanding, the cards, your bidding cards, the tower, the scoring, all very well thought out. Best area influence game out there I'm sure if you can stand the lack of control (chaos factor). I do see the K&I expansion takes a lot of the chaos away and adds more strategy to the game so I am very anxious to try this, could be my first 10. I still think playing both ways will be very fun but I say that now, we'll see.

[u]UPDATE:[/u] more plays has revealed there is more control than first conceived (once you know the game better you can anticipate and plan better) however I can't wait to try K&I and the other expansions look quite interesting as well (rules read).

[u]UPDATE:[/u]9.25 => 9 After 8 games or so of this and comig back to it after a long layover it now feels chaotic again. Maybe it was just a 'bad day' but overall long term planning is pretty much out, this combined with the limited control now subtracts for me hence the rating drop. I still think it is a brilliant, elegant and fun all-time classic but it does have slight downsides.

I have also played K & I and it was not the "be all end all" I hoped it was and it was very AP prone and dragged on. Since control in the original is starting to bother me more I will have to try the expansion yet again....

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Lightly-themed area control game.  Players bid on action cards which affect the placement of "caballeros" in areas and sometimes scoring.  Action cards are beautifully balanced given their variety.  Can be a little too computation-heavy.  We use a chess king in place of the king piece provided with the game--it looks cooler and is the subject of far fewer jokes.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This is a pretty fun game.  I've only played once, so it will be interesting to see whether my rating will change with additional plays.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Classic area majority game. The rules are light so this helps as a gateway game for new players to learn area majority games. The strategy changes with every different combination of the 5 action cards. The Castillo adds to the tension of the game as they allows players to suddenly turn some majorities in their favor every 3 rounds. This game doesn't show its age and is still one of of the best area majority games out there.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.4
Bokkensprong 17/10/14 met Sander, Pascal, Roy en ik. Doel: punten scoren door op gezette momenten de meeste troepen in specifieke gebieden (Spaanse provincies) te hebben staan. In elke provincie is een te verdienen score opgegeven voor de grootste, tweede en derdegrootste troepenmacht daar aanwezig. Indien meerdere spelers daar even grote troepen hebben staan, krijgen ze allen een score lager dan normaal.
Spelverloop: Ieder trekt een thuisbasis (dikke blok in provincie) en legt om de beurt een cijferkaart die de speelvolgorde zal bepalen (de hoogste begint). Tijdens je beurt 1) neem je evenveel nieuwe mannetjes uit de provincie (de pot) als op je cijferkaart staat aangegeven, 2) kies je een actiekaartje, 3) zet je evenveel mannetjes op het bord (of je steekt er een aantal in de toren) als aangegeven op je actiekaartje, 4) voer je de actie uit (vb. verplaats de koning; verplaats troepen; reken één provincie af, etc.). Puntjes 3 en 4 mogen ook omgewisseld worden. Om de drie beurten wordt de toren geleegd, krijgen de grootste troepen daar punten voor, en mogen die troepen in een (geheim te kiezen) regio worden bijgeplaatst voor alle provincies worden afgerekend. Super spel zonder al te complexe spelregels. Een topper voor mij!

Sinterklaas 2014: gekregen!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.4
The grand-daddy of majority/scoring games. Over nine turns, players manipulate their control blocks of wood on the board, to try and make them score as many of the regions as possible. Getting them to the board is a three step process, and once on the board they can be moved and removed by events. Lots to think about and certainly rewarding when you win, but boiled down you are never far removed from moving coloured cubes around a board. Several expansions are available. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
What a great game!  There is randomness only in what cards come up - but no randomness that affects if a player will win or lose - that's left up to skill!  A great game that is not a brain burner.  It's fun and social and very competitive.  The expansions only make it better by allowing for variations.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Mildly enjoyable but doesn't scratch my gaming itch as much as some other games.  Area control, getting points through dominating areas with your pieces.  You have to make trade-offs between a number of factors including getting more pieces into play, the number of pieces you get to place at a time, and getting first choice at a number of special actions.  Lots of trying to figure out what everyone else is up to and out-maneuvering them as there are a variety of options and a variety of territories with different values.  If that's what you like, this is a very good game.  A typical eurogame in that the theme is a bit thin as the mechanics are rather abstract.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
The cool tower lends an interesting mechanic to the various scoring turns.  This is a nice quick game that is easy to explain.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

I can certainly see why this game has the reputation it does - a great area control experience.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.8
Great game, elegant mechanics, scales well and plays out in a decent 60-90 mins. Lots of interesting decisions, and every decision is potentially a critical one, which is how I like my games.

RATING: 9
One of the best area control games out there. I've played with 2, 3, 4 and 5. Pretty good with 2, very good with 3, excellent with 4 and 5. It has a lot more screwage than other area control games, but it's well done and not overly frustrating. Every phase of a turn offers agonizing decisions. A winner that I expect to be in the rotation for a long time. Upped rating from a 9 to a 10 - this is my favorite area control game, hands down, in spite of it's relatively inferior play with 2 players.

RATING: 7.5
2011-08-22

Initial Rating: 8.5 (August 2010)

A GREAT gamer´s game. The father of the Majority games. 

Its reputation is totally deserved. El Grande has simple mechanics and can be explained quickly to new players, but it also has a surprising and satisfying tactical/strategic depth. This is one of the few games that I enjoy with the full complement of 5 players as the tension goes up with the bidding (it also plays well with 4 players. Not recommended with less than 4 players), also you don’t feel the downtime as you are planning all the time. It has a "screw your neighbor" feel so if you enjoy this kind of thing go for it you won’t regret it. The luck factor is relatively low (another plus for me).

On the bad side the game lends itself to unintentional kingmaking by a player with less relative skill and/or experience.

I totally recommend it, one of my favorite Euros.

Current Rating: 8.5
[hr]
2015-09-14

I have changed a lot during my 5 yearlong gaming career. I (generally) no longer enjoy games in which the “attack the leader” mechanism is prevalent, however El Grande has a special place in my heart so it continues to be among my favorite games. I’m still decreasing its rating but it is a solid game. I won’t ever sell it.

Current Rating: 7.5

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This is an awesome game that scales well. My wife likes it and that's always a plus.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Classic of area majority games. Each player has a set of Power cards 1 to 13. In each round, highest card gets first choice of the five special actions on offer that round. Cards and actions increase the men in your reserve, other cards and actions let you play more or less men onto the board. Each space on the board has points for 1st/2nd/3rd.

Enjoyably different. A tight set of various mechanics work really well together, and the theme is completely in keeping... not a 100% natural theme layer, but completely in keeping.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
This game should get more "gateway" hype. This has been a great game for my family.

RATING: 9
I've wanted this game for two years; finally found it in a game store - and pulled the trigger!

Maybe because I waited so long for it (a lesson in abstinence, youth of America), but it was great, even with two players.

The box reads "a subtle game of strategy."  There really is no better way to describe this game.  You have many different options on your turn, different actions you can take or not take, but they all seem to make sense.  I can only imagine how cool this game will be with more than two players.

RATING: 9
El Grande is an outstanding game with deep strategy, dramatic interaction, and a healthy amount of tension. The use of the power cards to bid for card order is practically a game within itself; the action cards keep the game dynamic and full of suspense; the castillo and secret disks add even more layers of strategic decision making. This smooth, elegant classic defined area control and I haven't seen another game that does it better.

RATING: 7

I like the strategic angle to the bidding, and the area control aspect works well, but I have a (personal) lack of enthusiasm for myriad special powers, embodied in the action cards in El Grande, and I'm not yet convinced that the interplay between bidding cards, action cards, and the caballero province-to-court-to-board pipeline is ideal.

RATING: 7
I like to call this a game of controlled chaos. You're looking to score points based on having a majority(1st/2nd/3rd)of pieces in each region. However the board changes, often dramatically,from round to round. And sometimes even from player to player making it hard/near impossible to employ long term strategy.

I really only like to play this game with 5 players as I feel the board is a little too open with less.

RATING: 9
I finally have the expansion! I am really looking forward to give this a try!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
An interesting game of multiple area control.  This game has several innovations that make it better than similar games - the power card concept is quite nice, as obviously some action cards are much more powerful than others.  You can't complain about your action cards, because you could always have played your 13 and taken your pick!  They balance the game very nicely.  The castillo is also interesting, although it should be visible by all players in my opinion.  Why tax the memory unnecessarily?  The theme is very weak, and the game seems abstract and dry.  Also, it suffers from two multi-player conflict game weaknesses, beat-up-on-the-leader, and two-guys-take-each-other-down.  Hardcore multiplayer gamers might not even think that these are weaknesses, but I have a preference for games where the leader can more easily keep his position through skillful play.  Even so, for what it is, it is nearly perfect, and it is easy to see how it gets such high ratings.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.5
Did not like, boring after a while.  Apparently I like a little theme to the game and this has none, it could be ducks on a pond.  If it was fun I could overlook theme.  For such a high rated BGG game this one really disappoints.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A true classic for a reason. So much fun to play. This is still the best area control game made to date and that says a lot, as this game was released in 1996! I Take my hat off and make a deep bow for Mr. Kramer & Ulrich.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Every phase in this game has interesting and challenging decisions. Do I go early in turn order or replenish my court? Which action do I want to take or prevent and how badly? How many cubes do I need to move to the board? Should I play heavily to the Castillo or not? Should I use the king to open up regions for placement, or block regions from other players? The specifics of each available action in the current combination makes these decisions even harder, but also more fun. Area majority games can tend to be on the dry side - place cubes, remove cubes, move cubes. I tend not to like bare-bones majority games that are not combined with special actions, such as China. But there are some - El Grande is one, Struggle of Empires is another - that use the base mechanics as a foundation for a variety of interesting choices. I score this game a 9, but it may even deserved a ten. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
Let me put it this way. By rights, with a little marketing (and proofreading, ahem) there should be a whole generation of kids who fondly remember El Grande instead of Risk. The ratio of simplicity to challenge/engagement/replayability is such that I imagine this one will be around in 50 years. 

Don't even bother playing without 5. It won't get to the table as much as a result, but this is the perfect five player game. 

Update: If you like this, you owe it to yourself to seek out Struggle of Empires. Strong kinship between the two, but each succeeds on its own merits.

RATING: 10
The best area control game I have played.  Very high intensity.  Timing is very impotent as is card counting.  Also a bit of bluffing can be useful to trick your opponents is useful.  The Castile/tower really adds to the game. It is very competitive, but this makes it a very fun game.  It plays great with more players.  It is hard to play without taking sides with other players, but this makes it very interactive.
I think some players will not like this element of the game and that it can be so competitive.
Another minor gripe is perhaps some of the cards aren't as balanced as they could be.
I can't believe this game is not in print.  Many modern games are not as good as this one.
Top 10 game on my list.

RATING: 8
Fun area control game that presents tough and interesting choices. Tactics within a single turn are more important than long term planning. [Follow-up edit: I think that long-term planning of the use of your bid cards is very important; in particular the flexibility in available bids at points of scoring.] The gang-up-on-the-leader potential is a minor annoyance. The theme as irrelevant to the actual game play. The Castillo is a brilliant game mechanic. Overall a very, very solid game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I admire the game system, but I don't like its chaotic nature.  Part of the problem is that I have the German version and found it was difficult to play.  I got the English Cards, but the cards were too small to see across the table.  I am not willing to spend more on the game so I gave up.  This experience is why I am very leery of getting German games with language on the cards.

Upon playing it once more, I think I can pinpoint the reasons that I do not like this game as much as I should: 

1. It is too chaotic for my tastes. Who wins is dictated more by what other people do to you than what you do. 

2. It is prone to Analysis Paralysis. There are a lot of choices and a lot of possible responses and some people try to figure out all the possibilities. 

3. A combination of 1 & 2 above. It is too long for the amount of randomness. I feel it has more randomness in it than Settlers and Ra. Whereas Settlers and Ra usually can be done in 30-45 minutes, I am usually looking at a 2 hour playing time for El Grande. 

4. Too much of a wargamers feel to me. There are too many cards that end up you hurting someone else (and the ones not targeted win).

RATING: 9
Based on 15+ plays.  El Grande's greatness comes from its well-honed balance of competing elements.  The rules are quite elegant, while permitting myriad crucial decisions.  The subtle random elements provide just enough chaos to keep the game exciting, while still allowing players to plan ahead.  And the scoring mechanism allows meaningful conflict, while mitigating the bash-the-leader tendency of other games.

RATING: 4
I feel similar about this game as I do about Power Grid.  Really good fundamental concept and gameplay, but just held back by a few design flaws.

Firstly the tower - what were they thinking?  Bizarre.  We played without it because it's just so stupid, but then I think that kind of breaks the game, too.

Also the action card decks, there are too many weird abilities available to everyone every turn.

In short, the game is just a huge mess and way too chaotic for my taste.  Long term planning isn't really possible.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Combines strategic play, auctioning, and bluffing.
Have only played a 5 player game, which I hear is the way to go and unfortunately will limit chances of play.

This is a game of constant turmoil as area of influence (where you can place your meeples or "caballeros")changes and your caballeros get pushed around and you do your best to get back into scoring position by the end of the phase.

And don't ignore the Castillo (the huge wooden tower), or it will cost you the game.  Not only does it count for score at the end of the phase, but it allows you to "paratroop" your caballeros into any region of your choice.  This is the key bluff in the game, because you have to remember what your opponents have put in the Castillo, and also have to assume where they're dropping their men.  Do you need to protect an existing territory?  Or do you think that they think otherwise?  Some good multi-tiered game theory.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: N/A
Reprint coming
https://boardgamegeek.com/article/18001899#18001899

In this award-winning game, players take on the roles of Grandes in medieval Spain. The king's power is flagging, and these powerful lords are vying for control of the various regions. To that end, you draft caballeros (knights in the form of colored cubes) into your court and subsequently move them onto the board to help seize control of regions. After every third round, the regions are scored, and after the ninth round, the player with the most points is the winner.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
The grandpa of area control games. I still don't know why so many people stick to Risk. Maybe it's the gambling aspect. This was seriously what drew me off. I don't think a strategy game should involve dice in that way. El Grande on the other hand has everything and more - it's easy to teach, with timeless mechanisms and well balanced cards to choose from. And since the Big Box Edition for its 20th anniversary there are tons of new great stuff to explore. A timeless classic and my favourite area control game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Simplicity and elegance, as always when you speak of a Wolfgang Kramer's game. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
The great granddaddy of area majority games. Still one of the best of its kind. Full of interesting decisions and tension. Seems to be completely tactical but it's far from that. As the different cards in one deck provide more or less samey actions, the game also feels like a forerunner of "one-worker placement" like Puerto Rico and, as a result, a forerunner of worker placement games - here, while the action spaces offer something different each turn, you bid with your cards for the player order (and the caballeros you get this turn) and then, in player order, each player chooses one action and then everyone executes it - just like in worker placement games.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
[2007.Feb.17] Not quite sure how to rate this one yet. The mechanics are truly elegant on paper, but during play the game feels quite chaotic. Long-term planning does not seem to be possible. Additionally, it appears that if a player ends up trailing (in score) by a significant margin after the 1st scoring turn, he/she may not be able to catch-up for the rest of the game.

RATING: 8
I'm of the opinion that this was a "ground-breaking" design in modern Euro/German-style games.  I sometimes prefer Eiszeit/Mammoth Hunters for a quicker "area influence" game but this truly is a lofty classic by Kramer, regardless of whether it's your cup of tea or not.  You really don't need the expansions to add flavor to an already flavorful game.  However, with five players, I do prefer to add the (free) Grandissimo expansion so that the last player of a round has two stacks to pick from (b/c with 3 or 4 plyrs, the last plyr always has at least two stacks to choose from).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
2-5 players
Decennial edition
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Looks like this game appeals to both wargamers and Eurogamers from the ratings. 

I played this game with a group of 4.  But I don't have a sense of how to accompolish things in the game.  

El Grande is a game about the expansion of your Spanish kingdom to the surrounding areas adjacent to where the King is. By moving Caballeros from your provinces to your court then onto the regions, scoring of which according to the no. of Caballeros you have. Scoring happens on turn 3,6 and 9. So players prepare for the moving of Caballeros with the action cards revealed. The order of choosing the action cards and playing your Cablleros is determined by a power card bidding system, comparing 1 to 13 power value on the action cards, whereas the highest goes first in a descending order. 

Apart from the Spanish map, I find the whole game is very abstract to me. The action cards are randomly drawn and maybe this is my first play, I don't know how to choose the best card in view of the actual exsiting situation on the board. The concept of provinces, courts and regions are just names for the places to hold the Cablleros, simply a game mechanic which is too abstract to me in my mind. 

Well I guess I don't like the Euro game, no matter how this game is highly praised by the fellow Eurogamers here in BGG. No doubt I came last in a game of 5.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I can see why this game was so popular.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Pocos juegos tienen una profundidad estratégica como éste, a lo que hay que sumar que no se pueden aplicar estrategias definitivas por parte de los jugadores, que deben plantearse un plan A, uno B e incluso uno C, por lo que la toma de decisiones no es fácil ni tampoco rápida, algo que puede gustar a algunos pero exasperar a otros (por no decir una buena parte); por lo tanto, una sencillez de mecánica de juego se convierte en un laberinto de posibilidades que hace exprimir las neuronas de los jugadores en un afán imposible de hacer que su planteamiento teórico se lleve a la práctica.
Una profundidad estratégica que provoca una dificultad y una sensación de falta de control de juego no apta para todos los jugadores, aunque a mí me ha conquistado.

Variante:

Sólo se explican los cambios; el resto se mantiene fiel al juego original.

Cada jugador roba una carta de región. Aquel jugador cuya carta tenga una mayor puntuación en la primera casilla será el primero en jugar; en caso de empate, la segunda casilla, o la tercera si hay de nuevo iguales, decidirá el orden.

Se barajan las 13 cartas de juego, y sin mirar se quitan 4 boca abajo y se devuelven a la caja de juego. Las 9 restantes se colocan boca abajo en un mazo al alcanze del jugador.

Turno de un jugador:

1. Coger y mirar la primera de las 9 cartas del mazo de juego. Coger, como máximo, de las provincias, el número de caballeros representados por los iconos de caras en la carta. Descartar dicha carta boca arriba en un mazo de descarte. Conforme avanza el juego se van acumulando boca arriba una sobre otra las cartas de descarte de cada uno de los 9 turnos del juego.

2. Seleccionar 1 de entre las 5 opciones de las cartas de poder y proceder como indican las reglas del juego original.

El resto de jugadores procede de la misma manera en su propio turno en el orden de las agujas del reloj, igual que en las reglas originales del juego.


De esta manera se añade un factor de azar al no elegir intencionadamente qué carta de las 9 (ya no son 13, lo que le da aún más factor suerte) vas a utilizar. No siempre estarás en disposición de realizar la estrategia que tenías en mente, si no que tienes que adaptarte a las cartas que tienes en cada momento.

El turno de un jugador es suyo y sólo suyo; con esta variante ningún otro jugador puede interferir con su carta de acción (9 ahora) y arrebatar el orden del juego al jugador que actuamente tiene el turno en juego. Aunque se pierde interacción entre jugadores aporta dinamismo y simplicidad al juego. De esta manera un jugador sabe que en su turno él es quien manda y puede plantearse una clara estrategia (si las cartas de acción, las 9, se lo permiten) y decidir cuál de las 5 cartas de poder le interesa más porque le favorece más o porque le perjudica más a sus rivales.
El juego original se eternizaba en la toma de decisiones ya que una vez el jugador tomaba una decisión y en consecuencia jugaba una carta de acción (13 en ese caso), posteriormente otro jugador le estropeaba la jugada utilizando una carta de poder de mayor valor y adelantándose en el uso de las cartas de acción. De esta manera, aquél jugador tenía que replanterarse de nuevo la estrategia, con la consecuencia pérdida de tiempo y alargamiento de la partida.

Con esta nueva variante, la toma de decisiones es más rápida y se aporta un factor de azar más que interesante. Aunque se pierda un tanto de interacción entre jugadores, el resultado es más que satisfactorio.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Wow what a well designed game. I don't think I always want to play it as the level of tactical play is a bit too stressful for me, but there is a lot to think about for a game with a really simple concept of area control + timing of actions. For example, placing cubes in the castle seems really good because those cubes basically get to score twice, but put too many and you put tooany of your eggs in one basket, and also there are multiple actions that let you score regions immediately, which you can miss out on. The castillo or whatever it is called is also a really cool mechanism. That it locks out one region that it is placed allows you to guarantee wins there but makes it hard for you to win that region in the first place, and  that it soft locks nonadjacent regions while making adjacent ones vulnerable to manipulation means at other times you just want it far away from your winning regions. Of course, what you want may completely change based on if you went first or last in a round, which brings up something a lot of euros nowadays lack: gameplay that is highly dependent on group dynamics.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
