RATING: 7
Considering that area majority is one of my least favorite mechanics, this was a pleasant surprise. This game is all about area majority, with people pushing your cubes around and messing with your plans.

However, it's short enough that it doesn't overstay its welcome (even at 5 players). The cards also limit what you can do, and there's a great balance between getting cubes, putting them on the board, turn order, and the special action you get.

My only complaint is the castillo. There's *no* reason to keep that information hidden. For someone with goldfish memory like me, it's not that I forget what other people put in over 3 rounds, it's that I forget what *I* put in 30 seconds after I drop the cubes. I'd play the game again, but keep the castillo information open.

RATING: 8
This game has pretty much everything you could want in a classic Euro. It's beautifully designed, full of tension, reversals and tricky tactical decisions that come up out of nowhere. The luck element is strong enough to keep up the suspense without ever making one feel that it's determinative of who wins. My only slight complaint is that it does feel a bit abstract relative to some other Euros with the same virtues, such as Ursuppe and (perhaps most notably) Puerto Rico.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
The grand-daddy of the area majority games.  You bid on cards that allow you to place more cubes on the board while at the same time providing new cabalerros to be placed on the board from your supply.  It includes a lower that players can place cubes in and it is uncovered at the end of each scoring round.  The game is played over 12 turns with scoring at regular intervals.  Players get points based on majority control for first, second and third place on the board.  

An old game, but one that holds up very well.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4.7
I don't know why but I wasn't totally getting into El Grande. I think the problem may be in the power cards, there may be one or two that you really need to be effective but unless you're playing the number cards last you don't usually have much of a chance at them. Then if you end up playing the smallest number card and have to play your power card last you're punished by playing first the next round.

 I can see some advantages in playing a power card last (even though you are typically left with crap by that time) but I don't think it is proportional to the disadvantage of playing your number card first. Basically the win seems to go to whoever just happened to get screwed the least.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.8
Good game that have been around for 15 years now. Interesting mechanism for deciding turn order and moving cubes (caballeros) for dominance to and between provinces. The various posibilities to move around cubes with the actioncards make the game more tactic than for long term strategies even though there are severeal strategic elements to consider. 
The mechanisms with moving cubes for dominance (and cards that modifies) give the same feeling as in Louis XIV, but with higher complexity. The castill also ads some spice of tactical uncertainty and increases the fun of the game. It is loaded with interactions that if find intriguing and exiting. Might well raise in rank with more plays. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
It's an interesting game, but I've never been overly fond of it.

RATING: 6
We really wanted to like this game and, indeed, we had a good time playing it with friends. On the other hand, we didn't end up feeling like we would want to play it again. It is just too chaotic. There is so much randomness to the cards, and they have such wild and varied consequences, that it is hard to plan your game play.

Update after second play with 5. Again, we had a good time playing it, but didn't really come away liking the game. The game really encourages good player interaction and lots of fun commentary, which is why we had a good time playing it, but the basic game isn't all that fun. It is really just too random for us - every turn you get such a strange collection of cards to choose from it is really hard to know how to proceed.

The power play of using a low card two turns before scoring so you can place cards first and then using a high card one turn before scoring so you can place the Grande really seems to follow the winner. I'm leaving my rating at 6. I'd play it again if I was in the right mood.

RATING: 8
There was a time that I really loved this game, but that love has deteriorated a bit, after playing this game with the wrong people. 

If there are people at the table that are there just to make sure one specific person doesn't win, this game will be a pain in the ass. But if you play with well educated people that just play to win themselves, this is a great game.

In other words, in this game what your opponents do to you is more important than what you do to your own armies on the board. This is one of these games where it is better to stay behind in scoring during the first phases of the game, so that you don't stand out. Because once you do, everyone will be moving your armies where you don't want them.

Minus: 2 - 7

RATING: 9
Eternal King Of Area Control Games!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
2005 Comments:

I wanted to elaborate a bit on my comments for El Grande (and the rest of my collection) after reading some of the great comments from several GotW lately (namely Michael Webb aka CortexBomb). 

El Grande is as rich of a gaming experience that you can get. I would classify it as a mid weight to heavy Eurogame takes about 2-3 hours to play. I love the many choices you have to make each turn: which power card to I pick for turn order? Which action card should I take, Should I place men in the Castillo?, Where should I place my caballeros? Which region(s) should I use this card on? Should I use the card first or place my men first? El Grande is actually very easy to learn as the mechanics are very straightforward, yet the game play is so much more involved than the game would first suggest. With only three scoring rounds, you want to be the one in control of the first card selection on one of the at the very minimum, and two of them if at all possible and thus this management of your power cards becomes a meta game inside the main game - and it can create a lot of tension in itself.

I really like the Castillo and the uncertainty of where those Caballeros will end up just prior to scoring and the use of the region disks is one of the coolest things about this game.

El Grande is both tactical and strategic as you have to figure out where your men will be placed as well as how you want to use the various cards available to you. The key to winning is having a presence in as many areas as you possibly can - preferably a lot of 2nd places and a few 1st places if you can manage it. 

Many times as I play this, I will see subtle subversive measures I can take against opponents that don't necessarily look that way on the surface. Im talking about things like playing a card to move some Caballeros (which is the obvious thing to improve a region you are in), but then placing them into regions where they end up tying another player for a position (which doesnt hurt them as they were already in a lower scoring position), but it also drops the other player to a lower scoring position. Often, this goes unnoticed by the other player(s).

This game really only works with 4 or 5 players and a 4 player game is a lot nicer than a 5 player game - where someone will usually get stuck with a card that offers them little or no benefit. A 5 player game is tense from start to finish and I often find myself all knotted up inside when I'm playing a real close 5 player game.

The many expansions to the game each add a new way to play and I've enjoyed using them all at different times. I'll be adding seperate reviews for them under their own listings.

I also have to say how much I enjoy the artwork and components of the game. The board could easily be framed and places on a wall and the Castillo is a unique addition to the game.

El Grande is tense, very engrossing, and will keep you thinking the entire time you are playing. It's very satisfying when you win as you feel like you really accomplished something instead of just being at the lucky end of some die rolls. 

...[b] Abstract [/b]...______[]____...[b]Themed [/b].....
.........[b] Luck [/b]...________[]__...[b] Skill [/b]...........
......[b] Simple [/b]..._______[]___...[b] Complex [/b]...
..[b] Strategic [/b]..._____[]_____...[b] Tactical [/b]....
....[b] Friendly [/b]..._______[]___...[b] Cutthroat [/b]..
.......[b] Fiddly [/b]...________[]__...[b] Elegant [/b].....

Rules: 9
Fun Factor: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Great Area control game. Each turn you manage to send your Caballeros to the different provinces in order to gain control of them. You can not plan in advance but you can take the best option each turn to consolidate your positions and expand your influence. 
As opposite to other euros, you have to follow very carefully what other players are doing in order to select what's the best option for you. Will you recruit and send a lot of Caballeros to the provinces or will you sacrifice numbers for mobility or the ability to punish other players in order to clear your path to the victory?
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Grandpappy of area control, still one of the best.

I think the quality of the experience of this game depends mostly on the group you play it with. If your playing with a downer group, its quiet, analytical, and nothing more then just pushing wooden cubes around; with a lively group its a blast to play and watch.

RATING: N/A
Nathalie Rating System: Like it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This game is AWESOME! It is beautiful and the components are all top-notch. As Tom Vasel stated, this game is ELEGANT. The mechanics of this game are extremely interesting and enjoyable. The castillo throws in an ability to surprise your opponents if they lose track of your deposits and a neat way to swoop in and steal points from your opponents. While direct player interaction is low (as opposed to the trading done in Bohnanza... also a fantastic game) there is a high level of player influence. The game mechanics offer tough choices of: how many caballeros do I want to add to my court? how many caballeros do I want to add to the board? do I want to invest any caballeros in the castillo? do I want to overbid or underbid my opponent in selecting cards that will allow me to play earlier or later? do I want to move the king to increase my score, prevent my opponent from adding caballeros to neighboring provinces, or prevent my opponent from getting those extra points? Bottom line: LOTS OF STRATEGIC OPTIONS AND TOUGH DECISIONS MIXED WITH BEAUTIFUL COMPONENTS AND RELATIVELY EASY GAMEPLAY MAKE THIS GAME A MUST-HAVE!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
An obvious euro classic. Great streamline gameplay and deep strategy without burning out your brain ;)

RATING: 7
El Grande is a gang up on the leader game. If you're ahead after the first scoring round, you probably won't be after the second. I think your best bet is to secure your home region while scoring a bunch of second places in other regions. Hang back in the middle of the pack for the first scoring round while keeping your options open. Then begin to make your move in the second scoring round while no one is paying attention to you.

RATING: 9
A very good game in which the only thing that irritates me is the Last-Person-Goes-First in card play as it seems very easy for someone to be stuck at the back. You played last in the previous round, therefore you have the disadvantage of going first and not getting a chance to see what card value others play. This really sucks. Later games have come up with much better bidding mechanics than this, so I can't complain too much as El Grande introduced so much to board gaming. Apart from that one fault, I think it's still fresh and inspiring.

RATING: 7.45
Area dominance game with light, sleek and aesthetic rules and mechanics. Auction system that actually works and feels as a natural and correct part of the game mechanics design. Good flow of play. Quick start with tendency to slow down as game progresses. Medium--range quicksand for AP-prone types. Solid, slightly overrated, and failing slightly on the side of dry mathematics. 

For gamers less strategically inclined or demanding a lighter or more thematically lurid area control game Smallworld is an alternative that shares a light version of similar game mechanics but with the same session times.

RATING: 8
Game in a Nutshell: Basic area-majority game that gets spiced up with a power card type auction for turn order and action cards that allow special events on every players turn.

Played as: 4 player

Played with: Base game only.

Pros: Great execution in game design were simple rules meet good player interaction. Some action cards are just plain brilliant like secretly selecting territories to score and not scoring territories selected by multiple people.

Cons: It's a shame it supposedly only plays well with 4 or 5 people, an area where many other games shine, so it's in a dime a dozen niche. The game won't bring anyone in for its attractiveness.

Other: I'm really excited to try it with five people where I imagine action selection being much harder fought over and scoring regions a bit more tense. Also, I don't see what the big deal is about making sure you get the decennial edition. Apparently all the expansions suck and the base game is so good by itself, why bother?

Best Use: A good 'next step' game for people looking past the usual gateways.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
My #12.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
02/15
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
There are few games that enthrall me like El Grande does. After a game of El Grande, I'll find myself thinking about it again and again for the next couple of days.

The theme is a bit dry and the art a bit dull, but the gameplay is neither. I love it because there is some much interaction between players, but only mildly 'take-that'. There's plenty of room for strategy and tactics, but also enough chance to save it from being too heavy or serious.

This is one of the few games I've seen that still feels fresh and innovative at 20 years old.

Don't fall for the common myth that the game is strictly a 5 player affair. The game is also great at 3 or 4 players. It takes out some of the tension of the power card bidding with fewer than 5 players, but rounds are also significantly faster.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Angol
Big Box Edition,kartyagyaras kartyakkal

RATING: 4
Fun only if strictly 5p, and players are quick thinkers.
There is a huge amount of possibilities each turn, which do not make sense to think longer than a minute about because there are simply too many things your opponents can do to foil your carefully thought out plans. This gives a somewhat chaotic feel to the game, and bogs it down if players are going to analyze everything.
If players are quick, this is still a fun game with plenty of screwage factors and a smash of bluffing involved.

"Can I move the scoreboard from the King's region?"

"No, you can't do anything in the King's region."

"Can I put this scoreboard into the King's region?"

"No, you can't do [i]anything[/i] in the King's region."

"Can I drop my Castillo guys into the King's region?"

"No, you can't do [b]anything[/b] in the King's region."

"The card says I can move all the Caballeros from one region...."

"I'll eat your liver if you even ask."  :zombie::zombie::zombie:

- BGG user DSHStratRat2


"I can't begin to count how many times people have asked me this. When explaining to the rules I say "The king is throwing the biggest, most exclusive party in Spain. When he rolls up the doors close, the bouncers are posted at every entrance, nobody gets in and nobody leaves until he's done.""

- BGG user jaybeethree

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This is a well balanced game. I played it with 2, 3, 4 and 5 players. It always keeps it up. With two it's a more predictable game. Once one of the players falls a bit behind, it is very hard to come back from that if the other plays smart.

The game is simple in it's rules but for the unexperienced player it can takes about 3 round to get the point of it. Cause than you can witness the effect of scoring.
Choices in this game are never easy. You even need to "battle" for the turn order and you can't always go first. Planning is necessary but you can't plan far ahead. There are always unexpected decissions by other players, sometimes in your favor, sometimes not. 

Never will I refuse to play this but it's maybe a bit too abstract for me to score higher than 8. In the end you are just moving cubes. The story works fine as a theme but it's not much more than some nice background story.

RATING: 9
What a clever game. On the surface there is not a lot going on: just your own cubes and a few cards. No resources, money, etc. Each turn you only pull a few levers but each lever turns at least two gears and each choice is actually a balancing act on two, three, even four axes. Really great.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
A thought-provoking area-influence game that feautres lots of player interaction (players can move opponents' pieces at many times, unlike in Louis XIV).  The game focuses around rounds wherein players bid for play order, choose between one of five cards that have various actions, and then place variable numbers of markers in regions of the board (Spain).  The game takes a decent amount of time to play (especially due to the many action cards available), but strikes me as having much replayability due to the large number of action cards available (and how much they influence play).  The game is very tactical, which I like.  I'm not sure whether I prefer Louis XIV (which is somewhat more predictable, at least during each turn) or El Grande (which is more interactive).  Both seem like the would be more fun with experienced players.  Looks like I've got some work to do :)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Best 5p area control game. Good with less, but I'd rather play Chaos in the Old World with 4. Easy rules and great amounts of tactics.

Highly recommended, all self-respecting "german game" players should own this one!

THIS IS NOT FUN AT ALL! Attention Euro designers, games are meant to be fun, not just interesting. Games like these will always be inaccessible and prevent our hobby from growing.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A highly enjoyable euro style game.  The relative strengths of the power and action cards and the number of cabelleros you can move is just fantastic.  If you want to go first in a round, then forget about acquiring any more cabelleros.  If you want to move the all powerful king, then forget about using any of the more useful action cards.

This is simply a great game all around.  If you get a chance to play El Grande, take advantage of the opportunity.

A területfoglalós játékok öregapja.

10-15 évvel ezelőtt valószínűleg 8-9 közötti pontot kapott volna, de lássuk be, azóta eljárt felette az idő.

Ennek ellenére egész jó, szódával elmegy, nem véletlenül lett SdJ díjas anno, de lássuk be: vannak azóta ennél már sokkal jobb (akár csak területfoglalós) játékok is.

Hihetetlen, hogy amikor ez megjelent, még Horn Gyula volt a miniszterelnök, az NB1 8. és 9. helyezett csapatát Csepel SC-nek és a Stadler FC-nek hívták, nem beszélve arról, hogy a Fradiban olyan játékosok fociztak még, mint Telek Manci, Simon Tibi (RIP), Lisztes, Hrutka Jani, Keller Józsi, Kuntics, Kopunovics, Kuznyecov vagy a gólkirály Nyicsenko. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
To me, El Grande is the quintessential 5-player euro. It has very crisp mechanics, amazing player interaction, and even a bit of diplomacy.

Two minor nits which are easy to fix:
1. Don't hide the Castillo. I find game of 'memory' a bit silly since you can simply use mnemonics and count the cubes added in your head. This is feasible since it's the only piece of "hidden" information. Of course, once you have the count you can look at the board and also know exactly how many cubes each player has in the province.

2. The wording on the cards is atrocious - spelling mistakes, sentences cut off, etc. It would be handy to have an errata sheet nearby so nobody is confused over how a card works.

RATING: 7.5
This game is the epitome of excellent euro design - simple and intuitive, while being deep enough to keep things engaging. The downtime between turns was a bit much sometimes, and there was a bit of a runaway leader problem, but otherwise this is an excellent game, and I could see my rating improving with future play. Also, I can see the degree to which it has influenced later games--it's definitely the grandfather of area control.

RATING: N/A
Brad
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Face-to-face, this is a 6. Chances are you'll have someone prone to analysis paralysis, which makes this game take far longer than it needs to be. There's not a whole lot you can consider when it's not your turn, since the board is constantly changing. I don't find the slowdowns to be as bad as with some of Kramer's other games (Tikal, Java), but it's enough that my enjoyment suffers.

The game's okay as a "post-gateway," but don't let the relatively quick initial rules explanation fool you: you have to go back to explanation mode nine more times, once for every new batch of cards. The better pick here, in my opinion, would be Taj Mahal, which is pretty easy to explain and gets shorter the more you play it.

Online play might up it to a 7. As others have stated, there's a lot to consider on your turn, and I like being able to take my time pondering all my options. Even better, other players can do the same thing without aggravating the rest of us with a huge amount of downtime.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Dreamland

This game really blasted us away when we played it for the first time! In general the rules are quite simple but the majority area control management system is so clever that every round becomes a tactical moving of pieces on the board. Also the tower mechanism builds in some uncertainty in this classic board game.

RATING: 8.5
El Grande hat schon einige Jahre auf dem Buckel, tatsächlich zählt es fürmich aber noch immerzu einem der besten Are-Control Spiele überhaupt. Die Spieler übernehmen die Rolle von spanischen Lords im Mittelalter und versuchen die Kontrolle über einzelne Gebiete zu erlangen. Aber auch der Einfluss des Königs ist nicht zu unterschätzen und so muss dieser geschickt manipuliert werden. Jeder Spieler hat außerdem Zugriff auf Machtkarten, die das spiel beeinflussen können. Ein echter Klassiker!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This is one of the few games that I can lose badly but still have a lot of fun playing. El Grande is almost entirely tactical and sometimes a bit random but the variety of game mechanics mesh together really well to create a "leader bashing" game that has a unique and appealing game arc. Most games I've played result in a surprise leader with lots of suspense throughout the entire game. I'd play this a lot more if I could but it usually only comes out for 5 players, and there are plenty of other good games competing for that niche.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
I really like the mechanism of the secret disk to decide and announce certain moves. The playing of power cards and the action turns created some confusion. We decided to leave the last played power card face up on the table, so at the beginning of the next round we knew that the person with the lowest number in front of them is the first person to play a power card. Modified the game rules on tie breakers. We did not think that in a 3 way tie for first that the fourth place person can still end up with the points based on the scoring table. Instead during a 3 way tie, all 3 players get the second point value and nobody gets the third point value. 

I do not like the fact that the game does not have a tiebreaker for the end of game. Already ran into that situation, we had to search the web for tiebreaker options.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
I enjoy playing El Grande, but my brain doesn't latch on to multiplayer area control games in the same way that it does to some other, less chaotic, genres.  Or perhaps I'm just bothered by the necessity of lying low to prevent getting dogpiled; it seems as though whenever *I* make a big power play the whole table turns against me for a while, whereas when anybody else makes a big power play they take a turn's-worth of flak from somebody and then it's back to business as usual.

Also I have an irrational hatred of the veto card.  Either I dance too far out of optimal in an attempt to get my special action not vetoed, or I don't, and it's vetoed (for some reason, in the couple of games when it's come up, nobody *else* has ever had their special action vetoed).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
This definitely feels like the Settlers of Catan of area control games. It has that timeless feel to it, and it does a good job of making it all about the area control without feeling too dry and abstract. Ultimately, however, I would rather just play Dominant Species. DS is an evolution of El Grande, and I appreciate it more for its thematic integration. I would happily play this anytime though.

UPDATE: The runaway leader problem and the length are both big detractors for me when it comes to El Grande. I'll still play, but I think age is finally starting to catch up to this one.

Still a better version than the new big box one from Z-Man.

RATING: 8.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Well, after playing this at Drews house (Drew1365) I left basically with my jaw on the floor and totally amazed.  This one is a must.   I knew I wanted to go out and get it.  So I checked the internet.  O.K, this is not going to be easy, I kept on getting "Out of Stock or Out of Print".  Then I used this website and found a copy on ebay.  What luck for me, because there was one for sale in the Twin Cities area, and my sister in law lives there.  A few phone calls later, and its mine!

Shes going to bring it up to me on 8/11/07 when she picks up her son.  

I just love the 2 basic elements of the game, bidding and territory control.  Its like any bidding card game (pinochole, bridge, smear, etc) combined with risk, which is right up my alley.  The best thing about this game is that its 100 times better than risk.  

I'm looking forward to play it soon, when it arrives, and I don't ever forsee this game collecting much dust.  A solid staple for any gamer and I'm gald to have this in my collection. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Excellent area control game. Great bidding mechanism. Difficult and interesting choices from start to finish. The more players the better with 5 being optimal as it makes bidding even more interesting and tactical. 

Overall just a brilliant game that's really simple in concept... but the special actions each round require some thought and conservation in how you bid your power cards throughout the game. 

The only thing that keeps me from rating this a 9+ is that it's a bit dry. Now I love the tactical play of this game but you can easily strip out any theme and it comes down to pushing and flicking cubes around the board. That's both the game's strength (simplicity) and a weakness (basically a painted on theme).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
A classic introductory game with the reputation comparable to Settlers that fulfills all expectations. Simple and elegant mechanisms where the players compete for area majority by moving caballeros back and forth. The bidding for action cards and hidden placements in the Castillo adds just enough unpredictability. Potentially a kingmaker risk but with all players competing for victory, this shouldn't be a problem. The game could have been a bit shorter as the gameplay gets repetitive in the long run.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Elegant design and smooth gameplay make El Grande my favorite game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I suspect that the rating for El Grande is actually lower than what it will eventually be, because El Grande is almost a forgotten game in my group.  Because it has been around for so long, it is often passed over for newer acquisitions, even though it hasn't been played a great deal.  Still, it only takes a game or two to be impressed by the amazing design of El Grande.  The game is fun and strategic, and to me it represents the pinnacle of streamlined design.  Every element plays several roles, and this forces you to make tough decisions whenever you choose to act.

In practice, the game can work out to be a little less elegant than it reads, but it is still very fun, and I expect it to become even more rewarding with additional plays.  This is one of the best designs in my opinion, and the result is a very good game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
classic game, doesn't get played as much as it deserves.

RATING: 9

RATING: 10
Outstanding. Game after game you keep discovering many different options during gameplay.  The tactical factor within this game is so deep, because you have to make decisions on the fly at every moment. I've been trying the expansions, but for sure, the original game is the master piece of all. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Overall comment: a challenging game to weigh your options in because everything that goes on is subtle, the game is much more interesting with more players (at least 4). The basics are quick to pick up but the actions that seem to have little effect with few players are potentially dangerous with more.

Ratings:
Initial: 10 (comes with all of the expansions and even has a game walkthrough which makes the game easier to learn)
Family: 7 (not requested much anymore)
Game group: 8 (this is just starting to create a buzz in the group eventhough I have had the game for awhile)
AP rating: 5 (unfortunately this can run high with some players and this severely detracts from the play)
Solo play: 8 (it is good and offers an slightly different approach to the game - I like it with the expansions for the variety)

When purchased: 2006
Recommended expansions: Decennial edition has all of them in it - yes
Age range: 8+
Luck factor(1-10high): 3 (when the new options are flipped the first player can get an advantage in games with fewer players)

Reason purchased: Geek and months of geek analysis

Pros: Simple mechanics and easy to understand gameplay, lots of tough choices especially with 4 or more players, game scores are close and the castillo can have a devastating affect.
Cons: AP in some players(one of the reasons the decision to buy was so tough), veteran players unwilling to play any of the expansions(the game has little variety otherwise)

Recommendation: An excellent buy because of what you get in the package. The base game is a good start and all of the extras give the game longevity.  It may be tough for some newer players to grasp but a couple plays will get them past that
Replay rating: Above average(with expansions); Average(without)
Game value(plays/cost ratio): Above average (solo play has improved this by giving the game a different strategy which improves overall skill and no AP(a definite +))

RATING: 7
One of the first Eurogame area control games I played: move units from playing area to holding area, from holding area to board through bidding cards. King marker moves around to limit where units may go and a tower (castillo) can contain units as well.  Fun, expansion cards were fun also. Lots of things to agonize over, such as the Castillo, overloading an area, and parachuting a different scoreboard into an area.

RATING: 7
Heard this is similar to Hansa Teutonica, and that El Grande was sleek and elegant while maintaining high depth and easy access. I really want to try this, though only the big box edition is available. Also supposedly best area majority game on the market.

Biggest issue is semi memory aspect of remembering whats inside the castillo. I could play as open info but that would change the core of the game, and I dislike variants and rule changes if theyre unofficial/extensively playtested and statiscally proven/balanced.

Played and extremely streamlined with fast setup and deep play. A tiny bit of bash the leader and memory which I dislike but I found the game intuitively good and didnt strongly feel downtime, and I could see a lot of replay too. Tiny bit of catchup problem, the inexperienced played was behind about 30 points and didnt have a chance midway through. If only it was unknown who was in the lead.

RATING: 4
I don't understand why some people call this game elegant. There are too many different cards with many exceptions that always make the game slow down. Also those points in each area just look very random. The game is too long for what it is.

RATING: 9
Strategic masterpiece
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I believe this game is the end-all be-all of area majority games.  Every player will first play a card that determines how many pieces they bring from their stock to the ready position and determines the turn order for the round.  After this, in turn order, everyone takes an action card that not only gives them a special action for the round, but also determines how many of their pieces can be brought from their ready area, onto the board.

One of the problems with a game like this is that it can breed 'ganging-up' on people, which is usually not too fun for the one getting ganged up on.  Sometimes it is inevitable that the person in the lead will get picked on, but it is something that you cannot help in an area majority game.  Thankfully, with clever planning and card-play the game does try to balance itself and really is a joy to play.

I really love this game, the only thing keeping it from staying at a 9, for me is the ganging up problem.  I know this can not be helped, but it is a hindrance to an otherwise great, balanced, area majority game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

On loan from the Cairo Foundation.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Subtitle "subtle strategy game" suits it. Only played once, and I want to play so many times that I can play the King and Intrigue expansion. The box for this game is a bit oversize.
-----------
On a second play, my impression is that this game works very differently from other games. I feel as a player you cede a great deal of control to your opponents; whom they decide to vie with can determine whether you will be locked into a tough war of attrition or if you can fly under the radar to victory. There's a lot of thinking and double-thinking, and if you guess wrong (for example, on where to send your caballeros out of the castillo), it can sink your game early on. There's a bewildering array of options for any given action, and it's almost as though each move you make you are playing kingmaker. It should move more quickly than it does, but the bewildering array of options each turn really makes it difficult to figure out what to do.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
[size=9][b][c]OVERALL REVIEW:     :star::star::star::star::star:[/c][/b][/size]
[size=8]Beautifully produced with unique game mechanics, when it was released twenty years ago. Minimal setup and good game length. A really tight majority control game that can shift balance every scoring period.
[color=green]My favorite area/majority control game.[/color][/size]

[size=9][c]RULES SIMPLICITY:   :star::star::halfstar::nostar::nostar:[/c]
[size=8]It takes a round, then turn order and scoring is intuitive[/size]
[c]QUICK SETUP:        :star::star::star::star::nostar:[/c]
[size=8]Minimal setup to distribute player pieces[/size]
[c]SHORT GAME LENGTH:  :star::star::halfstar::nostar::nostar:[/c]
[size=8]Depending on players, ninety+ minutes[/size]
[c]MAXIMUM STRATEGY:   :star::star::star::star::star:[/c]
[size=8]Turn order bids affect recruitment and turn actions affect deployment[/size]
[c]MINIMUM LUCK:       :star::star::halfstar::nostar::nostar:[/c]
[size=8]Initial placement, and randomly drawn actions (to choose from)[/size]
[c]PLAYER INTERACTION: :star::star::star::star::star:[/c]
[size=8]Every move is a direct action for and/or against other players control[/size]
[c]COMPONENT QUALITY:  :star::star::star::star::star:[/c]
[size=8]Beautiful artwork and high quality components.[/size]
[c]THEME INTEGRATION:  :star::star::star::star::star:[/c]
[size=8]You feel like the Grande ordering your caballeros, and hosting the King[/size]
[c]REPLAYABILITY:      :star::star::star::star::star:[/c]
[size=8]Different initial placement, random action cards, and scaling unit placement keep it fresh[/size]

[b][c]BEST WITH:[/c][/b]
[size=8]5 players[/size]

[b][c]MY PLAYS:[/c][/b]
[size=8]in-person with 4,5 players[/size][/size]

Beautiful design:

[ImageID=2056918 small]

El Grande was released in 1995, and introduced me to some game mechanics for the first time. (A) Players bid for ascending turn order every turn by choosing from cards that determine descending caballero recruitment. (B) Players choose their turn action from a limited pool of randomly drawn cards. (C) Action cards to choose from grant ascending special abilities and determine descending caballero deployment. (D) A player can move the King to freeze activity in a territory for the duration of a turn. (E) One scoring territory is "hidden" by use of the Castillo tower. (F) Some actions require a disc that players use to secretly choose a territory. (G) Tie breakers get a penalty during scoring. 

The game play feels very tight and you can never do everything that you want to do on a single turn. Player actions have built in advantages and disadvantages. During turn order bidding, a player might choose to be first or second in turn order, but receive the fewest caballeros from the supply. An action card may provide a powerful special ability for that turn, but the player can only deploy the smallest amount of caballeros to the board. If a player ties another player's control in a territory, both players split points of the next lower scoring value. A player may have control in a territory and then suddenly have that territory penalized by a mobile scoreboard activated by another player. Players may be scheming in a territory and suddenly the King arrives and all activity ceases in that territory for the turn - but the King is not going to stay and players scramble in that territory immediately when he leaves.

[color=#3388cc][b]Play with or without expansion?[/b][/color]

The game is best with five players, in my opinion, as turn order bidding is competitive, all territories are active, and all action cards are used per turn. The Grandissimo expansion adds another set of cards so that in a five player game, the fifth player on a turn has a choice between two actions. The expansion feels empowering and balancing, but it is not necessary. It can make the game longer, as the fifth player might spend time contemplating the choice of the last two cards. I have played with and without, and definitely would play without the expansion when teaching the game the first time. Additional expansions include a replacement for the action and bidding cards, and another expansion that adds a new territory and ships. 

El Grande is one of the oldest games in the top rankings at BGG, and it deserves the accolades. It is beautifully produced, with extremely streamlined game play.

[color=#3388cc][b]Pimp it?[/b][/color]

This is one game that I have never considered pimping out. It is beautiful as-is. I suppose one could replace all the caballeros, grande, and king with miniatures, so long as a dozen units can fit into a territory.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Difficult area control game. With the way the cards are, you need to keep track of what other people's plans are. You might want to take a card just to prevent someone else from getting it. Seems to require people to work together to reign in the leader. Have to always be aware of the board position of the other players, and not just the score.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
I'm aware my opinion about this game is one of a kind, but I don't enjoy playing it, even if I value how great and innovative it was in its era. I would have probably loved it back then, but now the market offers much better games.
I dislike
-> Even if you play your best game, all your rivals need to take you down is one turn if they ally against you (and that's what would certainly happen if you play your best game). You could argue that you have to hide your chances by not doing your best, but I don't enjoy games that encourage you to perform bad.
-> The first turns are not that important. Nobody will want to get a big lead over the others and they become very boring. They make the game unnecesarily longer.
-> The game is too chaotic.
-> The game promotes AP on the last turns, and the possibilities are endless when there are players deploying after you.
-> Many games will end with someone being kingmaker.

2 player games are much better (you don't have to bluff), but are too dependant on luck, especially with the cards you get to choose in the last turns.

RATING: 9
The area control game. There is just the right amount of control & chaos to make El Grande a modern classic. It can get quite nasty because you can do powerful moves that affect other players game a lot. It's not for those who prefer low-confrontational games. There certainly is hit-the-leader going on but you cannot do too much harm to anyone (and they usually have a chance to prevent things - but it's costly).
Works with both gamers and non-gamers and is excellent either way. Seems best with a full table of 5 players but very good with 4 players too.

RATING: 10
The quintessential German style game. RATING: 9
E' il gioco di maggioranze per eccellenza, forse il primo di questo genere. Meccaniche e regole abbastanza semplici permettono a questo piccolo capolavoro di essere facilmente appreso già dalla prima/seconda partita. Nove turni di gioco per guadagnare la supremazia nelle regioni della Spagna. Un gioco strategico che necessita di una buona programmazione, la grande interazione però rende complesso il tutto. Non esiste una versione italiana del gioco, ma questo non dovrebbe creare problemi perché il poco testo lo si trova solo sulle carte pubbliche. El Grande è un gioco per 5 giocatori, trovo che in 4, o addirittura in 3, perda molto del fascino e anche un po' di profondità strategica. Quasi assente la fortuna mentre è utile un po' di memoria per i caballeros mandati nel Castillo. Una partita dura circa 1h30', massimo 2. Un gioco che consiglio senza dubbi, anche se comincia a far sentire i suoi anni (quasi vent'anni). Tra i difetti che gli vengono attribuiti si parla di tempi morti e troppa attenzione che rende il gioco bello ma non divertente. Io lo trovo semplicemente tosto! Nel 2015 è stata annunciata una nuova riedizione.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Highly influential and thinky area control, and deservedly resident in the pantheon of all-time greats. The flexibility in the turn positioning is key to this game, whatever anyone else would have you think. The design as a whole stands up excellently alongside all those lesser games that have tried to subvert it. My big issue with the game is a slight excess of luck, but this is more easily cured with a 'see what's coming up' house-rule for the action cards.

RATING: 10
[b]El Grande[/b] was received in a trade (10/28/14). [i]This is the Decennial Edition.[/i]

[COLOR=#FF0000]A year later... thoughts and rating (10):[/COLOR]

[i]It only took one play for El Grande to get it's hooks into me and it has since become a top 3 game for me. El Grande provides players with a very streamlined set of rules that offer an amazing amount of choice in how you decide to go about playing the game. Each choice you make has lasting effects which ultimately leads to the "I can't believe what just happened" moment.

My favorite game mechanics found in El Grande:

The Castille: offers you an opportunity to not only score points for majority but also stock pile some cubes to be placed on the board in a location you choose in secret using the territory wheel.

Territory Selection Wheel: Anytime players need to choose a location in secret (due to cards selected or placing cubes from the Castille) you use this wheel. Trying to take into account what your opponents will due versus what your priorities are lead to some tense and extremely fun decisions.

The King: When someone decides to move the King it influences everyone's decisions because cubes can't be placed in the same territory as the King. On top of that cubes can only be placed in territories adjacent to the King. This is usually one of the most contested cards in the game and deciding when to play a power card that will insure you get to select the King becomes a critical choice in the game.

This is a desert island game for me, it is an elegant and easy to understand set of rules that give players complete control over how the game plays out without bogging down in a mire of complex rules and exceptions. Most importantly it is also a game that I was able to teach to my family with ease and a game they can play quite well (especially my older daughter).[/i]

 [COLOR=#FF0000]Initial thoughts and rating (10):[/COLOR]

[i]- Elegant! This game has such a simple rule set, yet there is so much depth and strategy to explore.
- Plays great with 3, 4 and 5.
- A lot of player interaction, this is not multiplayer solitaire.
- My favorite mechanic is secretly selecting a territory to place/move guys using the dial, there are a lot of memorable moments created because of this (Especially when it comes to the Castillo).
- Great family game, my 9 year old daughter has picked up this game quickly because the rules are so simple.
- For a 20 year old game it still looks good, especially the Castillo.[/i]

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
My co-worker's loss is my gain.  I recently discovered a couple of guys at work play Puerto Rico together and we discussed games.  One had bought the Decennial Edition of El Grande a couple months ago and didn't like it.  He and his family couldn't figure out the rules.  I traded him family-friendly Ticket to Ride for a week while we got this.  I think part of my buddy's problem was that all of the extra pieces for the expansions are packed into the same featureless square in the box along with the normal game.  It's totally chaotic and overstuffed.  I repacked the pieces in individual baggies and stuck the expansions underneath--haven't gotten to those yet--and offered to teach him the game.  He declined.  He is going to buy Ticket to Ride instead and offered to sell me this at 60% of the price he paid because the FLGS won't let him return it.  Well, if you're twisting my arm... =)  Sweet deal for us!

We love it!  This is the game Tikal wishes it was.  We also thought it much more straight-forward than Puerto Rico.  

Edit: WOW....I'd read it here, but it is incredibly MUCH better with 4 or 5 people.  FUN!  This game is only improving.  It's the new 10 on my list.

RATING: 9.7
We played our first game of El Grande tonight. What a blast! Even though we did the sample game and read the rules often for clarification (adding a lot of time to the gaming session), we all had a great time. One of the best games I have ever played! A great core gaming mechanism, great components and very entertaining.  We have the expansion and the free set of cards and plan on playing them soon. I can see why so many people love the game. I do not award a rate of 10 very often. I very well may come back and upgrade this score to 10 after a few more plays. Dont pass this one up. Get a copy, if at all possible. I listed the minimum optimal players as 3 because I can not see the game having the same "flavor" with 2 players.

RATING: 8
I like the turn order mechanics, and the way you have to acquire cubes in front of you before you can place them. Lots of interesting decisions. 

There can be some AP when the board is getting full.

Play with open tower scoring. If the tower is there, you can still know what's in it by counting cubes, but that slows the game down. Hence remove the tower to improve the game (doing this does NOT give anyone any new information).

RATING: 8
This is one of the games I've spent the most time playing. Always as a 5 player though. There's a satisfying engagement in the valuation of the powers given the current game state, and determining the required bid to secure the card of choice whilst keeping enough bidding power in hand to take advantage of potentially even better situations later in the game. But it's dropped a rating notch or two over the years as area majority games have gradually fallen out of favour with me, largely due to dis-satisfaction with the frequent kingmaking choices required. If you like the genre, this is one of the best though ... as long as you're not playing with analyser paralysers.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
What I liked:
- I think the board was pretty, and the castillo was cool
- It is strategic, and it is tactical, within the chaos (see below).

What I didn't like:
- Area majority, which is a mechanic I tend to strongly dislike.
- Utter chaos. You can't plan ahead at all, because you don't even know what special action you will get until it is your turn. Plus the board can change pretty radically from one turn to the next.
- Long (our 5p learning game was 2.5 hours). For a game this chaotic, 30-45 minutes would be a good length.
- Bash-the-leader and kingmaker problems. Both surfaced in the game I played.

With many games, I can appreciate their strengths even if I don't like them. This is one that I honestly don't understand the insanely high ratings. I also can't figure out how anyone would consider it a "gateway" game.

The weight of 3.1 seems a bit low to me, only because there are SO many options to analyze each turn.

RATING: 10
I love this game.  Great depth, multiple paths to victory, a good mix of known and hidden information, and strong strategic and tactical elements.  I find every game of this we play to be competitive, interesting, and typically a nail-biter.

The one complaint members of my group raise is that the theme is relatively loosely coupled to the mechanics.  One goes so far as to say that "This just wasn't the way things worked in the Spanish court..."  We tell him to shut up and focus on winning, but if you like the theme to be stronger and more reflective of reality, then you'd likely rate this game lower.

RATING: 9
I love it when people are rocking through this game. Not doing an overwhelming amount of table talk (play your own game, people!) and not taking forever in their decisions.  

The experience can definitely vary based on how AP your opponents are and how much table talk they are doing. This can make the game really drag. But if you are playing at fairly rapid pace & people are making their own damn decisions-this is the area control game for me.

I have the Decennial version. Enjoyed both short and long versions, better with long version, though.  Better with 4 than 5. Interesting with just 3.  With 3-its a different game knowing that 2 of the choices are going to be unused.

In May 08, El Grande was our "Game of the Month" (vanilla El Grande, without expansion) and really focused on it-playing it every time we got together. This was at least 5 times. It was a highly excellent and rewarding experience, getting to really know the game. 

Then in June 08 we integrated the expansions, one by one and really had an excellent experience delving into those expansions.

RATING: 5
The area majority system is brilliant and tough, the turn order bidding is perfect and the whole fits together neatly.  

This game has a flaw: too many action cards.   They slow the whole thing down.  It never feels like it flows.  I want to simplify the game. 

Thus my variant: each stack of action cards contains only two cards (chosen at random), except for the king of course, who is solo.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This classic area control game is still the best of its genre.  Bidding for special abilities is balanced by getting your cubes.  Special scoring makes your cubes on the board relevant at all times.  The King and its restrictions on cube placement is simply brilliant.  The Castillo is just icing on the cake.  Nothing to dislike here.

(5+ plays)

RATING: 4
Can't rate this yet after only one play. It has pretty and interesting components. It is the daddy of area control games. It's got a big box. It's highly rated. It's getting older... we'll see. 8/6: okay, after one play, a few solo plays, I just framed the thing and hung it on my wall. Pieces went into a shadow-box. I am going to pass on the decenial version, I just don't think this one will come out much with all the other titles that I have. I would play it if one of my friends insisted. I am rating it a 5 based on strict definition of ratings. 2005, put on wall as art.

2014: Mark Johnson has a really interesting take on this game, which I heard on his Top 100 podcast series (which I HIGHLY RECOMMEND). I probably missed the time when this game would have appealed to me - between 1995 and 2000.

With Puerto Rico and T&E. and Princes of Florence out around this time, I can't see why El Grande would be a big deal. Granted, it's area control. I know. But they are better games. El Grande felt to me, and I think Mark J. validated this for me, like it was all about being in 2nd place, and about timing.

That's SO over now as a mechanic. It was cool for a few years in the late 1990's. No one does this anymore.

TRY July/05: Well, this is pretty good!  I like the multi-purpose bids & the variability of the actions available.  Lots of good little things. RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
A bit too samey.

I like area scoring as a mechanic among others in a game. But El Grande has nothing else to offer. Granted - the action cards brings some variety, but in practice they have a lesser impact on the game than I first excpected.

I know EG was first to explore area majority in this way. But this mechanic is certainly no novelty these days and El Grande just feels a bit dated.

Pros:
Easy to pick up. Rulewise its much easier than the weight on BGG suggest. Gameplay could be challanging though, it should be able to give AP-prone players head ace calculating optimal moves.

The Castillo and the secret discs are really cool!

Love the crude old school-euro artwork.

Verdict: I like it better when area scoring is just one scoring element among others in a game (AOEIII, Rise of Empires, Struggle of empires...). Manhattan is vaguely reminiscent to El Grande and is also only about majority, but the former is brisker, meaner and plays much faster.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 1
I feel only one thing while playing this game: hatred
...towards the game.

I hate the downtime, when you have to wait scratching your hair, unable to plan anything because the other players' choices will affect you so greatly. 
The game art looks rather depressing and just guess who had to sit behind of THE GREAT CASTILLO (or what was its name..) trying to see the game board over it.
And that Castillo scoring? Idiotic factor, bad idea forged into a worthless game component.

A game totally worth its rating! I won't give 1 since I'm pretty hopeful that there is something worse than this game.

Edit: Nothing worse found after over 300 different games played. This is an achievement of a sort. :)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
All about region control -- you get points for having the most cabarellos in each region during the scoring round. Extra points are given for having the most in your home region or the region where the king is visiting. Very simple mechanics, but fun.

This is definitely a game that will improve with more players.

RATING: 9
(01/18)

El Grande is the definitive area majority game, it is a really fun game, simple mechanics but great depth, it's been more than 20 years and it is still exciting. 

The Tower concept is soooo good, you have to be really concentrated to remember how many players the other player have in there, but then the game happens, and you have to pick a card with a number... "OH SH*T! that number made me forget how many meeples did the other guy put inside the tower... how many did I have?"

It is an amazing game.

Only complaint I have is that the big box isn't neccesary, I get it, it's called El Grande, but that makes it more difficult to bring to other houses to play.

I feel this one would still be exciting in 20 more years

RATING: 10
It's GREAT!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
El Grande is almost perfect. The auction system takes care of the luck factor with card drawing in a way that adds an additional layer of strategy. Managing of your hand, court, and provinces ensures a constant struggle that provides for a great table wide feeling of tension throughout the game. Every game has a different flavor depending on how players play their auction cards. Downtime is minimal because someone is always picking up ground in one of your provinces forcing you to think how to counter. It does experience the kingmaker problem at times and I suggest making rules beforehand to deal with it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Not sure what makes this game so good. I do like area control, so that is definitely part of it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Great design. Gets better with more players. I do feel that it's somewhat overrated. Often it's just a bunch of players simply trying to put as many cubes as possible on the board, and there is no real strategy, nor many clever tactical moves.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
I believe this game really needs 5 players to at least provide tense competition of resources. But the problems start. Firstly to play well you need to know the other 44 action cards to at least make an informed decision as to evaluate effectively which power card to play. Not only that, you need to number crunch what the displayed cards are worth for the other players. So the pace is affected, with text on the action cards slowing it some more. Then once you executed your move, it's a waiting game as really you have nothing to plan as you really can't anticipate what the next four action cards to be displayed will be. All that mental exercise just to have your cabelleros moved by someones action card. When it comes to scoring, the highlight is dialling up to deploy your cabelleros from the castillo to the dialled region. Then it's the longwinded scoring of majorities. Unless you love number crunching, it's quite a dull experience.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This was one of the big Euros that I felt I had to try when getting into the hobby (just after Carcassonne, Settlers, Puerto Rico and Power Grid), but I never quite warmed to it. It gets props as the first of many Euro cubes-on-a-map area-control games (correct me if I'm wrong) but I prefer several of the games that have followed and refined that mechanic: San Marco, King of Siam, Tammany Hall for example. 

I think that's mainly down to the lack of constraints in El Grande. The King provides some limitation on what you can do on your turn, but there are so many special powers coming into play that it's almost impossible to predict what other players will do. This means the game tends towards the meta (bash the leader etc.) rather than mechanics-driven. Another factor is chaos: so much can happen between your turns that it feels almost entirely tactical, aside from the rather obvious hand management around playing your bidding cards. I do think the Castillo is a fantastic game component though. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

A really brilliant area control game with lots of expansions and variants.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
There are nine turns in a game of El Grande.  The player with the most points wins.  A round of turns consists of players bidding cards for the right to go first.  Low number cards allow players to ready more Caballeros to place on the board.  Then, in turn order, players choose one of five action cards.  The weaker actions allow more Caballeros to actually be placed on the board.  Every three turns a scoring round takes place.  Players get points based on how many Caballeros they have in the various regions of Spain relative to the other players.

There's some interesting elements that take this superficially dry approach and inject it full of excitment and fun.  For example Caballeros can be placed into the Castillo and then players can secretly deploy them just prior to scoring.  The available action cards vary from turn to turn and from game to game making each game different.  The timing of when to take control of the king and how to funnel your Caballeros onto the the board is also a fun consideration.  The more I play this game the more I like it.  There's plenty of tactical manouvering.  Additionally there's bluffing and second guessing your opponents.  I find more and more that games that require me to predict what my opponents will do provide the best kind of player interaction paricularly if they require players to form short term alliances.  El Grande has these qualities.  

Certain regions provide many more points than others yet fighting too hard over the point-rich regions can cost you in the long run.  Competition is fierce and back stabbing opprotunities abound.

At first the action cards seemed fiddly, but now we make sure to explain them clearly at the beginning of each round if there are any new players.  I find it important to focus on "short term" strategy, i.e. make a plan for the next three turns.  Long term strategy comes in to play with how you ration your bidding cards and route Caballeros to the board.

I should probably note that we always play the variant were turn order is determined from high power card to low power card rather than in clock-wise order from the highest power card.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.25
It was a surprising good game, even though the length is short.

RATING: 9
I love area control but I'm not a fan of the swings that come with it.  In El Grande, it's a beautiful thing with how much control you have.  From knowing when to play what turn order card to the Castile...it's a controlled area control game that deserves it's place in board game history.  If you like area control and more Euro style games : buy this!

RATING: 10

Facile da spiegare e con assenza quasi totale del fattore fortuna ma è utile un po’ di memoria. L'ambientazione è fasulla (cavalieri rappresentati da cubetti improbabili), ma il materiale piace comunque (la torre è fantastica e il tabellone ha un non so che di intrigante). L'interazione è molto alta. Si fanno parecchie bastardate, le proprie scelte dipendono SEMPRE dal comportamento altrui e viceversa. Spiel des Jahres... 1996.

RATING: 8.5
I finally got to play this at BGG Con '08 and I loved it!  It wasn't nearly as complicated as I thought it might be and I was on the edge of my seat pretty much the entire time.  

My only (two) complaint was the card that got rid of everyones pool of available guys to place, which slowed things down considerably and the inherent value of being the last person to bid isn't really balanced out or accounted for in any way.  What I mean is, when you are last to bid, it isn't through really any effort on your part, but you have the advantage of full bidding knowledge.  It was often the last bidder who got the highest bid when there wasn't a "grab" for the high bid, and so they would get to place the king for a bid of like 7.

Anyways, that being said, I really loved the game, it felt like a really tight, good design.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This is the original game. Now included with all expansions so far (2016) stuffed in to one big box. 

Rules are quite simple each round you bid for player order. In your turn you move some caballero's on the board and execute a special action that almost always interfere's with the plans of the other players. In this way you try to get majorities is as much regions as possible to score points.

Lots of player interaction which makes detailed planning ahead impossible, in stead try to keep as much options open.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

(+) Not very luck-dependant
(+) Small strategically played actions can have huge impact
(+) A lot of replay-value
(+) One of the best area-control games I know

(-) Theme not up to today's game standards

Approx gametime: 20 - 25 min / player

RATING: 7
http://www.ronkkonen.com/boardgames.html#Grande
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
The theme of El Grande is scrambling over others.  The decisions are almost always of the flavor of, "if I do this, I get
lots of points!  Also, that really sticks it to Player X."  Sometimes it's the other way around.  What makes El Grande so neat is that it's able to take this wonderful theme and find many of its variations--you can stick it to others through analysis, through careful management, through rotten luck, and through psychological wiliness.  What other game do you hear people saying "Noooooooooooo...don't do that..." for
so many reasons?  It's not the fairest game, but it's a game with a distinct flavor that I find delicious.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
NL

OMSCHRIJVING: Strategisch area-control-spel. Elke speler tracht zoveel mogelijk invloed uit te bouwen in de verschillende provincies van het middeleeuwse Spanje, door zijn caballero's (= invloedrijke adel) uit te sturen om zo overal een politieke meerderheid te bekomen.

--> 2 tot 5 spelers

RATING: 8

Turn order, resource management and bidding each present in a streamlined and easy-to-understand way. This is not only great fun, it is a fine example of the way to implement a good-weight game while minimizing rules.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
01-03-2015. Rated after 2 plays. Granddad of the area-control genre I think, in which you score points based on how many guys you have in a certain area of Spain. Areas award several players a fixed amount of VPs based on how many dudes each player has in the area. In addition, you have the Castillo. Its a special location that gives VPs, but in addition allows you to place the guys you put into the Castillo into another region in order to get VPs from that region also. 

Each turn you choose a card with a placement number and a number of cubes you get from the supply. Then you can choose one of the action cards, that and get a number of guys to place based on that card from your supply to your board and give you a special scoring or special ability. The last player may play the first card in the next round. There are 3 scoring rounds in the game.

Game is a bit too simple for my tastes.. but certainly no bad game. I do wonder if it's still as exceptionally good as some people made it out to be (once). Might be replaced by small world (for many people?), since SW adds variable player powers - well race powers-. I think I like this game better than SW personally, since SW really doesn't have more than area control.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Fun but a bit to simple mechanics. Age shows
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
I am beginning to like area control games a lot. So I figured I should trade for this without having played it since it is well received and area control.

Enjoyed the game a lot even though we made some mistakes with the rules in our first play.

I swear every game that I play where someone (myself included) is teaching it based off of reading the rules and never having played it we always make at least one mistake with the rules.

In any case, the game still went very smoothly and everyone seemed to enjoy it. I can't wait to play again. I think I'll play it once more with the base game and then add the expansions.

RATING: 9
Certainly a classic that is deserving of all the praise it receives. The Grandfather of all area control with some variable turn order. Tons of depth and re-playability to be found here. Unfortunately, my first game was a bit miserable due to a certain card, unbeknownst to me, that wiped my court. Had to learn the hard way that playing two low power cards back to back can be a big gamble. Spent the rest of the game floundering in last place trying to counteract the effect of that nasty card. Most people would write off a game that can do a player in by turn 2 or 3, but I see the brilliance within, and I look forward to giving this game another attempt.

RATING: 8.5
Best area control game I've played so far.  Game mechanics of the king and castillo are truly special.

I'm not a fan of some of the card choices, like the veto card for example, and I think the rules should say those who played the lowest power card goes 1st next round, then 2nd lowest goes 2nd and so on (instead of clockwise order from lowest power card played) but I just deal with the veto cards and can easily make a house rule change.

Has that "classic" feel to it.

RATING: 8.5
--Jan2005-- Played enough now to realize I really like this game!  First couple times the volume of data was overwhelming, and I succumbed to an unfortunate degree of analysis paralysis.  But it seems now that one really needs to approach the game as a downhill skiier:  go for it with confidence; one might crash and burn, but it'll be a whole lot more fun than approaching the experience timidly.

--Mar2009-- And, for what little it's worth, the power cards from King&Intrigue are in my opinion an improvement.

RATING: 9
When it comes to true Euro-games, I don't think there is a finer area-control title out there.  The game has never been static for me.  I always seem to be defending my lead or trying to claw at the distance between me and the leader.  I suppose there is a bit of 'bash-the-leader,' but I feel that hidding your moves and ambushing your opponents is integral to the game.I have often wonder if El Grande wouldn't have made a better Game of Thrones title.

RATING: 7.5
Another classic work, area control. El Grande is about the aristocracy in Spain in the 15th Century. This game contains a lot of strategies, relying on your hand management, card selection, and even diplomacy. Two things I do not like this otherwise excellent game: memorizing the Castillo and starting your shameless diplomatic negotiation. I believe there are many treasures to dig out of this game, other than the treasurous Rule of Two and Rule of Three (two very universial Golden Rules applicable to almost every game).

RATING: 8
Based on two plays (I won both): very interesting and complex game, though I can't help but compare it to San Marco, which I played first. I really like San Marco's divide/choose mechanism, which seems to add an element of tension that I did not find in the bidding-for-turn-order aspect of El Grande. But el Grande has a lot going on - you have to balance offensive and defensive moves, and must decide when it's best to go first, and when it's best to go last. I think that balancing all those aspects is the key to winning this game - and that, to me, makes a game enjoyable and re-playable. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
A very original design when it went out, it is the father of many games as [i][url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/game/1041]San Marco[/url][/i], [i][url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/game/18258]Mission: Red Planet[/url][/i] and [i][url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/game/12477]Bootleggers[/url][/i], among others that share the majority mechanic.  It is one of the best of Kramer's games and the probably the best of Ulrich's.  Nevertheless I normally don't like much their designs, with [i][url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/boardgame/93]El Grande[/url][/i] they did a good job.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
The paradigm of area-of-control, players bid for player order to place "caballeros" in various areas of Spain, which grant you points if you have more in any given region.  Higher bid=less pieces to control, but better chance at choosing the action you need or want to prevent.  The game relies on careful timing, since scoring is pre-determined at certain intervals.  This game has simple rules, almost to a fault, but don't be fooled; the strategy of what action to select is quite deep.  It's best for at least 4, and preferably 5, players.  Anything less gives little incentive to bid high, since there are many options per player to fall back on.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Got this one from a silent auction.  It's actually the decennial edition with the expansions.  Not a bad game, I like the role selection aspects and placement issues.

people's choice 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
First off, this is a game that should be played only with 5 people. Even with 4, I did not like the uncertainty of having one of the cards go unused.

The mechanics of this game are quite clever, and it is one of my favorite area control games, which is not one of my favorite genres.

Doing well in this seems to require two elements: knowing when to fight for big points, and finding small, persistent points that won't attract too much notice. In that respect, I think some of the short-term gain, long term goal decisions at the begging of the game can be quite interesting.

And, the castle is just cool!

RATING: 7.5
P&P (Carolus Magnus)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Simple and elegant rules, layered strategy, tough decisions. Undoubtedly the best, cleanest area-majority game out there, and lesson 101 on elegant game design. Player scaling is a concern, as anything other than 4-5 players poses a problem.

-------------

Wasn't as fun for my 2nd play, as I was out of the 5-player game after the 2nd scoring, and spent the last 3 rounds contemplating last place. That's almost an hour of boredom, folks. Downside for such a strict player complement.

-------------

Further lowered rating from 8.5 to 8. The decisions are interesting, but there's a lot of player chaos. This is one of those evergreen games which, if released today, wouldn't sniff the BGG Top 20. Surpassed by majority games that have differentiated pieces and clever rules that relax the leader while incentivizing the losers.

3+2

RATING: 4
Excellent game that is thoroughly deserving of its high rank.  Built-in catchup mechanic as everyone gangs up on the leaders at the end, but I'm not sure if this makes it essentially a game of kingmaker.  Would be a 9 if not for this and a little bit of the dryness and may still go up to a 9 with additional play.  We'll see.  Do NOT underestimate the importance of the Castillo!  The cards allow for variance from game to game, but I would have liked to see more variety in the cards, but I suppose there is only so much one can do.  Lots to love about this one.  Perfect 5-player game.

After playing this a couple more times, it has confirmed my opinion that this becomes a game of kingmaker with the trailing players helping to determine the winner.  I don't really like that and this game really only becomes playable for me if we need something for 5 players.  The theme (or lack thereof) is bland and the gameplay just gets dryer with additional plays.  This game immediately goes into the For Trade pile for me.

I realized that I never corrected my rating for this steaming pile of crap.

RATING: 7.8
El Grande -- A must for any eurogame collection.  So much has been written about this one, I feel I have nothing new to add.

Of note:  In his geeklist titled, "Theme changed by the publisher", Bruno Faidutti mentions that the original theme for this game was the Trojan War.  The Castillo was the Trojan Horse!  Yes, it's not a war game.  And yes, the Trojan Horse didn't hold troops from multiple factions.  But it's still an interesting take.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
1 plays, both 4 players.

first play 
-----
People say it's dry and I would disagree with that, instead I would say it's opaque and contraintuitive:
1. Adjacency of two areas is mostly unimportant. Your units enter the map regardless to where your other units are (but next to the king, which I don't get) . 
2. Bidding for turn order. I find it so unnecessary, did all old euros had this? This might be part of calling El Grande dry (Khorne goes first because He Is The Blood God, now shutup!). 
3. The action cards. You simply have to memorize as they don't have any obvious sense (theme wise) beside making the game replayable while making it all about short term tactics. 
4. Kramer's action point system in a completely tactical game = downtime, downtime and AP.

Second game
--------
Showed that knowing which cards are in the deck is truly important. Contraintuitivess matters less, but still, owning Chaos in the Old World I see no reason why I would play this if given the choice between the two. 

I found Torres much better for somewhat similar style game (No turn order nonsense, cards are simpler and the spacial relations make much more sense making the whole thing is more intuitive to grasp).

RATING: 10
all right, this is the only 10 i have given to any game, so i ought to be able to explain myself.

this game has everything i look for in a game:  tough decisions, player interaction, back-stabbing, frustration and beautiful components.  all that in two hours or less...

my most memorable game was a 4-player in which we had a 3-way tie with the 4th player 5 points behind! talk about a nail-biter!

besides that, i have never been tempted to fiddle with the rules, not even a little bit!  it's the only game i can think of that i haven't.

RATING: 6.5
Played once with 5P. El Grande is a pure area control game, and naturally has a good deal of in-built conflict. This is one of those games where deep thought is required to perform well, at the expense of playing time. My one game lasted close to 3 hours, which made me a tad restless. As with most area control games, players need to constantly think ahead of their opponents and know when to assert dominance or consolidate their losses. That said, area control isn't one of my favourite mechanisms. In terms of similar games, I prefer San Marco for its quicker playing time and 'pie-rule' mechanism.
