RATING: 9
Area control. Great game that is simple to understand and can be enjoyed immediately. There is depth to the game that allows you to continuously refine your strategy. Dropping cabelleros into the castillo is a fun mechanic. Playing the shorter variant (6 turns instead of 9) falls a little flat. Some people may think the large wooden pawn representing the king looks like a big turd.  Do not let these people squirt the king piece out of their hand because you won't get the image out of your mind for the rest of the game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
[15 plays] My only 3 player game has revealed that much of the tension evaporates with less than 4 or 5 players.

El Grande is epic. This game hits all the right notes for me. The tactical decisions are numerous but not paralyzing. Messing with your opponents is expected behavior and very fun. Pursuing a grand strategy isn't really possible, but it seems like I always attempt something in the beginning. There are so many opportunities for clever moves throughout, and the games usually end up tense right to the finish. 

The yin-yang card mechanics are a clever way to make sure player's balance their play for the long and short term. The Castillo Tower adds a another nifty element of memory and psychology to the game. I like the bits, the art, and while the theme isn't deep at all - fighting for majority control of the areas is instinctively understood and fun for most people.

"Experts" will tell you that it is best not to be a leader and be targeted, that it is better to hang back and try to slingshot at the end. I disagree, and I will take scoring opportunities as early and often as I can. I have done well playing boldly from the lead.

Most recent play Aug '15.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This game is THE classic typical euro game. Tough and limited decisions and resources. Long term strategy and short term decisions making combine in one VERY intense game experience.

Ranks head and shoulders above E&T and the best of them. Yes, the theme is a little cold but the current 21st century lineage of German/Euro gaming can be traced back to this game.

RATING: 5
Why not higher? I don't know - this game, despite its elegance, just doesn't grab me with the "fever". I think it is incredibly designed and nicely produced. El Grande is an interesting game, but not a particularly fun or fascinating one. I realize El Grande is this landmark game, and is considered by many to be the premier area majority game. And I can see its historical place in the records of game development. But I do not find it that compelling. I like the mechanics - the crucial role of bidding for turn order and so on. But I think El Grande only really shines with five, and when we have five players, we usually play a lighter game, or a meatier game. Which leaves El Grande gathering dust.

RATING: 7
[2011-07-02]
A területfoglalós játékok őse. 1995-ös játék, ami tényleg megállja a helyét a mai játékok között, sőt, szabályának egyszerűsége, a könnyű játékmenete igazán kellemes játékká teszi a spanyolföldön játszódó társast. A 9 területen kell többséget elérnünk, ahova lerakást egy választott akciókártyával tehetjük meg, amin még egy plusz akció is szerepel, amivel további csoportosításokat, speciális értékeléseket tehetünk meg. A játék legizgalmasabb része a torony, amibe láthatatlanul gyűlnek a játékosok kockái és minden értékelés előtt egy titkokban választott tartományra kerülhetnek fel, amivel megbolondíthatják az addig jól számolt stratégiákat. Az El Grandéban elsőre két "hibát" találtam. Egyrészt nagyon gondolkodós lehet egy-egy köre egy játékosnak, másrészt erre a játékra tényleg igaz, hogy fix játékosszámmal igazán élvezetes. Négy játékos esetén még csak-csak, de hárman biztos nem ülnék le hozzá. Egyértelműen öten jön ki a játék igazi nagysága. A játék jó, de számomra nem kiemelkedő a mai jó játékok körében. 95-ben biztos eggyel vagy akár két ponttal is többet adtam volna neki, de most egy erős 7-es jár az El Grandénak.

[2011-08-27]
Sikerült kipróbálnom öten és egyértelműen jobb élményt kaptam. Ez a játék tényleg 5 személyre van kitalálva. A játék szép kivitelezése, a szabályok egyszerűsége és az izgalmas játékmenet megérdemelné a 8 pontot, de valahogy még mindig nem érzem, hogy megfogna a játék és egyre újabb partikat követelnék.

[2012-05-26]
A pontszám nem nő, mert ahogy éreztem hárman katasztrófa. Még öten is van benne rendesen királycsinálási lehetőség, de hárman csak arról szól. Négyen már élvezhető, de mint korábban írtam nagyon ajánlott csak öten leülni hozzá.

RATING: 10
Area majority masterpiece. Still the best after almost 20 years.

The forums are full of opinions that this is a tactical game. No. This is one of the most strategic games I've played. Sure, individual cube placement is tactical, but that won't take you very far. The game is won and lost through strategic cardplay.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This may be my favorite game.  EG is a very dynamic (read: high interaction) area control game.  There are nine regions on a board representing medieval Spain.  At three scheduled points, majorities are assessed in each region.  A majority is achieved by having the most markers (cabelleros) in the region.  The regions have different point values, and some reward second and third place as well.  There is also a region called the Castillo, which is a tower into which cabelleros can be dropped and be hidden.  The castillo is scored first, and any cabelleros in the tower are distributed back onto the board upon scoring by a simultaneous reveal mechanic.  

El Grande is a great social game that can be played at some depth, or intuitively:  really serious players know the card stacks very well and anticipate certain cards, while I enjoy the mostly tactical challenge of dealing with whatever comes up that round. 

Only good with 4 or 5.  Best with 5.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
An excellent game that has become a modern classic. It features a bunch of great mechanics: bid for turn order, draft cards that determine your actions, and score points via area control. The expansions shake it up a bit, in a good way.

Update: Upgrading my overall rating to a 9. This is a quality board game that has stood the test of time. It's hard to think of another game that brings together elegant gameplay mechanisms, player interaction, and tactical balance as well as El Grande does.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
I love this game, and so does my family.  Some of my family are not fleet enough of thought to really embrace games like Puerto Rico, and Settlers, but everyone understands this game, and picks up the subtleties quickly.  The options available the round before the scoring round is incredibly tense, and fun.

The game can be a bit combative, and the last time we played, my mom won three times...and she was working on her third glass of wine at the time, as well.  This would score a perfect 10 if I had a better feeling for the strategy of the game.  The fact that my mom seems to do so well, when her strategy is virtually non-existent cause me to worry about the integrity of the game, however the groups I play with, especially my family is so concerned about me winning a game, sometimes people like my mother are able to establish a huge lead which is challenging, but not difficult to recover from.  All in all, a great game with high quality pieces and tonnes of replayability.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I don't necessarily love the strategy in this game more than Puerto Rico or Tigris and Euphrates or Caylus, but I love that I can play it with almost any group or completely new people, and the new people can feel like they have an idea of what to do more than they would in any of those games.  Or maybe I really do just like this game better.

RATING: 9
I'm always up for a game of El Grande!  The mechanics are great:  using the cards to determine turn order and the number of caballeros to add to your court, the placement of caballeros, the castillo.  An extremely well-designed, original game concept.  You can see its influence in many games.   
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I actually like this game a good deal more than what is usually considered its big brother for gamers: Dominant Species.  While vanilla El Grande is a bit simpler than I tend to like, Dominant Species just felt overly convoluted.  And El Grande being simple makes it a great game for beginners.  There is also a good amount of strategy hidden behind that simplicity making it a very good game for anybody really.  I just don't think its deep enough to have the lifespan of more varied and dynamic games.

I will also warn that the game is best with larger player numbers (4-5) because fewer takes away a lot of the tension that gives this game its strategic chops.  I've played once so far with just 3 and even going last that player has 3 choices of action cards.  With 4 and especially with 5 play order plays a much bigger role in the game and playing the power cards becomes much more exciting, almost like its own mini-game with "Price is Right" style tricks.

RATING: N/A
French Edition. Descartes Editeur. Easy to understand, strategic enough, excellent mechanics, nice historic context and not too long. Every game is a different game. Very elegant.

After all this years this game didn't survive very well in my will to play it. I confess that I'm not too much excited in playing it again in any time soon but I still respect the way this game changed and molded my way to see games, especially euros. El Grande is one of the first euros that introduced some new and fresh mechanics that I still love. But then again, the lack of theme makes me don't like it that much after all these years.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
The popularity of this game tells me that all you Eurogamers are just ATers at heart!  "El Grande" is certainly a conflict-heavy Eurogame, so don't play it with people whose feelings get hurt easily.  In fact, I'd say that it almost has an uncomfortably high screwage factor for a Euro (especially if you're playing with some people that you don't know very well!).  But overall, my impressions after a single play are very positive.  This game is all about player interaction (which likely means that fewer players will decrease the fun factor - we played with 5), and there is no shortage of tension and anticipation.  As a result, a bit of diplomacy even tends to come into play!  Apparently I played the 10th anniversary edition, and I found all the bits to be functional, with a couple that certainly stood out over the others.  The board is large, uncrowded, and pleasing to the eye.  Unfortunately, the game doesn't come with dozens of plastic Spanish soldiers (as my buddy stated, perhaps they're saving that for the 20th anniversary edition!), but the wooden bits work nicely.  I really don't have much that's negative to say after our 5-player game, so I'll just leave it at that!  And you all should be proud of me - I managed to get through that without a single comment about large, black, phallic bits...  Game design: 4.5/5  Personal enjoyment: 3.5/5  Total: 8/10
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
I'm not sure what to think of this game.  On the one hand the rules are simple and the play time is just about right with very little down time.  It is rich in tactics but, unfortunately seems to have ZERO long-term strategy.  I say this because the board changes so quickly that tyring to make long-term plans is impossible.  I love tactical games as much as anybody but I didn't feel like I had much control over things at ALL even with bidding on turn order.  The game came down to a simple procedure of bid based on what my gut told me, hope that card is still there when I take my turn, then just try to maximize my point gain with whichever cards are left on my turn.  In other words, despite the fact I won my first game I didn't derive much satisfaction from it because I thought a lot of it didn't have much to do with me at all.  Maybe I just need to try this game some more because I DO understand why some people like it a lot.

RATING: 6.5
[3 plays]  It is hard for me to decide exactly how to rate this game.  I find the design of the game clever and interesting.  The games I have played have been tight and hard fought.  Definately has a good amount of thinking which I like.  But it seems like both times I have played the ending of the game was odd and anti-climatic.  Like king-making/ganging up on the leader or some twist at the end that just sort of took the wind of the sails.  Maybe it has just been flukes but it has been enough to keep this game from being requested that often over other Euro-games in my gaming group.  I am curious to try this one more though, I would try it a few more times, learn the strategy a bit better, get a better handle for how to bid in the auctions, which cards to try for, etc.  Also hopefully to see get a better handle on the end of game deal.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Another game I'll have to play a couple more times to solidify my feelings.  I'm not very good at area-control games, in general.  But while I wasn't impressed with this at first, in retrospect I find that there are some nice mechanics going on here, it doesn't feel too heavy, and it ends in a fairly reasonable length of time.

The tower of hidden cubes adds a nice memory/press-your-luck component, as well as a last minute element of change before scoring that keeps scoring rounds more tense.  The hidden-location rondels for each player allow for simultaneous secret actions in a concise (if slightly gimmicky) manner.  The special action cards allow for some good interaction and screw-your-neighbor plays.  I'm not a giant fan of the cube-farming mechanic (moving cubes from the provinces to your court), but it isn't nearly as omnipresent and annoying as it is in Notre Dame, so I'll let that slide.

I'd definitely play a couple more times, though it's not at the top of my to-do list.  Maybe I'm just a sucker for cube-towers.

COLORBLINDNESS NOTE: Oh jeez, the green and brown cubes are nigh indistinguishable.  WHY NOT BLACK AS A COLOR?  SHEESH.  So, yeah, this caused some issues in putting cubes in areas where I thought there was one other person with a lot of brown cubes when, in fact, the green and brown players were both there.  Careful with this if you have color impairment!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
A must have.  If you're at this site, you most likely already own this game.

A terrific combination of mechanics that allows for tactical decision making, and, despite what some say, plenty of long term strategic control.  I just don't understand how some say there is no strategy because you don't know what all the cards will be each turn. 

Personally, I think it is great with 3 or 4, even ok with 2 (though most disagree), and maybe the best game out there with 5.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
[u]Key Words:[/u] Area Control - 3-5 Players - 90mins

[u]Summarized Opinion:[/u] One of the best area majority games around.

[u]My Rating Explained:[/u] Very good game. I love to play it.

[u]Verbose Assessment:[/u]

Although I'm not a fan of area majority games, I think this is one of the best.

There's much to keep an eye on: how do you play the power cards that will determine player order? Which of the action cards is the best? When to move the king, and to which region? Do I place my cabbalero's first? There's so many things to consider.

As with many of this type of game, El Grande suffers a bit from kingmaker syndrome with more than 3 players, so for me 3 is the sweet spot, offering enough control and avoiding multi-player chaos. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Original and strategic area majority game. Players attempt to move cubes depicting caballeros into various regions of Spain. Whenever scoring occurs, which takes place every four rounds, the players with the most cubes in a region score the most points. It's a deceptively simple game and there is an emphasis on cleverly positioning yourself in turn order so that you can make best possible use of the options available to you, but this is a deeply strategic game and is an essential play for those interested in the area majority style.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Just played this 14 years (!) after I bought it (somewhere around 1998).

A lot of games would have lost their shine by a long shot but this game... wow. Should have played this much, much, much earlier. 

What a smooth and elegant game design. It gives a very pleasant play experience, with just the right mix of 'gotcha', 'thinking' and 'pleasantness' as we played it.

Great game. Even for nowadays standards.

[EDIT OKT 2016] Ran into the El Grande Big Box at Spiel 2016. Thought about trading my base game, but the like the box, the map art, the castillo and even the cubes of the base game over the big box version. Ended up putting all expansions of the big box (including the updated cards) into the base game box and shelving the big box (with the base game cards) in the attic with my other empty expansion boxes. Now I just wonder if I'm ever going to USE those expansions, as the base game itself is actually so good on its own.

RATING: 8.5
This game is in a class of its own. So simple to teach, yet gameplay is incredibly deep and complex. It's a highly tactical game (in other words: interactive), and the tension from turn to turn is exceptionally high. You are continually forced to react to your opponents' decisions, and I find this to be a wonderful thing.

El Grande is exactly the all-time area control classic you've always heard about, and the best 5-player game I've ever played.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
El Grande is a very nice area control game that has a bit of bidding/bluffing in it that makes it very good.  There are a couple of different strategies, plus groupthink which can derail a game and change it completely.  I think this is a good thing.  You have to be adaptable to what everyone else at the table is doing.

With 5 players.  This is very very good.  With 4 players, it's a still good, but much more friendly.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
I wondered if this game would be as good as is generally felt on the geek.  For the most part I have to agree with the ratings, however I guess I have one to many area control games right now so this was another in a long string of them that I have purchased which takes a bit of the edge off it.  To its benefit it plays a little faster than some of the other ones I have and the rules explanation didn't take me near as long as normal.  For now it is among the better of the area control games I own, but not many of them are so good that I rank them up in the 8 or 9 zone.

RATING: N/A
5,2-5
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Really solid game.  I love that you only need the base rules, and only four new actions come in each round.  It makes the game very accessible for new players.  The fact that you score after every three rounds is a bit of a problem since it makes it easier to see who will win.

I think control of the king is too critical as well;  securing a region as well as getting 2 bonus points makes it too powerful during the scoring rounds.  I also don't quite grasp the Veto card.  

Oftentimes there are two players who don't have a chance to win after the sixth round.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6.5
I can see why this is a classic.  It does so many things well, from the bidding to determine turn order, dropping cubes in a tower, the King, and the variety of actions you can take.

But ultimately it is just a game about distributing your cubes into different regions such that your cubes score more points that your opponent's cubes.  That is just not a mechanic that I enjoy.  It's the same reason that I didn't really like [thing=142326][/thing] despite the fact that it did everything else right.

RATING: 8
A clear, concise and reasonably fast-paced area control game that holds it's suspense until the end. Ergonomics-wise I think it's one of the best boardgames ever designed - the colors & graphics are very clear and easy to the eye and the various play aids (Castillo, scoring aid etc.) are very functional, the only fault being that the scoring track has no numbers. And, being set in medieval Spain gives it a very fitting theme.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This is my favourite of the classic Euro games.

It keeps you on your toes since the decisions of others are as interesting and nearly as impactful to your score as the decisions you make yourself.  Highly tactical.  It has great interaction with the other players as each jockeys for the best positions through the auction bidding and the manipulation of the pieces on the board.  

It's essentially themeless, which is usually a turn-off for me, but it's such a brilliant, stream-lined design that it wins me over completely.

Good-looking and functional board/pieces.  Looks great mid-game.

Best with five players, but still enjoyable with three or four.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
First Impression:
An area control eurogame that works perfectly well.

Before El Grande I was claiming that area control games should have some aspect of negotiation/territory building in order to provide a basis for the kingmaking that inevitably follows (f.e. I'm attacking you and not him because you didn't do this or that). And here comes this grandpa of boardgames to teach me never to say never. A eurogame that is pure area control, with minimum kingmaking. Sure you go after a specific player if you so want it, but you're going to finish dead last if you do so. With simple yet deep desicions, El Grande is a game that keeps the great interaction of area control, but discards the chaos of it with a clever drafting/hand management mechanism.

So what's not o like here? As an old euro the game doesn't try that much to carry its theme, though, surprisingly, it's far more thematic than many more modern boardgames.

Overall El Grande rejuvanated my faith for euro area control games. It's a v.good game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.8
This is THE area control game. Best learned by playing with experienced players, this game is incredibly deep. The game is just awesome. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A great classic game with a lot of player interaction and nastiness. My only problem is the very tactical nature of the game. There is also quite a lot of downtime. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Didn't like this -- just wasn't very much fun.  Don't know why this is called a strategy game.  Due to the amount of chaos/changes that go on between turns, this is entirely a tactical exercise with no ability to make and carry out long term plans.  On top of that, it is slow to play with lots of downtime as others ponder their changed situations.  I'm willing to give it another try before writing it off completely, but I'm very skeptical that my rating will improve.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Nice decisions.  Angling.  Well thought out plans.  Then your opponents screws you over and you mutter to yourself, "Why Grande?, Why?"  The tactical points of the game are quite intuitive.  I'm still trying to hammer out the strategical side of things.  I'm sure its there, the games I've done well my board looked different than the games I haven't.  Its fun hammering away at this one.  I must find a way to rise above the chaos.... or at least get my head above water.   It just seems the winner is more of a function of the other players than what they accomplished.  The ability to hurt others far outweighs the ability to help yourself.  

I'd like to try this with 4.  I think that'd be my personal sweet spot.  It should pony up more control, leave the pure negative cards in the unused pile, because it would be responded to because of the threat, but not used because of its lack of benefit to the person picking the card.  I'm not sure it would rise more than a point though.  

I like everything about the design.  There are great decisions to be made, but at the end of the game I'm always left disappointed in who managed the victory.  It never feels like it was the person who played the best game, but was left alone the most. (even, especially?  when I win)

RATING: 10
I pre-ordered this from Thought Hammer in October of 2005, and it didn't arrive until the end of July of 2006, but it was worth the wait!  This is one of my new favorite games, and definitely has the potential to move up to a 10 rating with repeated plays.  I just can't get enough of area control games it seems -- UPDATE: Moved it up to a 10 because after every game I finished I immediately want to play again.  The game is so fantastic because without being too complicated or convuluted it manages to present you with a lot of difficult decisions to make.  The game is pretty fast paced because there's little down time and it's crucial to stay involved on everyone else's turn.  One of the very best games out there in my opinion!

Received as gift: Christmas 2005

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
In this award-winning game, players take on the roles of Grandes in medieval Spain. The king's power is flagging, and these powerful lords are vying for control of the various provinces. To that end, you draft caballeros (knights) into your court and subsequently move them onto the board to help seize control of provinces. After every third turn, the regions are scored, and after the ninth turn, the Grande with the most points is deemed the winner.

RATING: 9
07/2007:9.5
The game is as advertised... simply amazing! I have enjoyed every single game I have played, with varying number of players. The balance and uncertainty of choices really makes this game shine. The only worry I have is that there are a lot of variable power cards, but since you only get so many choices each round, explanations of these cards don't have to be made early on prior to the game. The castillo device is unique and increases the tension of the game. The base game is fun enough that I have not even yet try the expansion.

072911
It has at least been several years since I last played El Grande. The game is still the grand daddy of all area majority games. After several more years of gaming experience and replaying this game, I realized how cut throat and unpredictable this game can become. This is not necessarily a criticism, but given how much control we want in our actions, sometimes the action cards can really stymie how we choose to play. Still, nothing is hidden and all the available actions are in plain sight. So, in a way, you can try to mitigate the actions by choosing to go first in turn order. I would consider the game high conflict. With our low conflict group, the tensions ran high (very unusual for this even keeled gang of friends). Still, as tempted as I am to lower my ratings, this game will remain high on my perch of games that is both fun and challenging: something I find amazing given the amount of games I have played and the fact that this game is 16 years old.

Grant beat us to it.  Looks like a good one.

We play this with five exactly.  It's also served well as an intro game for quite a few new gamers.

RATING: 9
Since the players can do a fair bit to each other, there is a fair amount of chaos. However, there are ways to mitigate it through the placement of your Caballeros. The Castillo is a lot of fun when you're parachuting to the board, since there is a lot of double think going on. The game is a lot of fun, with both new and experienced people, since it is difficult to have a runaway leader

RATING: 8
Best part of this game is the name and the inevitable female reaction when you whip out El Grande, slap him on the board, and watch him tower, erect and proud, above the  less well-endowed pieces in the game.

I've rarely seen my wife at a loss for words, but all she could manage was a mirth-choked "you're having me on, right?  What's El Grande's real name? Johnson? Richard?"
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Have played it twice, once with [url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/boardgame/3146-El%20Grande:%20Grand%20Inquisitor%20&%20the%20Colonies]the Grand Inquisitor and Colonies expansion[/url], once without.  This game is alright, but you'll be best served if you understand going into it that it is very minimal.  This is one of the granddaddies of Euros, and it shows.  Coming back to it as I have, it does not really feel original, because it's been copied by so many other games out there, and it doesn't have a gimmick like any new game in the category will have.  This is sparse, barebones area majority.  But it certainly does some things well.  There's conflict just beneath the skin, which is always a plus for me.  The scoring in different regions is quite entertaining, and the cards provide a good, but not excessive amount of randomness.

RATING: N/A
Wolfgang Kramer & Richard Ulrich; recommended for 4 or 5 players; draft caballeros (knights) into your court and subsequently move them onto the board to help seize control of provinces; Expanded by: El Grande: Intrigue & the King, El Grande - Koenig & Intrigant - Player's Edition, El Grande: König & Intrigant - Unverkäufliche Sonderkarten, El Grande: Grand Inquisitor & the Colonies, El Grande: Grandissimo; the three main expansions were included in the 2006 Decennial Edition.

RATING: 5
Here's the thing: I admire area control games, even though I don't do well at them.  When the theme and the game mechanisms come together well, then I don't mind playing them.  With El Grande, though, there's too much of a chaotic "I'm a-gonna mess with your shit!" element to the game for me to really stomach it.  I like that the designer added some other touches to prevent it from being completely random, but in the long run, there's too much in the game that can mess with your carefully laid plans.

3 plays: 5 players

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
In this award-winning game, players take on the roles of Grandes in medieval Spain. The king's power is flagging, and these powerful lords are vying for control of the various provinces. To that end, you draft caballeros (knights) into your court and subsequently move them onto the board to help seize control of provinces. After every third turn, the regions are scored, and after the ninth turn, the Grande with the most points is deemed the winner.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
After seeing El Grande in the BGG top ten for a few years but never getting the opportunity to play, I finally broke down and bought it blind. Thankfully, the game has lived up to its stellar reputation.

Truth be told, I was actually a little surprised at just how simple the rules to El Grande turned out to be. I guess I was expecting a heavier rule set, along the lines of Caylus or Die Macher. Still, simplistic or not, the balancing act between drafting good action cards and maintaining a good flow of caballero tokens makes for an incredibly engaging game. There is also a nice bit of diplomacy that creeps into the game, as players must often work together to reign in anyone that starts to score big and pull away from the group. There is also a fair bit of secret deployment that goes on, which again creates an atmosphere of negotiation and double cross.

I haven't played it enough to know if it really has the legs to be a top ten game for me, but I can say that my initial impressions have been very, very good.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A fun area control game. Players bid for the order of play, with the lowest bidding cards letting them bring more caballeros into their court. Then, in order, players choose the action cards, which give them a special action and tell them to place from 1-3 caballeros on the board.

The game feels chaotic with 5 people, as things can shift around wildly. I'll have to play again at some point :)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
I have only played this game once since I have picked it up, but it is an incredible game.  The number of decisions to be made is enormous, and the game play is fast.  Also, it seems like players are not really out of the game until the final scoring round determines the winner.
REVISED - Make this game an 11, it is that good.

REVISION II - After playing this game quite a bit, I can say that this game is one of the best ones out there.  It works well with 4, but is best with 5.  The angst with 5 is great, do you take the power to deny it to another player, or do you go for the one that is going to set you up better for the next turn, etc., etc.  If you're stranded with 5 other people on a desert island, this is definitely a game you want to have with you.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
Neat game.  A little tough to get into on your first game though - there's no way you can cover all the action cards,  and I'd imagine advanced players know what's in which deck.  And counting what goes into the castille is important - I forgot I had put things in there,  which could have changed strategies.  Silly memory.

Downsides - having this huge variety of actions seems a bit fiddly to me -  added complexity that complicates things for newcomers. 

Urgh...looks like those printing errors in the Decennial edition won't be going away any time soon.   Even though this is on my list of "must-buy classic games",  I'll probably play the open copy at Drexoll's before committing.

RATING: 8.75
Muy sencillo y para todos los públicos. Táctico y estratégico a partes iguales, consiste en influenciar mayoritariamente las provincias con los caballeros respecto a los rivales. Importante decisión el saber escoger adecuadamente las acciones de juego (de ello depende todo). Muy rejugable, reglas sencillas y para todo tipo de jugadores. Algo de análisis-paralisis puede haber en la elección de acciones y en la colocación de caballeros. Si no aseguras tu posición y estrategia, la partida puede dar muchos giros inesperados pero predecibles.

Incluye las expansiones de El Rey y el Intrigante, Grandissimo y El Gran Inquisidor y Las Colonias. Con fundas cuadradas tamaño 70x70mm, fundas tamaño eurogame 59X91mm y fundas tamaño mini-eurogame 44x67mm.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Terrific area control strategy game of Medieval Spain that withstands the aging of time.  Each round players select single use initiative cards from identical decks to get first dibs on action cards while placing knights for majority in territories adjacent to the King pawn's taboo territory. During scoring rounds the 3D castle tower reveals tucked away knights for majority points and the spin dial determines what territory they invade.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This classic game of politics in Spain was a pioneer area-majority game and inspired a whole genre of modern games.  The build-up to the scoring, the scrambling for position, and the possibility for sweeping changes and brilliant moves make this game a masterpiece.

This is one of the best examples of a tactical game where players really need to be flexible from turn to turn.  You can not usually plan a long-term strategy in El Grande, because there are so many unpredictable events, especially in the 4 or 5 player game.  Every game of El Grande is unique, challenging and fun.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
{ P - 2 3 [4] 5 }
[CK]

Area control is a mechanic that appeals to me when I play games like Louis XIV, Struggle of Empires, and Age of Empires III. However, those games involve the development of infrastructure or additional mechanics like worker placement; by comparison, El Grande is an exercise in pure tactical area control. What I find occurs in such games is that players place their influence or use screw-your-neighbor opportunities to keep everyone else in check and the guy picked on least by his opponents will win.

After a few scorings someone is out in front, and players must bash the leader because if unhindered he will maintain first place and ultimately win. Put another way, when a player gets an opportunity that scores him extra points, in all likelihood the action is actually worthless because he will lose points later that he otherwise would have scored because his opponents are obligated to target him. If this process is performed effectively, players' scores will remain within a small range, and big plays around the third scoring will decide the game.

El Grande's excessively tactical nature has other issues. The value of a Mobile Scoring tile varies wildly depending on whether the other two copies of it are lurking right below. A typical plan to drop '13' and have the last word on the King's whereabouts can be arbitrarily thwarted by Royal Advisor. Decay of Authority is extremely nasty and fear of the card nullifies an actual strategy like playing 1-3 within the first half of the game to enable 10-13 for the second half. Turn order introduces problems as well; many turns nobody selects the 1-stack, screw-your-neighbor actions because of the restriction on piece placement but when a player is dropping '1' this turn no matter what to prepare for next turn's pre-scoring '13' he'll often be stuck picking between the 1-stack or some crappy 2-stack card so he'll take the screw-your-neighbor - a completely situational shaft if you happen to be that neighbor encroaching on what he considers his turf.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9.5
Excellent area control game with lots of indirect interaction (by virtue of muddling with people's scoring potential and bidding). Lots of difficult choices, and a large mix of different things to do (bidding, forced scoring, various actions, etc). The downside, like PR, is that a poorly planned move by one player can severely impact the score of several others, without their knowledge. The potential for kingmaking other players through poor (or even intentional) decisions is clear, but the fact that information and scoring are public offsets this disadvantage somewhat.

RATING: 7
[b]GOOD.[/b]

Still formulating my ultimate opinion on this puppy due to the fewish number of games played; though I must declare that I love all the wooden cubes, the slender tower, the beautiful board, and the massive king pawn.
El Grande is a lot of fun to play, and can take a while, though the time invested is certainly worth the effort.
This is a well-designed Euro game, possibly the best. The rules are fast to master and well explained. Also, other than the hidden cubes within the confines of the castle, this is a game of perfect information: no dicerolling is required. Solid play will always triumph during a game of El Grande.

There is much to admire with this game. I also like the fact that the score track surrounds the play area; the same can be said of the turn sequence track.

RATING: 8
A classic quintessential area control game.  The placement and scoring are simple enough, but adding in some fun tricks linking turn order, special actions and supply of cubes to add to the map make El Grande something special.  If you enjoy area control I highly recommend you try this excellent game at some point.  If you don't like controlling areas you will however not like this game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Quite honestly, for about 2/3 of my first game, I wasn't quite sure what the big deal is about El Grande.  The bidding mechanism has already been done elsewhere; the randomness of the cards was often a source of frustration; and it certainly didn't help that I was pulling the rear.  The scoring was somewhat unique, as well as the attainment and placement of your pieces, but for the most part I felt very out of sync throughout the game, I wasn't sure what strategy to use.  However, things began to click into place at the last third of the session, and surprisingly I managed to win in the end.  I definitely can't credit that to great playing on my part, but what I had first thought to be a foregone conclusion in terms of the leaders, I am most certainly intrigued by the change in the final scoring.  There is definitely more than meets the eyes here, and I for sure will want to try this again.

Update #1: So far I'm 3-0 in El Grande.  Have I figured this game out?  Not sure, the first two times I didn't really have any strategy so I assumed I won because of luck rather than any skillful playing on my part.  The most recent session did involve a much more careful consideration and planning, while maintaining the same importance on one factor that I've employeed successfully before.  I ended up at least 12 points ahead the 2nd place.  I think I'm liking this more and more.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
The classic area-influence game.  If you're into Eurogames and haven't played El Grande yet, you don't know what you're missing.  To me, has stood the test of time (almost ten years old and I still would never refuse a game).  A superb design.  Ratings update: dipped slightly to 8.5 due to the potential lack of control of how others can screw you over.  Kingmaking potential exists, even at the cost of hurting you if you're not in the lead at the time.

RATING: 7.9
Very simple game, but so many possibilities. Played this one with just 2 players, and to be honest. It isn’t suitable as a 2 player game. You have to play this with 3 or 4 players. With 5, it might take just too long before one turn is over. 4 players would be a perfect group. Every player can choose a special action, without being forced to ‘just to take the last one, just because it’s the only one left’. The auction of the turn-order is important, because you can play a certain power-card just only once.  Tactics will become more important, because the King would be dancing around the gameboard. The tower (Il Castillo), will be way more difficult to count all the Caballero’s that are disappearing inside it. Great game, but you have to be with 4 players (or 3).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
A játék a XV. századi Spanyolországon alapul, ahol öt etnikai csoport verseng egymással.;) Mindegyikben a magas arisztokrácia (Grande-k) és az átlagos arisztokrácia (Caballerok) kap fontos szerepet. Minden régióban növelni próbálják hatalmukat és befolyásukat. Ebben a kastélyok (Castillos) is fontos szerepet játszanak. A játék célja: Minden játékos egy régió Grandeja. Van 30 szövetséges lovagja (Caballeroja). Mindegyik Grande megkísérli Spanyolországban megszerezni a legnagyobb befolyást azáltal, hogy a lovagjaikkal megpróbál többséget szerezni minél több régióban. 

Vélemény a játékról: Az egyik legszínvonalasabbnak tartott játékom. :meeple: (A BGG-n benne van a Top 20-ba). Kemény küzdelem végig a játék folyamán sok interakcióval. Nagy kihívás megszerezni a legjobb akciókártyákat, melyekkel nagyobb befolyást tudunk elérni, ebben segít a jó helyzetfelismerés és előretervezés. Tetszik a játékossorend meghatározása (hatalomkártyák kijátszása dönti el), a kastély (ahová betehetünk lovagokat és át is helyezhetjük pontozáskor), a titkos korong és pontozótáblák használata, valamint az, hogy be lehet állítani a játék hosszát a fordulók meghatározása által (1,5, vagy 2 óra legyen a játék).  Egy kis negatívum, hogy 2 játékossal nem igazán élvezetes. Ajánlanám hozzá a kiegészítők beszerzését, melyek magasan emelik a játék színvonalát. Itt gondolok a König & Intrigant-ra (ami számos akciólapot ad plusszba és segítségével könnyebb egyéni stratégiát felépíteni), valamint a Grossinquizitor und Kolonien-t és Grandissimo-t, melyek eseménydússá teszik a játékot (5 új régió, hajózás, kereskedelemi áruk, 2 új akciópakli, Inkvizítor és lovagjai, tömlöc és királynő).

Játék tartozékairól: nem a legdesignosabbak, de visszaadja  középkori hangulatot. 

Szabálykönyvről: Nagyon jó felépítésű, könnyen érthető és magyarázható (kb 15 perc). 

Kiknek ajánlanám: gémereknek, akik szeretik az összetett stratégiát. :laugh:

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
After 10+ Plays: When played with five this is absolutely one of my favorite games.  With fewer it is still fun, but a pale imitation of the 5-player game.  It's one of the more directly confrontational euros, as nearly every point gained is one taken from an opponent.  The restrictions on placement related to the king really make the game.  To many area control games actually give you too many options.  Paradoxically I think there are more interesting strategic choices when you don't have access to all possible placements.  The cards add two great levels of decision making.  The first is knowing when to bid high for turn order to grab a card you really want.  The second is the careful weighing of the benefits of using a betters card's power, or taking a less powerful card just to get more cubes onto the board.

I've played with a couple of the expansions, and I don't think they are worth the time.  I would still like to try the one that totally does away with the existing cards.  It sounds like a completely different game using El Grande's basic area majority structure.  I doubt I'll like it more, but I'd like to compare.
